IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Altered mitochondrial networking and energetics contributes to age-related diseases. Maintenance of mitochondrial networking is a function of the balance between rates of mitochondrial fission and fusion, which is, in turn, regulated by proteins localized at endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria contacts or MAMs. Studies in this application will advance our understanding of the interplay between mTORC2 kinase and its downstream targets at MAMs in preventing age-related decline in mitochondrial fission and energetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal focuses on developing a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism by which miR-21, an miRNA that is strongly associated with mouse and human SLE but yet poorly characterized, drives autoimmune responses and lupus nephritis. We will learn how an interplay of miR-21 and TLR7 signaling regulates B cell activation and metabolism in TLR7-promoted SLE. Finally, we will learn whether miR-21 or miR-21 regulated pathway(s) can be a therapeutic target for SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: As an orally transmitted pathogen, EBV translocates across the tonsillar epithelium and infects B cells, whereupon reaching the memory B-cell compartment, it silences nearly all of viral protein-coding genes to avoid immune detection. Here, we will investigate how lymphocyte metabolism pathways are subverted to cloak EBV’s presence, and how interventions such as restriction of the amino acid methionine can be used to reverse this silencing mechanism. The research promises to provide new directions in treatment of EBV-driven disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Fluoridated drinking water has been praised as one of the 10 great public health achievements of the 20th century, but its growth has stalled, leaving over 100 million Americans with drinking water that is not fluoridated, and which probably never will be. Fluoridated bottled water represents a publicly-acceptable and potent strategy for dental caries prevention in underserved communities. To provide scientific evidence to justify the strategy, this study will undertake the first ever randomized controlled trial to evaluate dental caries preventive effects of fluoridated bottled drinking water in 3-year-old children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases such as cancer and its development and progression, the pathogenesis of commensal microbes, and emergence of antimicrobial drug resistance are analogous to the process of adaptive evolution. Accordingly, the adaptation of biological systems poses a challenge to public health. A deeper understanding of how fungal pathogens respond and adapt to environmental stressors in biofilm states will lead to new treatment strategies and therapeutics.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE  The CTSA Predoctoral T32 Program at The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio will operate in collaboration with the Institute for Integration of Medicine and Science (IIMS), home for our CTSA. Predoctoral Trainees will be selected for an innovative 2-year program and trained to become the next- generation of translational scientists. The training in rigorous research, process innovation, systems thinking, and boundary crossing, along with team science and cultural diversity, will accelerate transformative breakthroughs and facilitate work in highly skilled, multidisciplinary teams that address threats to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research improves public health because it will define factors that modulate DNA repair that directly control the outcome of genome editing therapies. Identifying factors that manipulate DNA repair pathways has the potential to advance these therapies for rare and common genetic diseases. This research addresses fundamental questions about mammalian DNA repair, which is relevant to the NIH’s mission of improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The cognitive and mental health burden among virally suppressed people with HIV (VS-PWH) remains a major issue in HIV care. Integrity of the blood brain barrier (BBB) and immune cells migrating into the brain may contribute to neuroinflammation and related neuropsychiatric burden in VS-PWH. To better understand how HIV affects the BBB and the role of neuroinflammation, we will perform brain scans using a novel, noninvasive technique to measure BBB breakdown and tests of cognitive and mental health in a group of VS-PWH and demographically similar HIV-uninfected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In rodents, diets high in calories, fat, and/or added sugars cause inflammation in brain areas that regulate body weight, leading to overeating and obesity. The proposed research uses magnetic resonance imaging to evaluate the human hypothalamus for signs of inflammation in response to a similar diet. This research may lead to a better understanding of whether poor nutritional quality leads to obesity through effects on body-weight regulating areas of the brain in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is accumulating evidence showing that the circadian system plays a critical role in many physical activity-related pathways and regulates the diurnal variations in the cardiometabolic responses to physical activity. This raises the question whether timing may modulate the adaptive responses of physical activity, and can thus be used to enhance the health benefits of physical activity. Here, we aim to test the relationship between timing of physical activity and cardiometabolic outcomes in humans, with the hope of providing mechanistic insights that may assist in the design of lifestyle interventions to improve the efficacy of physical activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This award will continue supporting activities of the longstanding Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities Research Center (IDDRC) at the Kennedy Krieger Institute and Johns Hopkins University. The IDDRC's primary goals focus on supporting actively funded research projects targeting intellectual and developmental disorders (IDD) through Cores (Administrative, Clinical Translational Research, Genomics, Neuroimaging, and Behavioral Phenotyping). In addition, the Center directly supports a research project examining the role of sleep, circadian dysfunction, and brain development in children with autism.

PHR: This research proposal will inform public health decisions, as our findings will transform how clinicians and scientists think about neurodegeneration in Parkinson's Disease and Parkinsonism's. Understanding factors that render cells vulnerable to degeneration and the common and distinct mechanisms of molecular dysregulation underlying the disease states, particularly among inherited or familial subtypes, will increase the accuracy and precision to predict risk, improve diagnosis and establish a new framework for innovative therapeutic strategies in line with the mission of the NIH to improve the human condition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has pervasive and detrimental neurobiological and psychological consequences, and PTSD prevalence rates as high as 30-50% are observed among civilians living in areas with high violence. In addition, children of mothers with posttraumatic symptoms (PTS) are at increased risk for stress-related psychological disorders thereby promoting a cycle of intergenerational transmission of stress reactivity. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to combine clinical and developmental psychopathology research and basic neuroscience research to establish a mechanistic model of intergenerational PTS risk that can be translated into clear treatment targets in at-risk mothers and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Throughout life, the cerebellum calibrates both reflexes and learned movements, and is required for our most fundamental daily activities, ranging from writing to walking and speaking. This calibration requires a form of learning that has traditionally been thought to be guided by movement errors. We propose to test a new model of cerebellar learning based on predictions about reward that could enable learning to be guided by principles of reinforcement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sociodemographic changes and revised US Census questions have led to new recognition of the growth in the proportion of people self-identifying as biracial. However, despite calls from NIDA for etiological research to inform primary prevention of adolescent substance use, little is known about substance use among biracial youth. The proposed research aims to provide information critical to both the speedy refinement of existing programs and the creation of targeted programs for biracial adolescents and emerging adults. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health disparities in the burden of multiple chronic conditions in the Chicago region are attributed to a history of racial segregation leaving gaps in economic opportunities and gaps in the healthcare system. The Chicago Chronic Condition Equity Network (C3EN) will address these gaps by strengthening and building collaborations across community-based organizations, practice networks, and academic researchers, by promoting a comprehensive approach to the prevention and management of multiple chronic conditions that accounts for mental health, functional health and social life, and by supporting interventions that actively seek to cross boundaries of disease-specific management, professional training, community and practice.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiometabolic diseases currently pose one of the biggest threats to health and development globally, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. Despite calls from expert panels, little progress has been made in reducing this disease burden. We propose a nutrition-focused interdisciplinary predoctoral program to train leaders with expertise across global cardiometabolic disease biology, epidemiology, social, and environmental determinants that will translate to effective individual and global policy prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national challenge in the biomedical sciences is to recruit, train, and retain the broadest and most diverse scientific talent pool possible. At the University of Utah, we are poised to tackle this challenge by leveraging our recent successes in recruiting underrepresented students into our graduate programs and redoubling our efforts on the postbaccalaureate population. We will establish the Intermountain Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program and solidify key relationships with our local community and Historically Black Colleges and Universities to foster an inclusive, research-intensive environment where underrepresented scientists can flourish and attain their goal of admission to top-notch PhD training programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study seeks to provide large-scale, foundational evidence that high-intensity rehabilitation is effective and can be systematically implemented to improve functional outcomes for patients admitted to skilled nursing facilities following hospitalization. Additionally, this study will generate a descriptive overview of factors that predict implementation success while informing effective implementation strategies for future skilled nursing facilities innovation. Overall, this study is a critical step in advancing clinical practice to establish high-intensity rehabilitation as an effective standard of care in skilled nursing facilities to shift current treatment away from low-intensity, conservative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Candidate: Kurella Tamura, Manjula PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed K24 Midcareer Investigator Award ‘A Mentoring Program in Kidney Care for Older Adults’ will support a multi-disciplinary research program and train the next generation of patient-oriented researchers. Building on a track record of successfully mentoring junior investigators, this proposal will enable the candidate to dedicate more time to mentoring trainees, gain new skills that will expand the scope of her research, and conduct new research that will extend evidence from large clinical trials in hypertension and kidney disease to evaluate the comparative risks and benefits of intensive blood pressure targets in real world older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hirschsprung disease (HSCR) is congenital gastrointestinal condition affecting 1 in 5,000 infants that is characterized by the absence of an enteric nervous system (ENS) in the distal intestine. Even after surgery to remove the distal intestine, there is significant bowel dysfunction in the remaining intestine, highlighting the imperative to identify the key cellular and molecular drivers of ongoing intestinal dysfunction. As an aspiring pediatric surgeon-scientist, my goal is to leverage the K08 mechanism to provide a foundation for my independent academic career and to explore my central hypothesis that biomechanical forces trigger dysregulation of the intestinal extracellular matrix (ECM) microenvironment, which in turn alters the behavior of the ENS and ultimately drives gut dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of death, accounting for 1/3 of all cancer deaths. There are significant disparities in tobacco-induced cancer morbidity and mortality and reducing this disparate burden of disease requires understanding how the tobacco industry attempts to influence regulation, conduct target marketing, and oppose the diffusion innovative local and state level policies that promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. Deaf community – a group of more than 500,000 Americans who communicate using American Sign Language (ASL) – experiences nearly triple the rate of lifetime problem drinking compared to the general population. Yet, there are no therapy approaches that have been developed and formally tested to treat problem drinking or alcohol use disorder among Deaf clients. The proposed K23 study will begin to address this gap by supporting the development and preliminary validation of Deaf Motivational Enhancement Therapy (Deaf- MET), a Deaf-accessible pre-treatment for alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative-Relevance  This revised R01 application tackles one of the most challenging problems in the cancer field: brain metastases (BM). The major goal of this research is to determine how the dynamic interactions of MHC-II on BM tumor cells and Lag3 on microglia, the unique innate immune cells in the brain, control BM, and to develop novel therapeutic strategies using clinically-applicable epigenetic drugs to enhance MHC-II expression and immune response to treat BM. Our research findings can be smoothly translated to clinical trials, leading to new and better BM treatments to enhance the quality of life and prolong survival of patients suffering from BMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Spirulina is a top selling botanical for improving immune health. This proposal is directed towards generating sufficient data to optimally design future human intervention studies to evaluate the utility of Spirulina-derived oral supplements in promoting resilience against viral infections such as influenza. The use of a Spirulina-derived oral supplement may provide an important complementary approach to currently available antiviral therapies that is inexpensive, safe and readily available to the public.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative PHACS 2020 is a Program Project P01 grant, consisting of the following four support Cores: Scientific Administrative Core (SAC), Data Resources Core (DRC), Health Education and Community Core (HECC), and the Epidemiological and Statistical Methods Core (ESC) to provide scientific, site and cohort infrastructure, data management and analysis, health education and community input, as well as epidemiological and statistical support to four Research Projects: 1) Surveillance Monitoring for ART Toxicities (SMARTT); 2) The Adolescent Master Protocol (AMP) Up Series (the AMP Up Series); 3) Natural History of Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) and Human Papillomavirus (HPV) in HPV Vaccinated Youth with Perinatal HIV (PHIV) (HPV); and 4; the TERBO BRAIN Study: Trajectories of Emotional Regulation and Behavior Outcomes and related Brain Regions And Intrinsic Networks (TERBO BRAIN). This multidisciplinary, interactive and synergistic P01 will address the most critical scientific questions for children, youth and young adults living with or exposed to perinatal HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative During the previous period of support we identified brain regions and clinical symptoms affected by childhood maltreatment that prospectively increased risk for substance use and created the Maltreatment and Abuse Chronology of Exposure scale and novel AI procedures to identify type and timing of maltreatment that were the most important predictors of brain changes and risk for substance use. One aim of this continuing program of research is to provide the first rigorous test of our hypothesis that maltreated and non-maltreated individuals with substance used disorders have distinctly different neurobiological signatures, and that maltreatment and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder represent two distinctly different pathways to substance use, with far reaching implications for prevention, treatment and discovery. The second aim is to determine the degree to which inflammation and sleep stage disruption mediate the association between sensitive period exposure, brain changes and clinical symptoms in order to identify mediators that can be targeted to prevent the emergence of substance use in high-risk maltreated individuals and to potentially augment the effects of treatment in substance users.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Surveillance Monitoring for ART Toxicities (SMARTT) Study of the Pediatric HIV/AIDS Cohort Study (PHACS) network has been enrolling and following infants and children who are HIV-exposed but uninfected (CHEU) born to women with HIV, with over 4000 CHEU enrolled over the past 14 years. The primary goal of the PHACS SMARTT study is to evaluate the short-term and long-term safety of maternal antiretroviral treatment (ART) during pregnancy on health outcomes in CHEU across a wide range of domains, including growth, neurodevelopment, cardiometabolic, hearing, language, oral, and maternal health. This proposal describes our strategy for continued enrollment and follow-up of CHEU to inform ART guidelines and optimize the efficacy and safety of ART use in pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on gaining a better understanding of the immunology of infection of Clostridioides difficile, a common GI bacterial pathogen that can cause extensive inflammation and tissue damage. Our goal is to harness early innate immunity to improve the patient’s immune response against the bacteria, to resolve infection and/or prevent re-infection. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to preventing and curing human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States is currently experiencing an opioid crisis and nearly 20 million Americans have a substance abuse disorder. Changes to AMPA receptors in the brain or receptor plasticity is a hallmark of addiction linked to the development of additive behavior and withdrawal, but the molecular mechanisms that regulate AMPA receptors during drug addiction are unknown. I will investigate the molecular mechanisms that control AMPA receptor plasticity and identify potential therapeutic targets to support development of more effective treatments for drug addiction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The PHACS (Pediatric HIV/AIDS Cohort Study) Adolescent Master Protocol (AMP) Up Series (AMP Up Series) of studies – AMP Up and AMP Up Lite – are following a cohort of young adults with perinatal HIV (YAPHIV) and a comparison group of young adults with perinatal HIV exposure who are uninfected, a substantial proportion of whom have longitudinal data since early childhood on HIV status, antiretroviral medications, and clinical outcomes. Their primary goal is to evaluate the impact of HIV disease and its treatment on health and behavior outcomes across a wide range of domains, including cardiopulmonary, metabolic, mental health, neurological, neurocognitive, oral, reproductive, substance use and sexual behaviors, emotional, social and academic functioning, and health care utilization and access. This proposal describes our strategy for continued follow-up of these young adults to inform research and interventions for YAPHIV worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative It is unclear if young adults perinatally HIV infected (YAPHIV) are protected against human papilloma virus (HPV) associated cancers by the HPV vaccine. We have the opportunity to examine the natural history of HPV in HPV-vaccinated YAPHIV. The results of this study would inform clinical and policy guidelines for HPV vaccination strategies and cervical cancer screening in resourced and resource poor settings.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children and youth with perinatal exposure to HIV and antiretroviral medications (ARV) are at increased risk for cognitive, mental health and behavioral challenges, yet the underlying mechanisms of such risks are not well understood. The proposed research will leverage the Pediatric HIV/AIDS Cohort Study and large NIH-supported studies of normative development to identify the effects of perinatal HIV and ARV exposure on brain networks involved in cognitive and behavioral outcomes, such as emotional regulation and risk behaviors, using longitudinal structural and functioning neuroimaging along with cognitive and mental health measures. In light of the significant public health implications of the effects of HIV/ARV exposures throughout adolescence and young adulthood, this project will identify mechanisms driving cognitive, mental health and behavioral outcomes and will inform prevention and intervention strategies to support young people affected globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Current approaches to guiding percutaneous liver ablation have significant limitations yielding poor tumor control rates. This multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional Academic Industrial Partnership will develop and validate a simultaneous US and MR solution in combination with advanced MR methods for real-time guidance, treatment monitoring and margin assessment during liver ablations with the ultimate goal of improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury afflicts approximately three million Americans every year with a high rate of long-term cognitive and psychiatric morbidity. Chronic neuroinflammation resulting from the constitutive activation of microglia is complicit in this process and represents a complex interplay between the injured brain, microglia, and the gut microbiome via the gut-brain axis. However, the mechanism(s) underlying gut microbiota-microglia interaction have yet to be elucidated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO RIO PIEDRAS
PHR: Narrative The NeuroGRAD program will be the first Neuroscience graduate training program of its kind at the University of Puerto Rico, a premier research-intensive Hispanic Serving Institution in the USA. The main goal of NeuroGRAD program is to successfully impact, educate, train, and develop the new generation of promising underrepresented minority (URM) neuroscience graduate students using evidence-based successful strategies founded on three key strands: (1) the development of impactful neuroscience training blueprint based on cutting- edge and hands-on research experiences (2) the establishment of an effective multilayered mentoring network through strong partnerships with top-notch neuroscience researchers in Research 1(R1) institutions in the mainland and (3) the design of a series of transformative skill set activities that will yield a new cohort of URM neuroscientists role models and leaders in the 21st Century Neuroscience workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: CAR based immunotherapies are now credentialed as potent tools against hematologic malignancies and early signals suggest that these therapeutics may prove beneficial against brain tumors. Building upon impressive results in preclinical models, this project will undertake a Phase I trial of GD2-CAR T cells in H3K27M diffuse midline gliomas, universally lethal tumors of childhood and young adults. The project seeks to ensure the safety of this therapy for patients with brainstem gliomas where the risk of toxicity due to tumor edema is high, will use novel approaches to measure clinical efficacy and seek to define biomarkers or response, and will undertake studies focused on interrogating the biology of myeloid cell activation following CNS directed CAR T cell therapies that has been observed both in preclinical and clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is a systems biology approach to characterize the genetic and regulatory underpinnings of antibiotic persistence in the bacterium E. coli. The proposed studies will provide critical insights into how small sub-population of bacteria become tolerant to otherwise lethal levels of antibiotics. This phenomenon is highly relevant to emerging health crisis of antibiotic tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced B55 α expression frequently occur in ovarian cancers. The goal of this application is to explore new approaches to treat B55 α-defective ovarian cancers by studying a new synthetic lethal interaction between B55 α deficiency and cell cycle checkpoint kinases inhibition. If successful, our study will have a significant impact on improving the survival of ovarian cancer patients by identifying new approaches for treating B55 α defective ovarian cancer and by providing a new stratification biomarker for identifying ATR/CHK1 inhibitor sensitive populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Our long-term goal is to identify strategies that can acutely enhance the astrocytic scar, thereby reducing cell death and inflammation at the injury site, and promoting functional recovery in the newly spinally-injured aging population. The overall objective of this project is to demonstrate that enhancing mitochondrial functions in astrocytes early after SCI will enhance astroglial scar formation, and functional recovery after SCI in aged animals. Our central hypothesis is that the age-dependent decline in astrocytic mitochondrial functions impairs astroglial scar formation and reduces functional recovery after SCI with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing quest to understand the dynamics of intracellular and inter-cellular metabolism in the tumor microenvironment demands improved and expanded analytical techniques from specialized cores. I propose to build on the unique suite of services I have developed as Director of the Cancer Metabolism Core in the Cancer Center at Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute (SBP). Funding from an R50 award will support my goal to build a comprehensive, state-of-the-art, innovative and collaborative Cancer Metabolism Core at SBP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) is a serious and potentially fatal complication of rheumatic disease or viral infection. MAS is characterized by the development of cytopenias and the accumulation of hemophagocytes— activated macrophages that phagocytose red blood cells. The goal of this project is to define the mechanisms that drive the development of hemophagocytes and disease in MAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol’s ability to enhance the activity of -aminobutyric acid (GABA) at GABAA receptors has been implicated as a key mechanism underlying the abuse-related effects of alcohol in humans, making this system an attractive candidate for the development of therapeutics. The complex molecular biology of GABAA receptors raises the possibility that subtype-selective drugs can be developed with therapeutic specificity against alcohol use disorders. Our studies will yield needed information about neuropharmacological mechanisms underlying the addictive effects of alcohol and begin to identify clinical scenarios in which specific pharmacological approaches might be expected to produce improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell replacement therapy is a potential cure for T1D but must overcome major challenges of islet supply and immune protection. We developed a novel technology to direct cultured human stomach progenitors derived from biopsies to generate abundant insulin-secreting Beta-like cells capable of long-term glycemic control. We propose to significantly improve the progenitor lines and derivation protocol to enable consistent production of functional and immune-evasive autologous grafts for a cell replacement approach without immune suppression or encapsulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Glioblastomas are the most common malignant primary brain tumor, afflicting approximately 13,000 adults in the United States every year. The most effective treatments are radiation and a chemotherapy called temozolomide or lomustine but quickly become resistant and are fatal as a result. This proposal aims to determine how glioblastomas become resistant to radiation and temozolomide by determining the genetic changes they undergo during treatment, thereby enabling us to devise more effective treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE The proposed research seeks to identify environmental risk factors for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) using the ALS population in Massachusetts, the only state in the United States with a reportable ALS registry. Our hypothesis is that the presence, concentration, combination and/or spatial distribution of persistent and toxic elements (e.g. trace elements and nanoparticles) is associated with ALS risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE To study biological systems in their critical in vivo context and develop effective cell-based therapies, we need new methods to manipulate the function of cells deep inside living animals. In this project we will develop a technology that enables cellular remote control with ultrasound – a form of energy that can be targeted non- invasively to deep tissues with sub-millimeter spatial precision. This technology will use genetically encoded “acoustic antennae” to convert ultrasound into local mechanical force and apply it to engineered mechanosensitive receptors, triggering desired cellular pathways for remote-control of neural activity and immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative—Health Relevance This project will identify pharmacological interventions that improve the length of life and/or the quality of aging in a simple animal model that shares many hallmark features of aging in humans. Data obtained at three assay sites by rigorously testing a genetically diverse test set is anticipated to identify chemical treatments with high potential to be efficacious in a diverse human population. Our study may lead to treatments that protect against physical deterioration, cognitive decline, and disease susceptibility in the elderly human population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Deaths of older adults with Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's Disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD) are common and fast growing, while end-of-life care for AD/ADRD patients is often overly aggressive and costly. Advance care planning (ACP), the discussion of patient preferences and goals of care in the event of patient losing decision-making capacity, holds promise in curbing overly aggressive EOL care for AD/ADRD patients. This project aims to evaluate the effect of two recent Medicare reimbursement policy changes that promote ACP practice, providing rigorous and critical evidence for improving EOL care among AD/ADRD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high clinical significance of alcoholic hepatitis (AH), targeting hepatic injury alone has been of limited therapeutic benefit. Loss of muscle mass or sarcopenia is frequent and adversely affects clinical outcomes in AH. We propose to use a specific molecular weight hyaluronan, HA35, to restore skeletal muscle protein homeostasis and improve outcomes in AH. We will ascertain whether HA35 protects against ethanol-induced tissue injury in healthy subjects and patients with moderate AH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Prion disease is a fatal and untreatable neurodegenerative disease caused by misfolding of a single protein in the brain — prion protein or PrP. Here we apply divalent short interfering RNA (di-siRNA) technology to lower the amount of PrP in the brain, with the goal of advancing a safe and effective therapy for prion disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Despite advances in operative technology, intraoperative methods have not improved cancer detection during surgery in the past 30 years. In response to the recent Moonshot Initiative PAR-20-250 that solicits “concepts that propose a path to clinical validation … for probes with previously demonstrated capabilities for the detection of small tumors”, we propose to test the combination of high- resolution/depth-limited imaging properties of optical imaging agents with the low-resolution/tissue penetrating properties of nuclear agents for detection of primary tumors and regional lymph nodes. We propose that combined optical and nuclear imaging can detect tumor fragments less than 1 mm3 in vivo during removal of head and neck cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study tests the effectiveness of a community-based peer advocacy, mutual learning, and social support intervention (Refugee and Immigrant Well-being Project) to reduce several negative consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic that are disproportionately impacting Latinx and Black populations: psychological distress, financial problems, and daily stressors. In partnership with five community-based organizations that focus on mental health, legal, education, and youth issues with Latinx immigrants and African refugees, we will also be able to examine the effects of people’s involvement with community-based organizations and local and state policy changes on their mental health, economic stability, stressors, and social support. This is important not only for Latinx and Black populations and the large number of immigrants and refugees in the United States and worldwide, but also because the intervention model and what we learn from this study have the potential to alleviate mental health disparities experienced by other marginalized populations who face unequal access to social and material resources, disproportionate exposure to trauma and stress, and worse consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this study is to test whether a promising new therapy, inorganic nitrate, can improve exercise capacity — both muscle power and aerobic performance — in patients debilitated by heart failure. We will develop all the infrastructure necessary for a randomized clinical trial (RCT) of inorganic nitrate, including the necessary drug testing and human studies protections, and then we will perform a RCT of inorganic nitrate’s effects on exercise capacity. If inorganic nitrate is found safe and effective for improving aerobic exercise capacity, muscle power, and speed of muscle contraction, it could offer a new therapy for millions of people suffering from heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project tests whether inhibition of metabolism of the amino acid glutamine will improve the response of cervical cancer to radiation therapy. State of the art cell culture systems, mouse tumor models and a new clinical trial for patients with cervical cancer will be used to evaluate this new treatment approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) is the most common cause of cancer mortality worldwide and is difficult to target therapeutically due to substantial heterogeneity and lineage plasticity that arises during progression and therapeutic response. However, the mechanisms controlling differentiation state and plasticity in LUAD are not well understood, and there is an urgent unmet need to identity drivers of LUAD plasticity both during progression and therapeutic response. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which key lineage specifying transcription factors and oncogenic signaling pathways concomitantly influence LUAD growth and differentiation state, and the results that derive from this study may help to inform development of lineage-targeted therapies for LUAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-typhoidal Salmonella infects the gastrointestinal tract and is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. We aim to understand how Salmonella thrives in the inflamed gut, and how beneficial microbes can outcompete Salmonella in this hostile environment. Our long-term goal is to develop new strategies to limit Salmonella infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE- Acetyl CoA Carboxylase in the Metabolic Control of Inflammation Metabolic dysregulation in immune cells results in either compromised or overshooting innate immune responses, resulting in devastating outcomes in resolution of infections. Acetyl CoA Carboxylase (ACC) is a key enzyme directly regulating de novo lipogenesis as well as indirectly affecting transcriptional capacity by regulating acetyl-CoA levels and histone acetylation. Here, we test the overall hypothesis that ACC activity is essential for the immune cell-intrinsic metabolic and transcriptional adaptations required for the induction and resolution of the acute inflammatory response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Biomolecular condensates play important roles in the organization and function of human cells, and are defective in diseases including neurodegeneration (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, frontotemporal dementia), many cancers (e.g. Ewing sarcoma) and several skin barrier diseases. This proposal will address key problems in the field whose solutions could lead to new therapeutic approaches based on targeting biomolecular condensates. These include the sequence determinants of phase separation of intrinsically disordered proteins, the compositional and functional complexity of native condensates, and the contribution of phase separation to organization and functions of chromatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: In this proposal we will develop and optimize a targeted mass spec-based assay for glycopeptide markers discovered in our previous work for the early detection of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). These glycopeptide markers are orthogonal to ELISA based AFP detection so that they will contribute to an overall increase in the AUC and sensitivity for detection of early HCC. We will perform an analysis of a large confirmation set to determine the optimal combination of glycopeptide markers and then a phase II blinded validation of these markers for early stage HCC detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy brain activity depends on intercellular signaling between neuronal synapses and extracellular proteins produced from astrocytes. We aim to understand the specific mechanisms underlying this astrocyte-neuron relationship in human cells using bioengineered neural organoids as an experimental testing platform. The results from this study are expected to elucidate the influence of astrocyte-neuron interactions, to deliver validated innovations that will improve organoid-based technologies, and to identify proteins with high potential as therapeutic targets during states of dysregulated brain activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Islet transplantation is a promising therapy to achieve stable blood glucose control for T1D patients. To overcome the shortage of islet supply, we developed a novel technology to direct cultured human stomach stem cells to generate insulin-secreting β-like cells capable of reversing diabetes. We propose to significantly improve this technology by constructing unique cell lines and new tools to produce islet-like organoids with improved functionality and streamlined production suitable for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are the hub of multiple cellular processes including metabolism and immune responses, and are intimately associated with organismal aging. The extracellular matrix is a dynamic organelle that mediates communication between cells and regulate fundamental cellular behaviors. The extracellular matrix also undergoes profound remodeling during aging. We aim to understand how mitochondrial homeostasis is regulated by changes of the extracellular matrix and its impact on aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol use remains a serious problem among college students. Brief motivational interventions reduce college students' alcohol use but effects are not sustained. This research seeks to identify the psychosocial factors that affect college students' maintenance of intervention gains over time and to conduct the formative research needed to develop a maintenance-enhancement alcohol intervention for college students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The traditional paradigm of how neurons work assumes that dendrites receive excitatory and inhibitory synaptic inputs that are integrated in the soma, but dendrites are active nonlinear structures that could mediate, and control, which of the many thousands of inputs are integrated and which are not. We will assemble an interdisciplinary consortium of laboratories and use state-of-the-art experimental and computational methods to examine with unprecedented detail the structure, in vivo function and computational roles of dendrites of a mouse pyramidal neuron subtype in visual cortex. This work will elucidate the principles underlying the function of dendrites in pyramidal neurons and generate a series of complete morphological, connectivity, functional and computational datasets that could be used as “Rosetta Stones” by the field for futures studies of neurons in both normal and pathological states.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Boston University and Lata Medical Research Foundation with the academic consortium of the Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and the Datta Meghe Institute of Medical Sciences in Nagpur, Central India focuses on improving the health of pregnant women, their newborns, and children up to 3 years of age. We are committed to the Global Network's objective to conduct high impact, clinical trials and observational studies of sustainable, cost-effective health interventions and their implementation in women and children in low and middle income countries. Continued participation in the Global Network will also enable us to continue building sustainable research capacity and infrastructure in obstetric, neonatal, and pediatric research in Nagpur, India.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular Vesicles (EVs) are shed by all cells in the body into the blood, and so provide a unique opportunity for monitoring the pancreatic islet microenvironment with liquid biopsies. Here we propose to integrate an innovative tool set of bulk and single EV omics, nanotechnologies, and microtechnologies to extract the blood fingerprints of Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) and to develop EV based biomarkers for the early detection of T1D. The proposed methodology, as well as data set, will be of high value to the fundamental and clinical T1D communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Relevance: The goal of this research is to develop and validate a comprehensive computer-based technology that will help medical trainees to practice their skills for an emerging endoscopy-based weight loss procedure known as endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG). ESG is a nonsurgical, incision-less, organ-sparing procedure that is safe and effective and can be performed in an outpatient facilty by either a gastroenterologist or a bariatric surgeon with rapid return to work. The proposed training technology for ESG will allow clinicians to learn the procedure in a risk-free manner on computers before application to patients, resulting in improved patient outcomes and reduced treatment costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: SOCS1 is a crucial regulator for uveal melanoma response to immunotherapy PROJECT NARRATIVE Downregulation of the suppressor of cytokine signaling 1 (SOCS1) and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules was observed in uveal melanoma (UM) tumors derived from patients who did not respond to checkpoint inhibitors (CPIs), which provided a strong rationale for applying small SOCS1 modulators as potential therapeutics to enhance CPIs activities against metastatic UM. Herein, we proposed a comprehensive study to identify the distinct SOCS1-associated immune signature of UM and develop effectively combinational immune therapies with small SOCS1 modulators to enhance CPI anticancer immunity. Moreover, the research platform developed in this study can be directly applied to develop novel immunotherapies for head and neck cancer, breast cancer, liver cancer, and CM, in which SOCS1 plays a crucial role in the tumor progression and patient's overall survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on antibiotic use for treatment of diarrheal disease among children and the relationship to the development of antibacterial resistance in rural China. With data from an audit study in clinics and pharmacies and a micro-level survey of households in southwest China, I will explore the drivers of antibiotic use, both on the supply side with clinicians and pharmacists and the demand side among parents and caregivers, using machine learning-based quasi-experimental statistical analysis and agent-based modeling to identify various drivers of antibiotic demand, to simulate the effects of alternative policies on antibiotic use and antibiotic resistance, and to identify promising policies and interventions for future study. The outcomes of this research will contribute to knowledge of the behavioral drivers of population-level antibiotic use and resistance and support the development of policies and interventions suited to low and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early childhood depression symptoms are a significant public health concern as they are associated with functional impairments and heightened risk for depression across the lifespan. This project will comprehensively examine sleep in an ascertained sample of 3-year-olds oversampled for familial risk for depression, examining whether objectively measured sleep/circadian rhythms are markers of early childhood depression and whether sleep disturbances in infancy/toddlerhood are developmental precursors of early childhood depression at age 3. This project represents an unexplored, but vitally important area of research that may have substantial impact on our understanding of risk for early childhood depression, as well as our ability to identify children who may be suffering from early childhood depressive symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol- (ALD) and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) constitute the majority of liver-related morbidity and mortality. Based on national trends of increasing obesity and harmful alcohol use, the health burden of NAFLD and ALD is projected to rise, particularly among women, young adults, and under-represented minorities. This proposal directly addresses these overlapping epidemics through the lens of liver fibrosis (the most significant predictor of patient outcomes in ALD and NAFLD) by examining: (i) the longitudinal interactions of alcohol and metabolic risks on liver fibrosis, aiming to provide more individualized prognostic information; (ii) proprotein convertase subtilisin kexin type 9 (PCSK9), a novel biomarker and potential therapeutic target in ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: The proposed research focuses on prevention of dental caries through targeted treatment of acid- producing bacteria (t-TAB). Its goal will be achieved by formulating and developing a series of pH-sensitive quaternary pyridinium salts and transforming the traditional, non-pH-sensitive chlorhexidine into antimicrobial materials with t-TAB capability. The successful candidates capable of preventing acid-induced tooth damage through achieving a healthy microbial community and maintaining environmental pH above 5.5 will be identified using a multispecies biofilm model that simulates human oral microbial community and further assessed for caries prevention in vitro using a microbial-caries model on human enamel and in vivo through a well-developed mouse caries model .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to define the relationship of Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor initiation to adverse changes in cardiac remodeling that are linked to atrial fibrillation. These studies are also relevant to public health because they may lead to a more clear understanding of how cardiovascular disease develops following initiation of this increasingly ubiquitous class of drug, while critically informing clinicians and cancer patients on the safety of an innovative strategy for the prevention of potentially devastating cardiotoxic events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a debilitating medical condition characterized by the inability of the heart to supply blood to the body and critical organs. The number of people developing heart failure continues to increase worldwide and, despite intense efforts to improve the treatment of heart failure, death rates remain high. Although multiple complex causes lead to heart failure, oxidative stress is a common feature and by leveraging the strength of a newly characterized animal model that allows on demand generation of oxidative stress in the heart, I aim to define how oxidative stress leads to heart failure with the long-term goal to find novel therapies for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cancer Biology, Informatics & Omics (CBIO) training program prepares the next-generation of scientists with the knowledge, skills and proficiency in designing and executing research that incorporates the collection, analysis and interpretation of large-scale omics data to investigate the complex biology of cancer and to drive further advancement in precision cancer medicine. CBIO has leveraged the outstanding research, teaching and technology-innovation environment at the University of California, San Diego Health Sciences (UCSDHS) to establish a program that adds value to trainee education, career development, faculty interactivity and computational biology research in the UCSDHS community. By building on its successes and with regular, formalized, program evaluations by External and Internal Advisory Committees, trainees and faculty, CBIO will continue to develop and streamline training activities to fulfill its mission as a catalyst of research education at the forefront of informatics- and omics-driven cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative During adolescence the brain undergoes a profound reorganization, including the formation and stabilization of neural circuits that are critically involved in decision-making. Here, we use sophisticated in vivo methods to interrogate the functional developmental changes longitudinally across adolescence within a midbrain/amygdala- cortical neural network that mediates reinforcement-learning computations to guide value-based choice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: A decline in the pacemaker activity of the sinoatrial node of the heart is an inherent property of cardiovascular aging which is associated with cardiovascular morbidity, cognitive dysfunction, decreased functional independence, and reduced health span. Proposed studies will define the biophysical and molecular mechanisms in cardiac pacemaker cells that cause the heart to slow with age. Understanding these mechanisms is essential for the development of improved therapies to treat age-related bradycardia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart disease affecting 1 in 3600 births that is typically repaired with surgery early in life. Although advances in care have greatly improved patient survival, there is limited understanding of which patients will experience adverse events related to right ventricular remodeling, resulting in reduced quality of life, increased healthcare burden, and increased mortality. The proposed research introduces a multi-faceted approach using machine learning and computational fluid dynamics to identify the structural and hemodynamic parameters of tetralogy of Fallot that are associated with right ventricular remodeling.

PHR: Project Narrative: Malic enzyme 2 is frequently deleted in pancreatic cancer and its deletion correlates with poor patient prognosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The glioma microenvironment is very complex and heterogeneous, a feature that impedes both the understanding of their biology as well as the elaboration of efficient clinical interventions. The focus of our proposal is to mechanistically understand the nature of the communications that take place in the tumor microenvironment, especially between immune suppressive cells and tumor cells that resist therapy but also to test the therapeutic effect of disrupting these interactions to treat brain tumors. The long-term goal of this project is to translate the information gained into strategies useful as clinical therapies improving disease outcome.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Dysregulation of post-transcriptional regulation is very frequent in human cancers and other diseases, and usually it affects specific subsets of cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Heme enzymes catalyze a broad range of biological transformations important for immune system regulation, antibiotic production, and hormone biosynthesis. Elucidating their mechanistic behavior is therefore critical to understanding these pathways and developing new methods to combat disease. This proposal attempts to determine the structural basis for, and dynamics associated with, unusual heme-dependent enzyme reactions important for the development of new pharmaceuticals and anticancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Failed cytokinesis can promote tumor development and cause birth defects, and defects in vesicle trafficking contribute to diabetes and neurologic diseases. In addition, our studies on fungal-specific proteins such as glucan synthases and their regulators may reveal ideal targets for new antifungal drugs. Thus, understanding the crucial events and essential proteins that control successful completion of cytokinesis will help us discover the causes and possible treatments of cancer and other human health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cells are the dynamic unit of life, interacting with their local and systemic environments and other cells. This proposal aims to develop a method combining optical and DNA barcodes, that enables the large-scale acquisition of dynamic single-cell information including cells’ spatiotemporal, morphological, and physiological changes, cell-cell interactions, and responses to the environment along with their single-cell omics data. Completing this proposal will offer new avenues to analyze single cells comprehensively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic itch represents a significant health and socioeconomic burden, affecting a large proportion of the US and world population. The present proposal will use preclinical mouse models to investigate the mechanisms that underlie the descending modulation of itch from the brainstem, as well as ascending transmission of itch signals from the spinal cord to higher centers, with an emphasis on neurons that express the receptor for substance P (NK-1 receptor). A better understanding of descending modulation and ascending transmission of itch has translational significance for the mechanisms-based development of more effective treatments for chronic itch, particularly those targeting the NK-1 receptor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patient-derived tumor organoids (PDO), involving the ex vivo culture of fresh tumor fragments, have emerged as promising models for predicting patient drug response for personalized cancer therapy. Our work on a novel micro-dissection device to mechanically dissect fresh tumor specimen into uniform live micro-fragments for PDOs will reduce pre-analytical variations in PDO cultures, and increase the yield and quality of PDOs for downstream analyses, drug screens and biobanking. Upon validation, our work can lead to the standardization of the mechanical dissection process and micro-fragment size for PDOs, a critical step for broadening the clinical adoption of PDO technology for personalized cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Aga Khan University/Columbia University Global Network site has played an important role in each of the Global Network studies and is responsible for both the conceptualization and leadership of several important research projects. In recent years, the Global Network has evaluated the value of ultrasound examinations during prenatal care, aspirin use to reduce preterm birth, a multi-micronutrient supplement to reduce childhood stunting, antibiotics during labor to reduce perinatal infections and the impact of COVID – 19 infections on pregnancy outcomes, all in the low and middle-income countries. The goal of future studies will be to continue to provide insight into the causes of adverse outcomes for women and children in low and middle-income countries, to evaluate medical and public health interventions designed to improve those outcomes and make data available so that the medical and public health systems in low and low-middle income countries can utilize the best evidence based interventions to improve the health of women and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We propose to study episodic memory processing in parietal—hippocampal circuits in human intracranial EEG patients. We will use three innovative experimental approaches, including microelectrode recordings, cholinergic modulation, and direct brain stimulation, to address key knowledge gaps regarding the neurophysiological underpinnings of episodic processing in these circuits. Our approach builds directly on published and preliminary data collected in human subjects over the previous funded period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current diabetes treatments are woefully inadequate, and diabetes remains a leading cause of disability and death among Americans. Our program will meet a growing need within our region and the country for a cohort of capable diabetes investigators, by training new scientists in cutting edge research aimed at better treating and preventing diabetes. The trainees in this program will be scientists who are not yet independent but have earned their PhD and/or MD and intend to head their own diabetes research laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE To address the public health burden of alcohol use disorder (AUD), there is a tremendous need for continuing care options to support long-term recovery from AUD that (1) support whole-person recovery, defined as focusing on both functioning and reductions in drinking or abstinence, (2) are effective in targeting the neuroadaptations observed among those with addiction, and (3) are accessible in all communities nationwide, including medically underserved and health professional shortage areas. This project will evaluate the effectiveness and mechanisms of mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) delivered via video conferencing, as compared to referral to online mutual support groups, in supporting long-term whole-person recovery and improvements in neurobiologically-informed domains of addiction among individuals with AUD who have recently made a change attempt to reduce or stop drinking. The project will also examine the reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance of MBRP as an accessible and freely available continuing care option that supports long-term recovery from AUD in all communities nationwide, including medically underserved and health professional shortage areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in the fields of neuroscience, genetics, and other biological fields are leading to profound transformations in our understanding of mental health. In order to translate this understanding into new and optimized treatment approaches, research training should encompass a solid foundation in translational science. Consistent with the Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) initiative and emerging work on the use of biomarkers to guide prediction of disease development and treatment response, our Translational Research Activities In Neuropsychiatry (TRAIN) program is designed to train the next generation of physician-scientists in psychiatry so that they can translate neuroscience and genetics research into better outcomes for individuals with mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative PPM1D is recurrently mutated in clonal hematopoiesis and myeloid malignancies, resulting in elevated protein expression and chemotherapy resistance. This project seeks to define the role that PPM1D and PPM1D mutations play in hematopoiesis during steady state and under conditions of stress and to define the molecular mechanisms by which PPM1D is regulated by the proteasome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary goals of this K24 renewal application are to enable Marisa M. Silveri, Ph.D., to continue to 1) provide substantive mentoring of junior investigators and trainees in POR (35%), with a focus on mentoring underrepresented minority trainees; 2) continue and extend involvement in my POR (10%), and 3) advance my expertise in the content areas of adolescent comorbid psychopathology, clinical approaches in adolescent treatment settings, and vulnerable populations, including gender and racial/ethnically diverse youth, for which there are significant mental health disparities (5%). The public health importance of this renewal application addresses the need to characterize neurobiological markers in addiction and psychiatric disorders, which will inform development of new and effective treatments for alcohol use disorder and for patients with dual diagnoses, and the need to train the next generation of investigators to develop the skills they require to effectively conduct research with patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder, a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, is associated with gut dysbiosis, intestinal permeability and increased endotoxin into circulation, which induces inflammatory responses that drive organ injury, but the target and driver of ethanol-induced inflammation is uncertain. We recently showed the gut fermentation byproduct butyrate is protective against ethanol-induced gut permeability and associated liver inflammation and injury, and that this protection was linked with preserved markers for intestinal endothelium and reduced oxidative stress in mice. Here we will determine the mechanisms for protective effects of immune nutrients, butyrate and all trans retinoic acid, in intestinal microvascular endothelium and T-lymphocytes, with the long-term goal of this project aimed at identifying therapeutic agents that will protect against ethanol-induced injury to intestine and subsequently other organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Public Health Relevance (Narrative Statement) Ryanodine receptors (RyR2) mediate the release of Ca2+ for cardiac contraction and its dysfunctions underlie many cardiac pathologies, including heart failure and arrhythmia. Mechanistic data on the pathologies of RyR2 have come from transgenic mouse or heterologous cell models, with low relevance to human heart. Here we propose to develop powerful molecular and imaging tools to investigate the RyR2 disease-associated mutations in human stem cell derived cardiomyocytes, and believe that our unique multi-disciplinary approach will enhance the understanding of molecular regulatory sites of this protein and its pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our objective is to determine if video-conferencing with pediatric experts using mobile devices (teleconsultation) can improve emergency care for sick and injured children in ambulances. With emergency service personnel, we will: (1) optimize a video-conferencing platform for efficient and easy use outside the hospital; (2) determine whether they would and could use this technology, and if it makes care safer using infant patient simulators; and (3) determine if pediatric expert physicians in hospitals can use this technology to assess children in ambulances before they arrive at the hospital. This work has the potential to improve access to high quality emergency care for children, especially in rural and underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signaling pathways driven by the signaling lipid phosphoinositides (PIs) are frequently altered in many human diseases while the contributions of nuclear PIs found in the non-membranous subnuclear compartments to human health remain still largely elusive since the initial discoveries in the 1950s. With innovative research tools and genome-wide studies, we will elucidate the nature and functions of nuclear PIs in the regulation of key nuclear processes such as transcription control and epigenetics within diverse cellular contexts. The completion of the proposed research programs will provide fundamental knowledge for understanding the importance of nuclear PIs in human pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telomere maintenance by telomerase is a critical pathway for tissue homeostasis in the human body and as a consequence, deficiencies in telomerase lead to premature aging diseases and inappropriate activation of telomerase is a hallmark of 90% of human cancers. Telomerase is a multi-component ribonucleoprotein and its assembly is deficient in premature aging disorders and could be targeted to inhibit telomerase activity in cancer cells. The goal of this study is to determine the molecular mechanism underlying the role of TCAB1, an RNA- binding protein essential for telomere maintenance, in telomerase assembly to develop new approaches to target telomerase function for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and other gender minority emerging adults are at greater risk for substance use and adverse mental health outcomes than their non-transgender peers, driven in part by social stressors (e.g., stigma) and sociocultural appearance pressures. Online, interactive media (e.g., social media) may be a significant source of social stressors and harmful appearance pressures, while also offering unprecedented access to support for gender minority emerging adults and novel opportunities for interventions to reduce body dissatisfaction and substance use. This research will increase knowledge about (a) the influence of social media environments on body dissatisfaction and other substance use risk factors and (b) the feasibility and acceptability of an innovative intervention to increase critical social media literacy and reduce substance use risk factors with the goal of improving the health and wellbeing of gender minority young people and advancing health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to investigate the importance and origin of a fascinating modification that we recently discovered to the HIV structural proteins, namely the formation of dehydroamino acids. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS and infects over 1 million people each year. We will examine the role of these modifications in the HIV life cycle and evaluate their purpose. Further, we will test the hypothesis that they are formed enzymatically, and if so, discover the enzyme responsible. This may provide an exciting new pathway for the development of antiretroviral therapeutics. In 2020, over 37 million people, including 1.7 million children, were living with the virus, and over 500,000 died from AIDS. For a robust eradication of the virus, additional research such as the work proposed here is desperately needed to eliminate knowledge gaps in our understanding of viral infection and replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Difficulties in how people respond to negative and positive outcomes (called `valuation') in our environment can be related to debilitating depression and anxiety. Here we use novel neuroscience and computational methods to study how links among depressed mood, anhedonia, anxiety, and different types of valuation vary over time and can be changed. This work may lead to new ways to understand the role of valuation in mental health and neuroscience-guided behavioral approaches for treating symptoms regardless of mental health diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we propose to study the involvement of PCSK9, a critical protein that regulates the body’s cholesterol levels, for its involvement in modulating the anti-tumor immune response after radiotherapy. In particular, we will study the interaction between PCSK9 and the cGAS-STING pathway during radiotherapy and immune checkpoint blockade therapy of local and distant tumors. Because PCSK9 inhibitors are already available clinically for the treatment of hyperlipidemia, our study may lead to future clinical trials evaluating PCSK9 inhibitors for their ability to improve radiotherapy and immunotherapy of locoregional and distant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the ability to vicariously experience the other's aversive feelings in a situation, a process called observational fear (OF), is critical to live in society and the malfunctions of OF represent well-described findings in individuals with autism spectrum disorders, it remains unknown about the neural mechanisms of how both prior similar own fear experience and social familiarity with demonstrator facilitate OF (experience- dependent OF). Our proposed studies will elucidate the neural circuit mechanisms of the experience- dependent OF by examining hippocampal-amygdala neural circuits. Our proposed study will uncover the neural substrates for the fear memory ensemble-dependent perception-action mechanisms as a principle of Exp OF, which may be potentially generalized for other types of empathic ability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity and related health problems are an accelerating national health problem. We recently discovered a new circulating hormone, asprosin, that precisely controls appetite levels, and antibodies that neutralize it improve obesity in mice. The proposal represents an effort to validate the CNS receptor for asprosin that was recently discovered by our laboratory, and its potential targeting for treatment of obesity and the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Whereas advances in cancer treatment have dramatically improved the survival of cancer patients, some cancer patients suffer from serious side effects of cancer treatments, a typical example of which is the heart-muscle damage caused by anthracyclines, one of the most common chemotherapy drugs used for leukemia, breast cancer, and childhood cancer. Currently, it is challenging to predict who will develop heart problems before using anti-cancer drugs and prevent their side effects on the heart. To address these problems, this project aims to generate a “risk scoring system” to evaluate the risk of chemotherapy-induced heart damage from patients’ genetic information and identify already-existing drugs that could prevent the heart damage using human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) and cutting-edge CRISPR technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Mohs micrographic surgery is a highly effective procedure to selectively remove skin tumors; however, it is used in only a fraction of skin tumor surgeries because it requires substantial infrastructure and personnel training. This proposal seeks to develop lower infrastructure methods to assess surgical success during skin tumor surgery with the long term vision to expand surgical guidance where it is indicated but not currently being used.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Diabetes and its complications are a critical and growing public health problem in the United States and abroad. Given the complexity of this disease and associated syndromes, it is essential to recruit dedicated and talented researchers into the diabetes and metabolism field, and train them in interdisciplinary approaches. The Joslin Diabetes Center T32 Training Program in Diabetes and Metabolism aims to attract outstanding young scientists and physician/scientists into diabetes and metabolism research, and train them in a rich, vibrant, inclusive, diverse, and collaborative environment in which they are exposed to the many facets of diabetes, its underlying causes, and its complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE. Tobacco use is the leading cause of preventable death in the United States. This application will determine for the first time how visinin-like protein-1 (an endogenous protein found in the brain) modulates the function and expression of the most abundant neuronally-expressed nicotinic receptor subtype, which is well known to play a pivotal role in nicotine use disorder. By addressing critical gaps in our knowledge, this research will 1) advance the scientific understanding of intrinsic control mechanisms regulating nicotinic receptor function and expression, and 2) may provide an essential foundation for the development of new therapies to promote nicotine use cessation.
