IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Despite the effectiveness of antiretroviral medications for HIV suppression, people with HIV who also have mental health and or substance use disorders suffer disparities in rates of HIV suppression and retention in HIV care and thus have potential to sustain the HIV epidemic. We propose to evaluate effectiveness while also gathering implementation data on an innovative adaptation of collaborative care, using trained peer-specialists as care managers in a team based approach to increasing engagement in mental health and substance use disorder care in HIV continuity care settings; which will then lead to increases in HIV viral suppression and care retention. This proposal has potential to advance the implementation science of mental health and substance use disorder care integration into HIV care settings thus advancing progress towards ending the HIV epidemic

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic valve stenosis, a progressive disorder associated with calcification that worsens with aging, is the major cause of valve disease in the Western world, and the third leading cause of adult heart disease. Although there are no current medical therapies, we have discovered a small molecule drug that corrects dysregulated genes in patient valve cells and effectively treats aortic valve disease in mice. In this proposal, we will definitively determine the target of this drug, its optimal dose and route of administration, and associated pharmacologic properties and toxicity in order to advance for clinical development in patients with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Statement Personalized medicine requires technologies for measuring many disease biomarkers simultaneously for use in diagnostic tests; one widely used technology for clinical single-cell assays is flow cytometry, which is undergoing a transformation to greater multiplexing using a dramatically different technological approach called “spectral flow cytometry.” We have previously developed ultrabright high-multiplexing fluorescent probes called Pdots and have commercialized these Pdots for flow cytometry. Here we propose to expand our multi-color panel of Pdots to 75 for use in high multiplex spectral flow cytometry; this multi-color panel will also be useful in high multiplex tissue imaging (e.g., histopathology).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Devastating mental health disorders, including schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, remain mysterious as to their underlying biological causes and potential treatments. This project aims to develop new tools based on cell types, connectivity, and manipulations of neural activity to study the structure and function of neural circuits during cognitive processing. We aim to expand an emerging field of mechanistic cognitive neuroscience to understand mental health, its disorders, and possible avenues for therapy from the basic building blocks of biological processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CaMKII is an extremely abundant neuronal protein and a central mediator of the strengthening and weakening of neuronal synapses, termed bidirectional synaptic plasticity. This proposal will determine how the unique three- dimensional structure of CaMKII enables its dual role in these two opposing plasticity modes. The results from these experiments will provide critical insight into the normal role of CaMKII in synaptic plasticity and will in turn inform studies of CaMKII dysregulation in models of neurodegenerative, neurological, and neuropsychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There is a critical need for clinician-scientists possessing the medical training and research experience to conduct basic, clinical and translational research on the mechanisms and treatment of neurological disorders. This Neuroscience Research Education Program at Northwestern (R25) is designed to foster the development of clinician neuroscientists in the Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics (Neurology Division) at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine via research and educational experiences that will prepare these trainees for independent successful research careers that ultimately will lead to the development of new treatments for neurological disorders.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE  The CTSA Postdoctoral T32 Program at The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio will operate in collaboration with the Institute for Integration of Medicine and Science (IIMS), home for our CTSA. In this innovative 2-year program Trainees will exchange ideas and strategies in a CTS Roundtable with predoctoral, postdoctoral trainees and junior faculty members for successful team science and earn a graduate- level Translational Science Certificate. This next generation of translational scientists will be primed to speed up discovery and implementation for patients and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease is a common medical problem that can lead to kidney failure, cardiovascular disease, and premature death. The Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) Study is a long-term observational study of more than 5,600 people with chronic kidney disease that aims to identify contributors to adverse outcomes and targets for interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Proposed studies will identify the mechanisms by which IRF7 mediates aberrant regulation of antibody-forming cell (AFC) and germinal center (GC) responses, driving the development of autoreactive B cells, autoantibodies and autoimmune disease SLE. We will learn how interplay between B cell metabolism and IRF7 signaling in B cells regulates the magnitude of SLE-associated AFC and GC responses. We will further learn whether IRF7 can be targeted and whether it would be a better option for SLE than T1-IFN blocking therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) Study is an NIDDK-sponsored multicenter prospective cohort study investigating novel risk factors for the progression of chronic kidney disease and cardiovascular disease among patients with chronic kidney disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human noroviruses are a leading cause of acute gastroenteritis. The proposed studies aim to improve our understanding of how these pathogens infect and replicate in intestinal cells, how virus proteins interact with the human host and how they cause disease symptoms. We will also understand how antibody responses protect from norovirus infections and develop drugs that can be used in the treatment of these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Arrhythmias are a major cause of US mortality with ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation resulting in 430,000 annual deaths. Although catheter ablation is a proven treatment option, as reinforced by the HRS/EHRA/ECAS/APHRS/SOLAECE Expert Consensus Statement, control of ablation catheters can be complex, resulting in imprecise and unreliable heart-wall contact leading to an increased likelihood of injury and arrhythmia recurrence. UNandUP (short for “Unmet Needs and Underserved Populations”) is developing an affordable angiosuite compatible platform which uses low magnetic fields to overcome prior limitations related to electrophysiology catheter navigational accuracy, stability, and applied forces.

PHR: Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it may enhance the therapeutic potential of chondrocytes for repairing early stage cartilage injuries and preventing degeneration of the joint, which is an unmet clinical need. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome are key modulators of human health and disease. To date, we have a limited understanding of the specific gut microbes and microbial derived metabolites contributing to the development of type 2 diabetes. In this Early Stage Investigator NIH R01 application, we propose the largest prospective microbiome study on type 2 diabetes. These studies will reveal the specific gut microbes and microbial derived metabolites and their role in the development of type 2 diabetes in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: New therapies are urgently needed to treat patients diagnosed with glioblastoma as current standard of care is rarely curative and often associated with side effects. This research project started by studying the antitumor activity of carbazole-based molecules and led to the development of a series of microtubule targeting agents (ST-compounds) that disrupt microtubule function and kills cancer cells through a unique mechanism that is particularly efficacious in glioblastomas. This new R01 grant will determine how ST-compounds inhibit the fundamental oncogenic behaviors of glioblastomas, including cell division and cell fate, and how this response both compares to known microtubule targeting agents and how it interacts with standard of care DNA- damaging therapies, a body of work that will set a solid foundation to further develop MTAs for the treatment of glioblastomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: We conducted in vivo passaging of Human-Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (HSIV) in pigtailed macaques and recovered infectious molecular clones (IMCs) from the passage 3 macaque. We have observed several non- synonymous mutations throughout the genome of recovered IMCs, perhaps suggesting adaptation to pigtail macaques. In this grant application, we propose to determine the functional significance of mutations observed in envelope gene of recovered IMCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The heat shock response (HSR) is a highly conserved adaptive mechanism, regulated by heat shock factors, that acts to help proteins fold and function properly – critical in protecting against neurodegenerative diseases, but also exploited to our detriment to support the anabolic demands of viral infection and cancers. While the mechanistic principles of HSR activation and function have largely been studied in temperature stress, the physiological stresses that are found in normal development and disease are far more complex. This project is focused on elucidating novel mechanisms of heat shock factor function and regulation that are critical for cells coping with growth-related proteotoxic stresses that are relevant to human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: The goal of the GeneNetwork project is to provide a platform of innovation to make the best use of the data and computational tools for systems genetics. We will focus on broadening the impact of the web service by broadening research community participation in the web service and strengthening computational engine powering the web service. We will enhance our database by providing automated tools for data entry and curation (Aim 1); we will improve tools for genetic analysis of high-throughput traits (Aim 2); enable bidirectional information sharing between animal model and human genetic studies (Aim 3); and provide a platform for toolset prototyping and testing by the computational community (Aim 4).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Over 15 million people worldwide suffer from drug resistant epilepsy (DRE), and the most effective treatment for DRE is to surgically remove the seizure onset zone (SOZ), the region from which seizure activity is triggered. We propose to develop a tool that computes a combined intracranial EEG-fMRI biomarker of the SOZ while a DRE patient is not seizing or at “rest”. The novel biomarker is derived from connectivity properties of dynamical network models constructed from resting state intracranial EEG and fMRI, and may substantially reduce invasive monitoring times, avoiding further risks to patients and reducing costs to hospitals, and improve surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Six million Americans live with atrial fibrillation (AF), a heart rhythm abnormality that is a major risk factor for stroke and only half of those AF patients receive oral anticoagulation. Within the context of an ongoing collaboration between two large learning health systems, we propose to study the impact of a shared clinical decision support tool embedded within the electronic health record designed to enhance guideline-based oral anticoagulation prescription. Using a mixed-methods approach, we will examine how healthcare providers interact with the decision support tool to further refine the tool and measure its impact on anticoagulation prescribing behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: More than one third of epileptic patients have recurrent spontaneous seizures that cannot be treated with drugs. While optogenetic control of light-sensitized neurons can suppress seizures, our limited access to relevant neural circuits and the surgical implantation of external devices is a major barrier for clinical translation. Using a newly discovered potent protein actuator and viral-targeting strategy, this proposal will implement noninvasive optogenetics for long-term control of wild-type animals with drug-refractory epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The world is in need of an effective HIV/AIDS vaccine, and the cytomegalovirus (CMV) vector-based HIV/SIV vaccine featured in our studies is highly efficacious and durable to uniquely mediate viral “replication arrest” efficacy in the Rhesus Macaque-SIV model. Vaccine immunity is mediated by unconventional MHC-E-restricted CD8+ T cell responses and induction of IL-15, which correlate with vaccine protection. The work proposed in this application will reveal the molecular mechanisms of immune programming by the CMV-based vaccine and IL- 15 actions to inform human testing of this vaccine concept in ongoing and future phase I/II trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work has shown that humans exposed to several weeks of recurring 28-hour days to induce sleep restriction and circadian disruption (e.g., shift work, jet lag) had significantly decreased bone formation, with no change or an increase in bone resorption - an imbalance that could lead to bone loss, osteoporosis, and increased fracture risk. This R01 proposal will investigate the acute and chronic effects of real-world night shift work schedules on bone metabolism, density, quality and strength, and evaluate system-level mechanisms, including increased sympathetic tone. Results will inform screening recommendations for night shift workers, and introduce a paradigm shift in the prevention, evaluation, and treatment of osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventing epilepsy and its progression (epileptogenesis), and not just controlling seizure occurrence and severity, remains the Holy Grail for epilepsy research and therapy development. The current proposal will use a systematic approach to test the therapeutic efficacy for epilepsy prevention of different FDA-approved drugs and their combinations, which interact with the adenosine system (either upstream or downstream of adenosine). The expected outcome of this project is the development of a therapeutic strategy for epilepsy prevention based on the repurposing of existing FDA-approved drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This proposed U54 Collaborative Partnership between NCCU and UNC involves increasing NCCU alcohol research and student research experiences in fetal alcohol toxicity, alcohol neurotoxicity, and alcohol-induced carcinogenesis and inflammation. Health disparities include increased severity of alcohol-related pathology. Collaborative partnerships that carry out integrated and focused research on the molecular mechanisms of alcohol pathology involving faculty and students from NCCU, a historically Black College or University, educate and involve future researchers on alcohol-related health disparities and provide opportunities for careers in medical fields as well as making discoveries on mechanisms that may lead to cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BM-MSCs) and islet co-transplantation in the prevention of surgical diabetes, and to understand the mechanisms of protection in chronic pancreatitis (CP) patients undergoing total pancreatectomy and islet transplantation (TP-IAT). If proven effective, such strategy can be used as a therapeutic option in islet transplant patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF), Thunderclap headaches, and Nairobi sheep disease, are dangerous emerging human and animal diseases caused by nairoviruses that can potentially cause widespread health and economic devastation. Recently, nairoviruses have been shown to share a conserved evasion mechanism that hinders the human innate immune response. This proposal serves to investigate and leverage that mechanism through synergetic molecular, cell based and in vivo means in order to will provide information for the development of selective and broad-based anti- viral treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of the project is to continue the laboratory’s development of a novel neuroprosthetic therapy that enhances functional recovery of voluntary movement after spinal cord injury. The hypothesis addressed in the proposal is that targeted, activity-dependent spinal stimulation will substantially increase the effectiveness of traditional and use-dependent physical rehabilitation by inducing plasticity in spared descending and spinal neural circuits. In the long-term, this therapy may prove to be an effective complement to cellular transplants or genetic reprogramming treatments that target neuronal survival, regeneration, or synaptogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE: The current treatments for alcohol use disorders are not universally effective, so determining new therapeutic areas is of critical concern. Astrocytes, key regulators of the neuroimmune response and neurotransmission, represent a novel target by which to reduce excessive alcohol consumption. The results of the current study will explore the viability of reducing binge drinking and cognitive deficits through manipulating astrocytic regulations of neuroimmune and glutamate signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Why do organisms follow certain evolutionary trajectories when many are possible? The research program proposed here will identify the genetic factors and fitness effects that determine evolutionary repeatability in natural populations. The results are relevant to the fields of public health, conservation biology, and agricultural breeding, because they will help understand the probability of adaptation in target populations facing new selective challenges and parameterization of predictive models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as an understanding of those molecular pathways that modify sensitivity to prenatal alcohol exposure-induced birth defects is expected in the long-term to inform clinical practice and ultimately reduce the incidence and severity of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD). This objective will be met by applying two innovative and complementary approaches to assess in cell and animal models if novel genes or chemicals modulate the deficits elicited by ethanol exposure. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the parts of NIH/NIAAA’s mission that pertains to characterizing biological mechanisms underlying FASD, identifying biomarkers of prenatal alcohol exposure, and ultimately will reveal fundamental and novel insights into the mechanism of ethanol-induced birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to investigate the effects of alcohol on mammary stem cell deregulation and genomic instability in mammary tumor initiation and development. The role of the alcohol metabolite, acetaldehyde, in this process and the consequent molecular changes will be studied using transgenic animal models. Results from this project are expected to advance our understanding of the mechanisms of alcohol-associated breast cancer risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol withdrawal syndrome is a common, potentially fatal condition in hospitalized patients with two dominant therapies (benzodiazepines and phenobarbital), but no rigorous evidence to inform best practice. This K23 award will investigate how and why providers choose benzodiazepines or phenobarbital for management of inpatient alcohol withdrawal syndrome and the risk of adverse events associated with either treatment in different groups of hospitalized patients. This knowledge will be used to design and pilot an embedded pragmatic clinical trial to identify the safest first-line therapy for inpatient alcohol withdrawal syndrome: benzodiazepines or phenobarbital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: 3 sentences P. vivax is an emerging pathogen in sub-Saharan Africa, but control efforts remain focused on P. falciparum. Here, we propose to 1) quantify the clinical burden and associated risk factors of P. vivax for the first time in north-western Kenya, 2) estimate rate of underlying P. vivax infections in a P. falciparum and P. vivax co- endemic setting, and 3) implicate local vectors in P. vivax transmission with a special emphasis on surveillance for the invasive vector An. stephensi, thereby informing the potential for P. vivax to spread throughout Kenya. Findings from this study will not only help strengthen the core surveillance capacity in north-western Kenya, but will also generate evidence to guide Kenya’s National Malaria Control Programme and those of similar regions of sub-Saharan Africa as they confront the possibility of growing endemic P. vivax transmission fueled by an emerging vector species.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Septic shock is acute cardiovascular failure due to an infection that affects tens of thousands of children each year. Although crystalloid fluid resuscitation is the cornerstone of initial resuscitation, there is no definitive evidence for the most effective and safest type of crystalloid fluid in children. The objective of this large, pragmatic, randomized study is to test the comparative effectiveness of the two most common types of crystalloid to improve clinical outcomes in children treated for septic shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will test the novel hypothesis that increased blood pressure variability, as opposed to overt hypertension, impairs neurovascular function. Specifically, we will show that exacerbated mechanostimulation-driven calcium overload at the neurovascular unit cause cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We have recently demonstrated that aberrant activation of CHMP7 and the ESCRT-III nuclear surveillance pathway is an early pathogenic event that initiates NPC injury and impacts downstream TDP-43 dysfunction and localization in sporadic ALS and C9orf72 ALS/FTD. However, the molecular mechanisms that facilitate nuclear accumulation of CHMP7 and CHMP7 mediated NPC injury in ALS/FTD human neurons remain unknown. This proposal will test the hypothesis that cell biological events and protein interactions that specifically regulate CHMP7/ESCRT-III mediated NPC homeostasis in human neurons are pathologically impaired in ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) adults are almost twice as likely to have type 2 diabetes (T2D) than non-Hispanic white adults. Healthy nutrition habits are a cornerstone to effective diabetes self-management; however, barriers to healthful eating, such as lack of access to culturally-responsive diabetes nutrition education, lack of access to fresh food, or inability to afford healthy food (known as food insecurity), are common among AI/ANs with T2D. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of effective interventions to target AI/ANs with T2D who experience food insecurity is fundamental in reducing disproportionate diabetes health disparities among AI/AN communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is the deadliest leukemia, and though treatment with allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) and other immunotherapies is often beneficial, over 50% of AML patients eventually relapse. Little is known about what the drivers of the graft versus host and graft versus leukemia effects of alloSCT in this context. We hypothesize that minor histocompatibility antigens (mHAs) are a key driver of the effects of alloSCT for AML, and seek to identify novel mHAs and assess mHA-specific T cells in post-alloSCT relapse.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin-associated RNAs regulate gene expression and cell fate decisions during embryonic development. R-loops—nuclear structures that arise from hybridization of nascent RNA transcripts to their DNA templates— have important roles in regulation of chromatin structure, but also can contribute to genome instability. We will dissect the mechanisms by which R-loops carry out their regulatory functions and contribute to developmental cell fate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The purpose of the proposed study is to adapt the Ending Self-Stigma intervention for people living with HIV (PLWH) with opioid use disorder (OUD) and/or cocaine use disorder (CUD). The intervention will be modified through an iterative process of qualitative interviews with service delivery key informants and PLWH with OUD and/or CUD. There will also be two pilot tests before being tested in a small (N = 70) randomized clinical trial (RCT). Using data from the RCT, bivariate analyses will be conducted and path models will be fit to examine the effect of the intervention on proximal outcomes (internalized substance use and HIV stigmas, depressive symptoms, anxiety and stigma stress) and distal outcomes (antiretroviral therapy adherence, viral load suppression, self-reported substance use and urine toxicology screen for substances). The proposed research has the potential to reduce internalized stigma among PLWH with OUD and/or CUD and impact HIV outcomes and substance use cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Impact: Several serious mental health issues such as feeling depressed and using drugs involve problems with the processing and seeking of rewarding experiences. In addition, several of these emotional health problems are more common in individuals with a history of adversity early in life, and differ in men and women. Using experimental models, we discovered a new component of the brain machinery which is responsible for reward behaviors and have found the function of this component (projection) is influenced by early life adversity in a sex dependent way. Here we will use powerful methods in genetically-engineered mice to characterize the roles of this novel brain pathway in both males and females and uncover how it contributes to the mechanisms by which early-life adversity may promote mental health problems such as depression and substance use.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The most frequently diagnosed diseases among VA patients are inflammation related diseases including brain inflammation related diseases, obesity, rheumatoid arthritis, and colon cancer. Determining the precise mechanism(s) by which inflammation contributes to the development of these diseases is essential for the development of therapeutic strategies against these diseases. The focus of my career research is to characterize these mechanisms and then to determine whether targeting of these mechanisms effectively prevents/treats these diseases. Specifically, I will focus on the molecular mechanism(s) underlying how exosome-like nanoparticles from healthy edible plants contribute to the inhibition of microphage-mediated inflammation. A positive outcome for this study would be significant for the development of future products that provide a basis for developing mechanism-driven novel strategies for the prevention of chronic inflammation via non-invasive oral administration of treatments, and thus improve the health status of members of the VA patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narratives Dynamic biological acetylation regulates many facets of biological processes, including gene expression, genome stability, cellular metabolism, and chromatin organization. The conference brings together basic and translational scientists to discuss the fundamental mechanisms related to protein acetylation and its dysregulation in cancer and age-related diseases. The objectives of the conference are to 1) discuss new cutting-edge discoveries, 2) maximize new translational opportunities, 3) identify emerging new research directions and priorities, and 4) highlight the achievement of trainees and early career investigators via oral sessions, professional development forums, travel awards and other recognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative In the current proposal will investigate the influence of adipose tissue and obesity in the severity of cutaneous leishmaniasis. Our hypothesis is that adipokines, lipid profiles and leucocytes infiltrating adipose tissue are associated with inflammatory response-mediated tissue damage and severity of cutaneous leishmaniasis in obese patients. We will also study how lipids can reprogram macrophages towards a wound healing phenotype in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: MOI UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Next Generation Long lasting Insecticidal Treated Nets (LLINs) which combine a pyrethroid with a synergist that restores sensitivity in resistant mosquitoes are now recommended by the World Health Organization to mitigate insecticide resistance that has been documented in several areas and is threatening reversal of the gains made in controlling malaria. In Kenya, the distribution of PBO nets was done in mid-2021 in three high malaria burden counties (Bungoma, Kakamega and Busia), including among our cohort participants. Leveraging on our existing longitudinal cohort encompassing 500 people, the proposed work seeks to look at the impact of the PBO nets in real world implementation setting and explore human and entomological factors that may compromise effectiveness with the ultimate goal of informing co-interventions or other strategies that can maximize the impact of PBO and other next generation LLINs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aneuploidy, an abnormal number of chromosomes, is associated with many human conditions and diseases, including miscarriages, birth defects, and cancer. In this proposal, we are requesting grant support to bring together the world’s experts in the field of aneuploidy to share their latest findings during the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology sponsored conference “The Consequences of Aneuploidy.” The goal of the meeting is to advance our understanding of how aneuploidy impacts human health and disease which will lead to new therapeutic strategies that prevent aneuploidy, eliminate aneuploid cells, and treat the symptoms of aneuploidy associated conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Symbiotic relationships formed early in life with skin commensal microorganisms can promote health and restrict damaging inflammation. Understanding the cellular and molecular determinants of these interactions has the potential to inform novel therapeutic strategies for chronic inflammatory disease. Studies in this proposal aim to understand the mechanisms by which commensal bacteria influence the functional dynamics of the developing myeloid compartment in neonatal skin and the consequences of these interactions for cutaneous health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decision making is an important cognitive function that is impaired in psychiatric diseases like substance use disorder (SUD). This proposal aims to investigate the role that dopamine plays in the neuronal circuit that underlies decision making. A better understanding of the circuitry underlying decision-making will help us understand why maladaptive behavior arises in disorders like SUD and may lead to advancements in therapeutics for SUD which affect about 37 million Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Diversity supplement funding is requested to support the research and career training of Ms. Anna Kelly, who is a graduate of the Bioengineering Department at the University of Pittsburgh and whose career goal is to become a physician-scientist to provide accessible care to her patients and to contribute to the science that impacts them. Ms. Kelly will receive research and career training under the parent grant investigating the charge transfer, electrochemical, and biocompatibility properties of electrodes on the efficacy and safety of microstimulation, with her independent research project under the parent grant focusing on the effects of microstimulation on the integrity of the blood-brain barrier and brain vasculature. This research and career training will be invaluable for Ms. Kelly in achieving her future goal of becoming a physician-scientist in neural engineering and will contribute significantly to her future success in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) affects more than 5 million Americans over the age of 60 and manifests with progressive memory loss, decline in cognitive abilities, and altered circadian regulation, which affects sleep- wake patterns and behavior and represents the main factor of hospitalization and morbidity. The daily feed/fast cycle is a powerful regulator of the circadian system, and we recently demonstrated that time-restricted feeding improves key disease components including memory, sleep, disease pathology, and brain transcription in mouse models of AD. We will investigate the safety, feasibility, and effectiveness of prolonged night fasting in reducing cognitive decline and disease markers in patients with cognitive impairment due to AD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Sierra Leone, College of Medicine and Allied Health Sciences (COMAHS) and Kenema Government Hospital (KGH), in partnership with Tulane University; will build upon successes of its first five-year period to continue developing implementation science and clinical trial research capacity for emerging infections in Sierra Leone. The overarching five-year goal of the PREVSL project, in Phase II, will be to provide the support necessary to COMAHS and its newly launched PhD degree program in Biomedical Sciences and Public Health that will anchor effective systems over time and ensure the PhD programs long-term sustainability. We will do this while continuing to strengthen the KGH clinical research program as a training site for future student and researchers through the promotion of ongoing implementation science and clinical trial research in emerging infections from which trainees can attain practical and applied research skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the U.S HIV population ages the proportion of those diagnosed with cancer (such as HIV-related lymphomas) will continue to rise, emphasizing an urgent need for equitable access to curative lymphoma treatments such as hematopoietic cell transplants (HCT). This project will characterize the inequitable utilization of HCTs based on social determinants of health among California patients with HIV-related lymphomas, and elucidate differences in care outcomes based on HIV status and transplant type. Through the use of an innovative linked cancer registry dataset, the findings from this project will expand the knowledge base on inequitable HCT utilization and the related social determinants of health to support interventions that will close the gap in health disparities within this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Animal survival is dependent on locomotion to successfully find shelter, locate a mate, capture prey, and avoid predators. The goal of this proposal is to utilize the optically transparent and genetically tractable zebrafish model system to elucidate the mechanisms of glutamatergic signaling responsible for regulating the properties of in vivo spinal locomotor output, which will set the basis for a better understanding for the control of vertebrate locomotion. Since many principles of CPG function are conserved across vertebrates it is likely that these findings will translate to other animals, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Projective Narrative Youth experiencing homelessness (YEH) face high rates of childhood adversity and trauma on the streets, which are associated with impaired mental health. The purpose of this study is to examine associations between adversity profiles, social network processes (support and behavior), psychological distress (depressive symptoms, suicidal ideation, and suicide attempt), and physiological stress (hair cortisol concentration) among YEH, and the potential for social networks processes to buffer the negative effects of adversity. The results of this study may contribute to targeted interventions for YEH after adversity and prevent subsequent negative health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although peripheral viremia is suppressed in people living with HIV (PLWH) since the advent of combination anti-retroviral therapy, a significant portion of PLWH still suffer from comorbidities and complications. This project aims to determine the molecular mechanism of chronic inflammation, the chief driver of non-AIDS complications, caused by persistent HIV infection in PLWH on suppressive therapy. Successful completion of this proposal would help develop new therapeutics towards a functional cure of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Infections and tumors evade early immune detection in barrier tissues such as the skin, lung, and gut. The application offers foundational insight into how tissue-specific immunity is generated, and maintained in our, for which there is a current urgent need, given the SARSCoV2 pandemic (lung) and Monkeypox (skin) outbreak. We predict mechanisms being investigated in this application are central to modeling better vaccine immunizations, to understanding the efficacy and toxicity from immune based drugs being used in patients, to generating better adoptive cell therapies, and to therapeutically limit autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Skin immunity plays a pivotal role in mitigating tick feeding. In this R21 application, we will determine how the salivary protein sialostatin L2 affects alarmin immune signaling in keratinocytes during a tick bite. The epidermis, which interfaces with the external environment, has been neglected when studying ectoparasite feeding on a mammalian host. Collectively, this R21 project will advance fundamental knowledge of tick-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death due to an infectious disease globally and remains a serious public health problem in Ethiopia which is on the WHO “high burden countries” lists for TB and TB/HIV. A shortage of well-trained TB investigators in Ethiopia and globally remains a major barrier to achieving the WHO End TB Strategy goals to eliminate TB by 2035. The goals of this D43 renewal application for the “Ethiopia- Emory TB Research Training Program (EETB-RTP)” include: 1) Continue to build relevant and sustainable research capacity in Ethiopia by aligning research training activities with the research priorities outlined in the Ethiopian MOH’s “National Tuberculosis Research Roadmap (2022-2026)”; 2) Support career development to promote the 7 professional characteristics of a translational scientist aligned with leadership in TB research; 3) Implement a new Advanced Training Track which will provide advanced grant writing instruction, mentor training, and leadership training to former Ethiopian Fogarty trainees to optimize their transition into independent investigators and mentors for the next generation of Ethiopian investigators; and 4) Enhance the diversity of the Ethiopian TB biomedical workforce by continuing to increase the number of women engaged in TB research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In this supplement proposal we build on a unique randomized controlled trial of foster care as an alternative for institutional care based in Bucharest, Romania. This valuable sample of children is being studied when participants are 22 years of age to examine the long-term consequences of early adversity and early intervention, as well as the effects of positive caregiving during adolescence on brain development, psychopathology, and competent functioning in young adulthood. We are requesting support for our staff for six months to complete data collection on the sample.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even in the healthy aging brain there is a progressive decline in cognitive capabilities and vascular health, yet paradoxically brain energy consumption is close to normal. Our goal is to understand how the loss of vascular health impacts the accumulation in tissue of metabolic nutrients and waste products, which may interfere with brain function. Achieving this goal is expected to have broad impact to guide potential interventions to improve or preserve brain health in aging and beyond, including neurological conditions such as dementia, stroke, traumatic brain injury and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The purpose of this research is to confirm that the current treatment regimen for isoniazid-resistant tuberculosis (the most common drug-resistant tuberculosis) is well tolerated, has few side effects, and meets the WHO recommended efficacy target (90 percent treatment success). It will also assess blood concentrations of the most important drugs in the regimen to consider making dose adjustments that improve efficacy and safety. If the regimen is safe and effective, its duration could be reduced by adjusting doses; alternatively, exposure to specific drugs could be reduced or doses adjusted to improve efficacy while avoiding safety concerns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite effective prevention tools, the annual incidence of new HIV-1 infections remains high, emphasizing the need for a vaccine. This proposal introduces an innovative approach using deep learning to design immunogens computationally, expanding structural design possibilities to generate gp120 core immunogens that more closely resemble the pre-fusion gp120 and assess their potential to elicit potent B-cell responses for broadly neutralizing antibodies. This research will provide valuable insights into new antigen design techniques and their application in HIV-1 vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing disparities in the burden of chronic disease requires tools to support policy makers’ and communities’ understanding of which health-related policies, practices, or programs (PPP) could effectively and cost-effectively improve health, mortality, and equity outcomes. Building on our prior work developing chronic disease and economic models for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion, we will develop an interactive web-based simulation model of six chronic diseases (heart disease, stroke diabetes, cancer, chronic kidney disease, and Alzheimer’s disease) that allows users to explore the impacts of PPPs on chronic disease incidence and disparities over the next 5 to 30 years. The model will produce results at local, state, and national levels of the impacts of using PPPs to address disparities by race/ethnicity, age, income, education, urban versus rural status, and sex, thus encouraging the use of community-based participatory approaches to confront SDOH and chronic disease disparities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-DP-23-001, Simulation Model of Interventions Linking Evidence to SDOH (SMILES)

PHR: This research is relevant for Veterans, as stroke is one of the leading causes of long-term disability in Veterans. An estimated 15,000 Veterans suffer a stroke each year. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Non-cholera Vibrio species are a significant threat to human health through food poisoning and wound infection exacerbated by biofilms. This project will use structural and biochemical techniques to probe a central component of a highly relevant biofilm regulatory pathway. The resulting information will provide us with greater insight into the mechanisms governing this system and advance the field by broadening our understanding of how bacteria regulate biofilm formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The U.S. is experiencing a crisis of opioid misuse, addiction, and overdose; in the most recent year, there were over 100,000 drug-related overdose deaths, 75% of which involved opioids. There is a clear, urgent need for improved pharmacotherapies for the treatment of opioid use disorder (OUD) that do not possess a high potential for abuse, physical dependence, or overdose. Park Therapeutics is developing cebranopadol as a safe and potentially effective alternative treatment for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: THE HOST PATHOGEN MAP INITIATIVE 2.0 OVERALL NARRATIVE The Host-Pathogen Map Initiative (HPMI) 2.0 applies a state-of-the-art suite of systems biology approaches to study the molecular interactions of bacterial and viral respiratory pathogens with the host cell machinery in disease-relevant primary cell models. In the previous funding period, these approaches identified several new host factors with unexpectedly opposite roles in resistance to viral and bacterial pathogens. Here, we will uncover the protein-protein and genetic interactions of the most important pulmonary infectious agents of humans, Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) and SARS-CoV-2 - including currently circulating variants of concern omicron and delta - to deeply probe the functional roles of host and pathogen factors in infection and disease progression and identify therapeutically actionable targets for host-directed therapies, circumventing the risk of pathogen treatment resistance. Finally, the integration of such network information with clinical information will allow us to determine predictors of disease severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All organisms produce a bevy of small molecules, many of which are not required for primary metabolic processes but confer selective advantage to the producing organism in complex biological environments. The biosynthetic pathways to these molecules often involve complex enzymatic transformations, which in many cases remain to be discovered. Understanding the biosynthetic pathways to these small molecule natural products is an important step in gleaning their role in physiology, with an ultimate goal of introducing them in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – UCSF LIVER CENTER The Liver Center is a community of scientists performing research on a variety of topics pertinent to liver health and disease. Some study normal liver, including normal liver development and function; others study how livers become diseased, and use this insight to develop new therapies. Liver Center scientists cover the complete spectrum of liver disease research, from basic cell biology to clinical trials and studies of the impact of social and environmental factors on the outcome of liver diseases. The Liver Center supports these lines of research by facilitating access to research technologies, promoting exchange of knowledge and ideas, and launching innovative projects by gifted scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining the normal activity of lysosomes, the recycling centers of the cell, is essential for human health, as evidenced by the many rare disorders caused by defects in the formation or function of lysosomes. How lysosomal dysfunction leads to the symptoms of these disorders is poorly understood. Our long-term goal is to define those disease mechanisms, and use that information to identify new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Currently, there are no adequate methods to predict whether an individual with post-traumatic headache (PTH) will have resolution of headaches during the acute phase or will have persistence of PTH (PPTH). The goal of this study is to identify a prognostic biomarker signature that will accurately predict the persistence of PTH using clinical data and structural and functional brain neuroimaging data collected in the semi-acute post-concussion phase. The ability to predict who will develop PPTH would help clinicians determine how aggressively to manage patients with PTH during the acute phase and would allow for optimizing enrollment into PTH clinical trials by preferentially enrolling individuals who are likely to have PTH persistence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium (CPTAC) seeks to expand the proteogenomic approach developed during the past 10 years to more cancer types and to translational research focusing on clinically relevant problems. This application proposes an integrative proteogenomic data analysis center (iPGDAC) built on our established expertise and resources. The overarching goal of the iPGDAC is to accelerate the translation of cancer proteogenomic data into better understanding of cancer biology and improved cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Bacterial infections and in particular Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections (TB) cause millions of deaths each year. All anti-TB drugs have serious limitations due to the lack of timely antibacterial effect, their inability to eliminate slow growing “persister-like” cells, human toxicity over extended the treatment regimens required, the emergence of multidrug resistant strains, the lack of new effective pan-antibacterial drugs, and because the cost of extended drug therapies can bankrupt a poor family. Herein we explore DectiSomes, a transformative new drug design and conceptual framework in which antibacterial drug-loaded liposomes are coated with pathogen receptors, targeting them to bacterial cells and increasing drug efficacy by orders of magnitude.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Actinomycete bacteria have historically been an incredibly rich source of useful chemical compounds, often called natural products. These natural products include antibiotics, antifungals, and anti-cancer compounds. Pathogen resistance to many antibiotics is on the rise, however, the pace of antibiotics discovery has slowed. We now know that natural product biosynthesis by actinomycetes is often triggered during microbial interactions. We will study how social interactions between actinomycetes lead to biosynthesis of natural products at the molecular genetic and systems levels, and use these insights to leverage microbial interactions for novel antimicrobial discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep and circadian (24-hour) rhythms are fundamental functions of human beings that promote physical, mental, and cognitive health, but show substantial disparities across the population. Given the recent explosion of scientific knowledge about sleep and circadian rhythms, the scientific workforce in these areas remains small and insufficiently diverse. The aim of this grant is to train a new and diverse generation of sleep and circadian rhythms researchers, including doctoral, predoctoral, and short-term scholars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current eligibility guidelines for lung cancer screening exclude a greater percentage of high-risk African Americans than whites. To remedy this, we will build a lung cancer risk prediction model for African Americans and use the new model to identify racially equitable screening strategies in the US population. Finally, we will produce a web-based tool to aid personalized risk prediction at shared decision-making visits to equitably help African Americans assess whether lung screening is desired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose the development of the COllaborative Northwestern Surgical Oncology Research Training (CONSORT) program to develop the next generation of surgical oncology-focused scientists. The CONSORT program is anchored by our successful history of two-year dedicated research training by (1) a highly accomplished team of Northwestern University researchers and clinicians to provide tailored mentoring for the trainees and (2) the unique 15-year partnership in training surgical research trainees in conjunction with the American College of Surgeons’ Cancer Programs. The CONSORT program will be a national leader in increasing the pipeline of qualified surgical oncology physician and PhD scientists who go on to faculty positions, with independently funded research agendas, making seminal contributions to the field, and mentoring their own trainees, while also delivering high-quality, compassionate care to cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes several human cancers including Kaposi's sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman's disease. These malignancies inflict morbidity and mortality to the society in US and worldwide. This project will investigate the mechanisms regulating the replication of KSHV by RNA modifications, and identify potential therapeutic targets for developing novel prevention and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will provide novel information on the role of microglia in disease mechanisms and neuronal dysfunction in C9orf72 patients clinically diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia (FTD). While microglia activation is known to occur in this patient population through postmortem autopsy studies, a much better understanding is needed regarding the extend of microglia-neuron co-regulation and the existence or absence of non-cell autonomous disease mechanisms similar to what has been described for astrocyte and motor neurons in other neurodegenerative diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The proposed studies will provide novel opportunities for drug target identification and future drug discovery efforts with the hope of identifying novel therapeutics for these affected patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While evidence of long-term clinical outcomes and quality-of-life data for cancer patients is trivial for treatment planning, manual extraction of data is an extremely challenging task for human curators and needs hours of manual chart-review. We propose to develop an open-source NLP toolkit for curating treatment administered (chemotherapy, immunotherapy, radiation, surgery) and clinical outcome (progression, recurrence) data longitudinally by parsing varying types of clinical narratives for performing population-wide cancer research. In this study, we will collaborate with two state-wide cancer registries (Georgia and California) for evaluating our NLP developments for cancer data curation and obtain a robust performance evaluation across heterogeneous populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults with T1D, as a subgroup of the population with T1D, have the poorest glycemic control of all, reaching a peak mean A1c >9% around age 19; they, too, often experience diabetes distress. Diabetes distress is common in persons with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and contributes to suboptimal self-care behaviors and outcomes, especially for the high risk group of adolescents and young adults with T1D. In the proposed 2-year randomized clinical trial, we will implement and assess the impact of a behavioral/psycho- educational intervention to reduce diabetes distress, increase acceptance of self-care behaviors (with or without diabetes technologies), and improve glycemic outcomes in adolescents and young adults, aged 14-25 years, with T1D in order to optimize their short-term and long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rationale for the proposed research is that understanding the longitudinally-linked neural stages, representations, and mechanisms that underlie continuous speech processing, and ultimately permit speech understanding, will result in individually tuned innovative methods to assess and treat auditory disorders. Moreover, the neural components investigated in this proposal, separately and collectively, show great potential as objective measures of speech intelligibility; these measures provide a path for the development of brain-aware hearing aids and automated tuning of hearing assistive devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The knowledge gap in our understanding of ocular surface immunomodulation is a barrier for developing relevant new therapies for corneal inflammatory disorders and fibrosis that account for the most common reasons for outpatient visits to an ophthalmologist. By elucidating exciting new information related to the ocular surface immunomodulatory functions of SLURP1- an abundantly expressed yet understudied molecule- this project will lay a solid foundation for development of new therapies targeting ocular surface inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Current immunotherapy treatments have shown minimal therapeutic activity in pancreatic adenocarcinomas (PDA). This is due to the lack of effective T cell generation and the still unknown complex signals in the PDA tumor microenvironment (TME) that prohibit T cell infiltration and function. With the expertise of our multidisciplinary team of researchers, our Program will identify optimal combination therapies for inducing quality T cells and bypassing TME suppressive signals to yield effective antitumor immunity against PDAs.

PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and urinary tract infections (UTI) are very common disorders in the general population. The multidisciplinary Research Projects of the Columbia University George M. O’Brien Urology Cooperative Research Center build upon the work conducted in the prior cycle to address questions related to the genetic, cellular, and metabolic events that lead to lower urinary tract disorders such as LUTS and UTI, and devise new methods for prevention and treatment, while providing educational enrichment for future scientists and promoting collaborations with investigators within urology and other fields

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain’s capacity to use contextual information to modulate behavior is essential to maintain human health and quality of life. This proposal will use a multidisciplinary approach to elucidate molecular and cellular principles that enable neurons to translate contextual information into behaviors. Results of this study will elucidate novel pathways for context-dependent behavior and improve our understanding of the brain power in translating contextual information into behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Exposure to the class of environmental toxicants known as per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) has been associated with increased risk factors for cardiometabolic disease, including hypercholesterolemia. The proposed research will investigate if PFAS exposure can therefore induce the development of atherosclerosis, while also seeking to understand mechanisms causing the atherosclerosis that are related to bile acid metabolism and transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The burden of chronic disease disparities is most evident among African American and Hispanic/Latino populations in the southeastern United States. To address these pervasive health inequities, the Southeast Collaborative for Innovative and Equitable Solutions to Chronic Disease Disparities we will bring together expertise at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, University of Miami School of Medicine, and Meharry Medical College to collaboratively develop and implement multi-level interventions. The Center will partner with communities and will leverage advances in technology and data science to reduce risk factors for and disparities in diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, and related conditions among African American and Latino populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have previously shown that histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors can have significant effects on pancreatic cancer cells as well as the immune cells that are within pancreatic cancers. The overall goal of our project is to understand the mechanisms through which this epigenetic therapy affects the immune system's interaction with pancreatic cancer, and to investigate the potential for synergy between epigenetic therapies and other treatments that work on the immune system, to improve outcomes for patients with pancreatic cancer. We will accomplish these goals using mouse models of pancreatic cancer as well as tissues from a human clinical trial combining HDAC inhibition and immunotherapy in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CpH (H=A/C/T) methylation was found high level in neurons and plays important roles in brain development and neurological disorders. Using a state-of-the-art protein array, Digital Affinity Profiling via Proximity Ligation (DAPPL), a viral in vivo delivery system and high-throughput sequencing technologies, we will identify sequence-independent and -dependent mCpH-binding proteins and characterize their roles in transcriptional and chromatin regulation in adult mouse brain. These data will provide a foundation to investigate the roles of CpH methylation in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Asian immigrant women have a higher risk of an unintended birth compared to White women, and are less likely to report recent use of sexual and reproductive healthcare compared to US-born Asian women. Despite these trends, there is a lack of disaggregated data by ethnicities and immigration statuses, contributing to the invisibility of Asian women. This study will significantly contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms and protective factors that moderate immigration status and use of sexual and reproductive healthcare and to the identification of novel community, social, and policy-level interventions that can improve the sexual and reproductive health of Asian immigrant women.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The New Mexico Department of Health Scientific Laboratory Division (NMDOH SLD) Environmental Microbiology laboratory intends to continue participation in the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System Retail Meat Surveillance project. The SLD EM laboratory will continue to support the goal of the project by determining the prevalence of antimicrobial resistance among Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli, Enterococcus species, Vibrio species, Aeromonas species and Lactose fermenters isolated from retail samples of retail chicken, ground turkey, ground beef, pork chops and seafood purchased from grocery stores in New Mexico. The laboratory will continue to provide testing for this project following established procedures and participate in any pilot studies that are introduced. Page 1 of 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Stimulant use disorder (StUD) is rapidly growing in the US with a current prevalence of ~3.2M and ~57K stimulant-related overdose deaths/year. However, there are no pharmacological treatments for StUD. We propose to develop a novel agent, SBS-518, a dual sigma receptor antagonist / DAT inhibitor for the treatment of stimulant use disorder to help curb this rising epidemic with a novel pharmacological therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Project 3 Our group has led several previous and ongoing studies of immunotherapy in pancreatic cancer which have shown promising activity, but the benefits appear limited to a small number of patients. This project seeks to understand the contribution of macrophages to suppression of the anti-tumor immune response and resistance to immunotherapy, and will test new treatment strategies incorporating macrophage-targeting agents into immunotherapy combinations. We will examine the impact of these agents on the composition of immune cells in the tumor and in the peripheral blood to better understand how they exert anti-tumor effects.

PHR: NARRATIVE More people die of preventable disease in the United States than in other wealthy countries, especially among people with lower education or incomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia, the brain resident macrophages, exist in unique activation states that have been implicated in modulating Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk; however, the regulation of these states and their impact on AD progression is incompletely understood. We found that expression level of the transcription factor PU.1 plays an important role in regulating microglia gene expression in an amyloid mouse model of AD and that low expression is associated with neuroprotective phenotypes. In this proposal I will address the regulation of microglia activation states by PU.1 dosage and its potential downstream protective mechanisms during amyloid pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Castration-resistant prostate cancer is lethal and remains incurable, and the NCI-funded research program directed by Dr. Nima Sharifi seeks to understand mechanisms of resistance and identify new treatments. Our recently established Genitourinary Malignancy Research Center (GUMRC) is an interdisciplinary collaboration of research scientists and clinicians that focuses on understanding, diagnosing and treating bladder, kidney and prostate malignancy. This award will allow me to serve in complementary roles as a technical expert leading experiments in Dr. Sharifi's lab and Program Manager for the GUMRC.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative We know the early social-communication skills of children with ASD is one of the best predictors of later outcomes and often targeted in interventions; yet, current measures of social-communication skills designed for children with ASD do not easily allow for ongoing intervention progress monitoring. The proposed research is relevant to public health because by validating a novel outcome measure of key social-communication and language skills that is minimally burdensome to administer and sensitive to incremental change expected of young children with ASD, we may better monitor the effects of interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE The inaccessibility of the brain in living people has confined molecular investigations of neuropsychiatric traits to postmortem tissue. Here, we address critical limitations that arise from this framework through (1) comprehensive, multiomic molecular profiling of living and postmortem human brain tissue and (2) integrating multiomics data with neuroimaging and neurocognitive data from the same individuals. At the center of this proposal is the Living Brain Project (LBP), wherein we survey a vast data landscape in individuals undergoing deep brain stimulation, including molecular data derived from bilateral biopsies from the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. We anticipate fundamental advances in our understanding of the human brain will be made not only by the analyses proposed here but also by making this rich resource available to the larger scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The liver controls whole-body metabolism, and disease states such as pre-diabetes, type 2 diabetes and non- alcoholic fatty liver disease arise from disorders in liver metabolism. We identified a critically important sugar transporter that regulates liver metabolism, and a naturally-occurring disaccharide that acts upon this sugar transporter to improve liver and whole-body metabolism, including enhancing the body’s ability to burn calories and to dispose of fat within the liver. The goal of this project is to understand precisely how this sugar transporter regulates liver and whole-body metabolism, and to define the mechanism of action of our index drug to inform new, safe therapies against diabetes and fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many human diseases are the result of defects in developmental processes that occur during gestation or in early life. In order to improve our understanding of the developmental origins of disease, it is essential to have a rigorous understanding of the normal processes of human development. This study will provide essential data to better understand human development by providing insight into which molecular changes are conserved among primate species and which are human-specific.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pancreatic cancer has a highly desmoplastic stroma which is enriched with activated stellate cells and hyaluronic acids that contribute to the cancer’s poor prognosis. This project will test novel immunotherapy combinations targeting stromal signaling pathways in combination with immune checkpoint inhibitors in pancreatic cancers. Findings will provide novel strategies for testing combinations of stromal targeting agents with neoantigen- targeting approaches, epigenetic modifying approaches, and monocyte modulating immune checkpoint inhibitors in pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Tumors are complex entities that interact and coevolve with non-tumor cells, a major driving force for therapy resistance. This evolution is not random, but follows well-structured patterns. The recent development of single- cell technologies and novel quantitative approaches is creating the opportunity to uncover the principles of this coevolution and to develop therapeutic strategies to address this complexity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogens directly impact individual survival and thus strongly influence the genetics of host populations, providing a model for studying evolutionary processes of adaptation. In this proposal, we investigate the impact of host-pathogen interactions on human and non-human primate genomes focusing on admixed human and non-human primate populations and copy number variation. This work will reveal new patterns of natural selection and phenotypic associations at genes involved in recent battles against infectious pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  As PD-1 immune checkpoint blockade becomes a prevalent immunotherapeutic for treating cancer and chronic viral infections, the emergence of immune related adverse events highlights the importance of studying the effects of unleashing immune cell subsets in delicate organs like the salivary gland. I aim to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which PD-1 regulates CD8+ T cells in the salivary gland, and characterize the transcriptome and effector functions of the expanded CD8+ T cell population. I will also examine the potential immunopathological consequences of CD8+ T cell expansion in the PD-1 KO salivary gland by assessing histopathology and saliva secretions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-typhoidal Salmonella enterica sickens more than one million people each year in the United States. This proposal investigates how Salmonella responds to the sulfur metabolite, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to regulate gene expression and support enteric disease. An improved mechanistic understanding of how DMSO reduction pathways are regulated will guide the future development of therapeutics that reduce the metabolic versatility of Salmonella within the gut to improve human health.

PHR: Project Narrative Project iCREATE (investigating Career & Research Experience Access Through Evidence) will address the lack of diversity in biomedical careers by designing, implementing, and testing, two scalable and innovative interventions; as well as investigating the effect of various research and career development experiences on students' career goals, career strategies, and key student career intent and action outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survivors of Ebola virus disease report having symptoms beyond recovery from infection, often severe enough to interfere with daily life. These symptoms, collectively termed Post-Ebola Syndrome (PES), range from musculoskeletal to neurological manifestations, yet the cause of PES development is unknown. This proposal aims to uncover the role of antibody-mediated immune effector function in the development of PES, thereby identifying potential therapeutic targets for the treatment/prevention of PES.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Severe Chronic Neutropenia International Registry (SCNIR) is a research resource that supports the study of the diagnosis, genetics, treatment, and outcomes for patients with very low blood neutrophil counts, a type of immunodeficiency predisposing patients of all ages to severe bacterial infections. With support from NIAID, work from the SCNIR has guided clinical care of patients with SCN, advanced our scientific understanding about neutrophils, and provided educational resources for patients and medical providers regarding this rare condition over the past 25 years. To move forward, we propose to move the SCNIR to Boston Children’s Hospital, with its outstanding infrastructure to modernize the database; partner with both physician and patient communities; generate deep clinical and genetic datasets for researchers; promote novel clinical trials; and provide resources for engagement and education of patients, medical providers, and disease advocacy groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) experience prolonged hospital stays and poor neurodevelopmental outcomes, in-part because of the lack of accurate, individualized, biologic assessments available to manage this increasingly common medical condition. The proposed study will define the molecular mechanisms that regulate the response to opioid withdrawal in the developing brain by focusing on three candidate microRNAs (let-7a, miR-146a, miR-192) that have been shown to respond to opioid exposure in animal models and adults, and are impacted in both my preliminary study of infants with NAS, and my human neural progenitor cell (NPC) design of opioid withdrawal. By determining the mechanism through which microRNAs impact NPC differentiation in opioid withdrawal, and determining whether exosomal salivary microRNA levels predict treatment dose and neurodevelopmental outcomes in infants with NAS, this study will enhance our knowledge of NAS-related biology and identify potential biomarkers that could improve medical care for this important medical condition.
