IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genomics and Bioinformatics Core (Core C) provides a centralized resource that allows the Program Projects to harness powerful immunogenomic and epigenomic, bulk and single cell next generation sequencing technologies, computational/bioinformatics analyses, and cross-platform integration. The deployment of these cutting-edge technologies and integrative analyses will create important synergies and efficiencies in resource usage across the Program Project, and resolve the molecular and cellular landscape of the TME to facilitate the goal of achieving precision immunotherapy for pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative At the molecular level, the homeostasis of cells and tissues largely depends on the correct activity of properly structured proteins, that if altered can lead to the onset of a myriad different human diseases. With this research program we will develop new mass spectrometry technologies for the analysis of intact protein forms, or proteoforms, and their bioactive complexes, to elucidate the precise set of genetic and chemical modifications responsible for aberrant phenotypes in the human population. These new analytical tools will help advancing our understanding of the mechanisms underlying human pathologies and facilitate the identification of new biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE: The COMMUNITY Center of NYC brings together an interdisciplinary team of investigators, health care providers and community stakeholders around NYC through multi-institutional partnerships (Columbia, Cornell, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Physician Affiliate Group of New York) to reduce health disparities in multiple chronic diseases. We focus on cardiovascular disease and cancer, and their risk factors, as they are the two leading causes of death and that share common social context, etiological pathways, risk factors and management strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Digital Pathology and Mass Cytometry Core (Core D) will serve as a centralized resource for each project by providing state-of-the-art proteomic technologies to assay the status of the tumor microenvironment. The Core will employ multiple color image analysis (multispectral immunofluorescence tissue staining) and high- parameter single-cell protein profiling (mass cytometry by Time-of-Flight; CyTOF) of human and animal pancreatic tumor tissue in order to construct a multi-dimensional map of the tumor microenvironment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mayo Clinic Center for Clinical and Translational Sciences (CCaTS) accelerates innovations in clinical research and partners with our stakeholders and communities to improve patient care and human health for all people. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental disorders affect one in four people worldwide; however, the lack of quantifiable metrics for mental health disorders contributes to the challenges of diagnosis, monitoring, and treatment. The goal of this research proposal is to develop a skin-like wearable sensor system to monitor physical and chemical mental health biomarker as an approach to quantify mental health state. I will design and fabricate physical biosensors to monitor skin conductance and chemical biosensors to monitor sweat cortisol levels, using intrinsically stretchable materials to provide high signal-to-noise ratio recordings and minimal discomfort without social stigma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Errors in research are human and can provide us with valuable teachable moments to understand the why questions in science, i.e., the concepts underlying causality. The NeuR3o-LOGIC project uses a structured error analysis and reduction approach to teach critical thinking about causal relationships at the intersection of the human gut microbiome and the nervous system, particularly the brain. Expert interviews enhance recorded lectures and case study problems to illustrate the concepts through examples from related neurological disorders, such as autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most stroke patients are initially evaluated at the closest hospital but some need to be transferred to a hospital that can provide more advanced care. The “Door-In-Door-Out” (DIDO) process at the first hospital can take time making transferred patients no longer able to get the advanced treatments. This study will help hospitals across the US “stand up” new ways to evaluate stroke patients, decide who needs to be transferred, and transfer them quickly for advanced treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The identity of bacterial species present in the human gut microbiome impacts human health; however, the factors determining which species colonize an individual remain poorly understood. This study is designed to identify antagonistic interactions occurring between species in the mammalian gut, with the goal of uncovering their contribution to gut microbiome species composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Automated liquid handling systems have transformed biomedical research laboratories by enabling scientists to conduct programmable reactions from low-volume samples. However, most existing systems suffer from drawbacks such as surface adsorption, cross contamination, and limited programmability. The objective of the proposed project is to develop an acoustic-based technology that overcomes these key obstacles and enables a highly programmable, biocompatible, and high-throughput fluidic processor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Black/African-Americans use alcohol and illicit drugs at the same rates as their white counterparts but are much more likely to suffer negative substance related consequences. Moreover, they are less likely to initiate treatment when compared with other racial groups; and when they do, are significantly less likely to complete treatment or to be offered evidence-based treatments. Offering validated, technology-based treatments in alternative settings, such as the Black Church, a highly trusted entity in Black communities, is a novel, and potentially highly disseminable strategy for improving access to evidenced-based treatments and improving alcohol treatment outcomes for this important population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Pulse oximetry has played a crucial role during the COVID-19 pandemic because measurements of hypoxemia serve as the major indication for hospitalizing patients, but clinical studies have shown that commercially available pulse oximeters can systematically overestimate true arterial oxygen saturation for persons with dark skin pigmentation. This bias has resulted in respiratory compromised persons with dark skin not meeting criteria for hospitalization or initiation of ventilator support, thereby putting specific populations (Black, Latinx, and Native American) at disproportionately greater risk for higher mortality or morbidity compared to those with light skin. In view of our pilot research showing that the bias is due, at least in part, to the devices’ use of polychromatic red light-emitting diode (LED) light sources, we are proposing to present, develop, test, and promote an improved and more-accurate light-based technology for the provision and marketing of simple, inexpensive, and bias-free pulse oximeters.
PI_NAMEs: FIGUEIRO, MARIANA GROSS;HOROWITZ, CAROL R;REA, MARK S (contact);RICHARDSON, LYNNE D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Sleep health disparities contribute to the disproportionate burden of poor cardiometabolic health in Latinx, and its downstream effects on risk for multiple chronic diseases. The DREAM randomized controlled trial will evaluate the effect of a community health worker-delivered multidimensional sleep health intervention on multiple domains of cardiometabolic health in middle-aged to older Latinx men and women. Culturally adapted sleep health interventions may elucidate scalable and sustainable contextual behavioral approaches to improve cardiometabolic health and extend healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which transplants communicate with the recipient’s immune cells is required for development of better therapies to prevent or treat rejection of transplanted tissues and organs, including cardiac allografts. Recent studies have shown that allografts release donor antigens and likely immune-stimulatory signals through small extracellular vesicles that travel to graft-draining lymphoid tissues, where the vesicles elicit the anti-donor immune response that causes transplant rejection. Our application proposes to unveil in mouse transplantation models and a in a clinical translational model of humanized mice, how graft extracellular vesicles communicate with the recipient’s immune cells in lymphoid tissues, which will provide answers to old questions in the field of transplantation and new grounds for development of novel therapeutic approaches against transplant rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells have been a breakthrough in personalized cancer treatment; however, this therapy is not effective for many patients. Preliminary findings suggest that the epigenetic modifier TET2 is involved in controlling T cell fate and function; thus, I propose to investigate TET2 to identify strategies to improve CART cell efficacy in response to tumor challenge. By investigating the mechanisms and extent to which TET2 modulates antitumor T cell function, this research has the potential to improve patient responses to CAR T cell therapy as well as illuminate more general mechanisms by which DNA modifying enzymes alter the epigenetic landscape to regulate gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop new soft, tip-extending robotic catheters with shape control that have the potential to increase access to endovascular procedures by enabling navigation of vessels that can currently only be performed by a small number of specialists. Our approach represents a fundamentally di↵erent method of movement through the vasculature compared to typical manual and robotic methods that rely on axial loading of semi-rigid catheters, and our approach has the potential to improve safety and e↵ectiveness of endovascular surgical procedures. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to improve outcomes and ultimately increase access to high-quality minimally invasive surgical procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative People with type 1 diabetes have difficulty managing their glucose levels, especially during the daytime in response to carbohydrate intake; persistently elevated glucose levels can lead to dangerous, poor overall health outcomes including retinopathy, neuropathy, and nephropathy. We will develop a new dual hormone (insulin and pramlintide), fully automated closed loop system that can automatically detect meals and dose in response to these meals. By combining the slowed gastric emptying and suppression of endogenous glucose production that pramlintide provides with a meal detection algorithm, we expect to translate a fully automated closed loop system with minimal patient burden that can achieve substantial improvements in glycemic control both during the evening and during the day.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: The University of Kentucky Division of Regulatory Services (UKDRS) achieved full implementation and conformance to the Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS) in August of 2019. Moving forward, UKDRS requests continued funding support to continue full conformance with the AFRPS, to maintain an integrated animal feed safety system, and to advance the cooperative agreement with FDA. It is the goal of the UKDRS to be an effective component of an integrated animal feed safety system within the United States. Multiple activities will be supported through this project including continued funding for our AFRPS Coordinator, training, travel, feed sampling activity, conducting complaint investigations, and conducting animal feed manufacturer inspections.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The University of Kentucky Division of Regulatory Services (UKDRS) continued development of a risk-based Animal Feed Inspection Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: RELEVANCE There are long-standing disparities in adherence to medications and health outcomes in patients with multiple chronic conditions. This project will apply a “design with justice” process to refine a multicomponent adherence intervention targeting combined adherence to medications prescribed for breast cancer and cardiovascular disease. If successful, we will have developed an adherence intervention that can be adapted to improve adherence to other chronic conditions in a scalable and equitable manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Narrative Worldwide, cervical cancer remains one of the most common malignancies in women, particularly in those who are HIV-infected. The core objective of this application is to better elucidate the natural history of human papillomavirus infection and the development of cervical cancer in HIV-infected women. These include to clarify the cofactors involved in carcinogenesis, the persistence and progression of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) after local therapies, and to identify new viral and cellular biomarkers that will ultimately assist in screening, triage and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE The CHURCH Trial aims to reduce disparities in Colorectal Cancer (CRC) screening and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors linked to increased risk of CRC. This cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) will employ Community Health Workers (CHWs) in a cohort of 22 African American churches in New York City. We will assess CRC screening uptake (Primary Outcome) and dietary inflammation score (DIS) and Life Simple-7 scores (Secondary Outcomes) at 6- and 12-months post-intervention and conduct a mixed-methods process evaluation to assess multi-level facilitators and barriers of screening uptake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The project presents a new approach to studying mammalian brain development. The proposal is to apply modern molecular tools and new behavioural assays in a mouse-sized marsupial that is born at stage 18 (equivalent to human seven-week gestation) and develops further in their mother's pouch. Longitudinal studies in this model will provide unprecedented access to study the functional and behavioural outcomes of fetal disruptions to circuitry and could be applied to test therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because preschool-age irritability that persists into school-age predicts lifespan mental disorder and poorer functional outcomes, identifying the neural mechanisms by which children persist vs. remit in irritability is paramount to intervene in the earliest phase of the clinical cascade. Our overall goal is to identify reward- and inhibition-related neural pathways that characterize persistence vs. remission of early childhood irritability and may be targets for future novel preventive efforts. Our project is significant because it will pave the way for precision medicine for irritability: providing the right treatment (based on neural mechanisms) to the right people (children who will persist in irritability), at the right time (preschool age, before irritability problems worsen).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant post-transcriptional modification of eukaryotic mRNAs. In vitro studies have demonstrated that m6A modification influences all fundamental aspects of mRNA metabolism, but its in vivo functions in mammalian physiology remain elusive. The role of m6A mRNA methylation in innate immunity, particularly in macrophage activation, is completely unknown. In this application we will investigate the mechanism whereby macrophage m6A mRNA methylation regulates innate immunity in the context of acute inflammatory stress (i.e. sepsis).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative HIV-infected women have a higher risk of persistent high-risk HPV infection leading to higher rates of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 2/3. The standard of care for CIN2/3 is loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP). However, there is a gap in our understanding of recurrent CIN 2/3. This study proposes to increase our understanding of recurrent CIN2/3 in order to decide the best treatment for this recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Recognizing that high-risk HPVs cause cervical cancer, and HIV can accelerate its development and progression, we will compare clinical screening examinations to collected biologic samples in order to quantify expression of functional biomarkers and identify HPV through typing and sequencing. These biomarkers represent the dysregulation human papillomavirus and HIV cause in their hosts; as such, by determining the expression and association of these biomarkers with clinical disease, and the virologic fingerprint of high-risk HPV found in Kenya and Uganda, we will create a roadmap to discriminate between women with greater risk for HPV-associated precancerous lesions, both with and without HIV co-infection.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Narrative: Texas Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards Maintenance and Preventive Controls Initiative During the next 5 years, OTSC will more fully integrate AFRPS through a number of activities including exploring how the preventive controls for animal food regulations could be incorporated into Texas Commercial Feed Rules, building a more robust facility risk ranking matrix and analysis platform, expanding audits to focus on PCAF and CGMP inspections, utilizing feed-related illnesses or death data in the risk ranking matrix, continue to evaluate industry compliance through the enforcement matrix, and incorporating Laboratory Flexible Funding Model program samples into the OTSC annual plan of work. OTSC will expand the number of qualified field investigators who can perform PCAF inspections by seven who will be supported by a Preventive Control Qualified Field Inspection Trainer and Auditor and offer new outreach programs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Texas Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards Maintenance and Preventive Controls Initiative

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Funding provided through this Cooperative Agreement will allow the New Mexico Department of Agriculture to continue to develop and refine the Produce Safety program to reach the objectives of the FDA Produce Safety Rule. Such alignment necessitates a significant investment to successfully develop and implement a multi-faceted administrative program in support of the Produce Safety Rule. This grant opportunity provides New Mexico the resources necessary to advance efforts for a viable, aligned regulatory program contributing to a reduction of foodborne illness hazards and a nationally integrated food safety system.

PROJECT_TITLE: Path B Enhancement of NM Department of Agriculture's Produce Safety Program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetics is the study of how the information governing traits of an organism is decoded, how this information is stably passed on between generations, and how variant traits, including altered appearance, behaviors, birth defects, or disease states, arise. Studying the functions of genes, the control of their expression, and the effects of genetic variation give practical insights into how normal development and health are established and maintained, and how changes in gene function and expression contribute to congenital defects, aging, the origins of cancer, and the basis of many diseases. The goal of this Genetics Training Program is to give a diverse set of outstanding predoctoral researchers a broad education in genetics, intensive training in the process of performing and evaluating research in a rigorous and ethical manner, and mentorship and support of their development as productive members of society who apply their training in ethics, inclusiveness, and genetics during their careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project will install lights along the bathroom or entry way doorframe of persons with Alzheimer's disease or related dementias who reside in assisted living, which are intended to promote postural stability and reduce nighttime falls. Given that a pilot study found a 34% reduction in falls due to the novel lighting intervention, this pragmatic passive lighting system has the potential to reduce falls and related sequelae for countless persons with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, and to become a new standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  This work validates and implements a novel imaging approach for quantitative SPECT imaging of alpha particle radiotherapies. Using computational models, physical phantoms and in a first-in-man study in patients for initial feasibility, we validate our extensive pilot data to derive quantitative activity uptake values of low count producing radiotherapies. The proposal will provide the first quantitative assessment of uptake at lesions and in radiosensitive background organs that has great significance for optimizing patient treatment approaches with alpha particle therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: There is a pressing clinical need to develop new strategies to both encourage and accelerate axon  regeneration in the peripheral and central nervous systems; however, we need to understand the  molecular mechanisms underlying promotion of axonal growth to maximize therapeutic benefits and  minimize potential negative effects. This proposal exploits a previously unrecognized mechanism  that limits rates of axon growth by suppressing translation of stored mRNAs, and we will determine  how broadly this mechanism applies to different neural injuries and mechanisms underlying this axon  growth promotion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistance is becoming a significant problem in human health and infections that were once routinely treated are now resistant to our arsenal of clinically-approved antibiotics. Consequently, the need for new antibiotics has never been greater. This project will utilize integrated genomic, bioinformatic and chemical approaches for accessing and developing new antimicrobial agents from a completely new and unstudied resource, the halophilic microorganisms isolated from the hypersaline environment of the Great Salt Lake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Vaccines are a major tool to prevent infection, yet many who receive hepatitis B vaccination do not respond and are not protected. The goal of this proposal is to understand the qualities of the T and B cell responses that enable early prediction of who might have a weak vaccine response by focusing on the immune cells relevant to the antibody response, in order to decipher mechanisms that can be addressed with future vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a devastating hematopoietic malignancy that is fatal for most of the patients who develop this disease. In this proposal, we will develop and analyze comprehensive genomic, epigenomic, and proteomic databases using samples from AML patients, and genetically defined mouse models with common AML initiating events. The long-term goal of this project is to use these datasets to develop effective, mechanistically-driven therapies directed against the initiating mutations of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rare but incurable disease that ultimately leads to death. In the proposed study, we will investigate the role of mitochondrial dysfunction (MD) in 1) impaired pulmonary angiogenesis, 2) pulmonary artery obliteration, and 3) right ventricle (RV) hypertrophy/dysfunction, all critical components of the complex pathogenesis of PAH. We will investigate novel molecular mechanisms involved in the downstream pathogenic effects initiated by MD and test several therapeutic strategies that showed efficient protection in preliminary studies, including an ability to reverse RV hypertrophy, the primary reason for PAH patients’ death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in the length or location of the axon initial segment in neurons has been implicated in many neurodegenerative conditions including type 2 diabetes. This application will uncover the role of endoplasmic reticulum stress in type 2 diabetes induced AIS shortening and cognitive impairment while training a future physician scientist. Completion of the proposed research will impact public health by providing important fundamental knowledge of the pathophysiology of diabetic encephalopathy that can be used in future studies to develop treatments for the patients living with these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ST. JUDE CHILDREN'S RESEARCH HOSPITAL GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES, LLC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein MCL-1 frequently occurs in both solid tumors and hematological malignances, which has inspired the use of small-molecule inhibitors of MCL-1 in clinical trials. MCL-1 has two distinct isoforms –– one that localizes to the outer mitochondrial membrane where it performs its canonical anti- apoptotic function and one that resides in the mitochondrial matrix where it regulates mitochondrial homeostasis through unknown mechanisms. This proposal aims to provide mechanistic insights into the non-apoptotic roles of mitochondrial matrix-localized MCL-1 and will shed light on the potential consequences of using MCL-1 inhibitors for clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The buildup of fat or lipids in the liver contributes to the progression of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD). We have discovered a protein, A-kinase anchoring protein (AKAP12), that interacts with proteins involved in controlling lipid content in the liver. Our proposal aims at investigating how the interactions of AKAP12 with these proteins can be preserved to prevent lipid accumulation and thereby control liver damage during ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative I will develop an experimental pipeline that is broadly applicable to study the molecular mechanism of regulation and activation of membrane/membrane-associated proteins in the context of their endogenous environment, by extracting them while retaining an annular ring of their local protein and lipid interactome (native nanodiscs). These native nanodiscs can be used in several biophysical and biochemical analyses to understand the structural and functional organization, spatially-enriched endogenous proteomic and lipidomic environments, and ultimately bioactivity of target membrane proteins embedded in them. I propose to apply this pipeline and downstream analyses to investigate (1) a small, clinically relevant GTPase that is a hallmark oncogene, and (2) a receptor tyrosine kinase family that is critical for neuronal survival and development and plays a crucial role in pain perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative  In food allergies responses, the immune system reacts inappropriately towards food antigens resulting in inflammation and in the severe cases, death. We are designing biodegradable, biocompatible particles loaded with food allergens that tolerate such antigens, without inducing immune suppression, while maintaining the ability of the immune system to respond to pathogenic challenges. This innovative approach has far reaching implications for decreasing specific immune responses, such as the many forms of allergies or the rejection of transplanted cells in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative- Overall Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) suffer from repeated cycles of relaxation of airway muscles during sleep, resulting in closing of the airway, and inability to breath (apnea), followed by arousal, opening the airway, breathing, and then falling back asleep. These cycles can occur hundreds of times per night and result in sleep fragmentation, daytime sleepiness and cognitive impairment, and predispose to diabetes, high blood pressure, heart attack, and stroke. We are studying the brain circuits that are activated by apnea, in an effort to identify drugs that can prevent the airway from closing and to eliminate the repetitive awakenings, and the consequent cognitive, cardiovascular and metabolic problems in patients with OSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health-related social needs, particularly food insecurity, housing instability, and transportation barriers, affect over 6 million people with type 2 diabetes mellitus, are associated with poor clinical. The proposed research program will significantly advance our understanding of how best to address health-related social needs in the context of diabetes management by testing longitudinal relationships between health-related social needs and diabetes outcomes, evaluating on-going health-related social needs interventions, and learning best practices for future interventions to adopt. This research program has the potential to improve health and reduce the impact of health-related social needs among individuals with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE An individual’s biological sex impacts their ability to repair tissue and maintain homeostasis. This proposal will utilize biomaterial technologies to interrogate sex differences in tissue repair by decoupling cell microenvironment and estrogen signaling to determine the role of each parameter independently on tissue repair using mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs). This work will have broad implications for the design, development, and implementation of biomaterial therapies tailored to a patient’s sex to promote tissue repair, regeneration, and homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The American Heart Association estimates that, in 2022, about 720,000 Americans will have a first coronary event and 335,000 will have a recurrent event, of which, approximately 87% are ischemic (thrombotic). Anti- thrombotic therapy reduces the risk of recurrent ischemic events at the cost of a greater incidence of bleeding complications thus necessitating an effective precision tool that can guide individualized therapy to manage this risk assessment. This proposal will address this need by establishing sensitivity, specificity, and reproducibility of the Prolocor prototype commercial assay – high platelet FcγRIIa expression – as a diagnostic tool for determination of thrombotic/ischemic risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dengue and Zika viruses are globally emerging infectious diseases. Development of a vaccine that provides broad protection against the four Dengue virus serotypes has been technically challenging. A single effective vaccine against both Dengue and Zika viruses is highly desirable. We employ innovative protein engineering approaches to develop subunit vaccines based on key neutralizing epitopes of the Dengue and Zika envelope glycoproteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mechanisms that Govern Cardiomyocyte Proliferation and Remuscularization following Ventricular Injury Program Overall The studies comprising this Program Project Grant application will examine mechanisms whereby CMs reenter the cell cycle and new strategies to remuscularize the heart with postinfarction LV remodeling. Project 1 will identify the CM cell-cycle regulators that are activated by MI in one-day-old pigs and construct human cardiac muscle patches (hCMP) of unprecedented clinically relevant dimensions from layers of proliferating hiPSC-CMs with activated cell cycle regulators, and other cardiac cells, and will determine whether the identified factors and hCMPs can remuscularize the hearts of adult pigs after MI; Project 2 will use genetic strategies, viral vectors, and modified RNAs to investigate members of the Sonic Hedgehog signaling pathway including: Gli1 and Sox4, which have already been shown to induce proliferation in cultured CMs, can also promote CM proliferation in the injured hearts of adult mice and pigs, and studies will examine the capacity of the master regulator, Etv2, to promote neovascularization to repair the injured hearts of adult mice and pigs; Project 3 will use gain and loss of function in mice and pigs to determine the role of oxygen metabolism in regulation of cardiomyocyte cell cycle. The central objective of this PPG proposal is to remuscularize the injured ventricle from “within,” by promoting endogenous CM proliferation, and from “outside,” by transplanting functionally mature hCMPs that are primed for in vivo CM proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  (Project 1)  Endogenous and Exogenous Mechanisms that Promote Myocardial Remuscularization in Postinfarction LV Remodeling  The molecular and cellular basis for the progressive heart failure is the result of the inability of damaged and apoptotic myocytes to be replaced. The central objective of this proposal is to “turn back the clock” of myocyte cell cycle for myocardial regeneration. The Specific Aims (SA) are SA1: fate mapping and identifying the key regulators that promote cell-cycle activity in the hearts of early neonatal pigs after myocardial injury; SA2a: engineering hCMPs containing CMs that are capable of proliferating and characterized by previously unattainable size and thickness that are functionally mature and primed for in-vivo vascularization; and SA2b: evaluating the effectiveness of our hCMP constructs for myocardial recovery and remuscularization in a large- animal (swine) model of myocardial injury with the state-of-the-art techniques of optical mapping in combination with the 3-dimensional intramural cardiac mapping to delineate potential arrhythmia mechanisms over the entire heart.

PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is common and deadly. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients living with both advanced peripheral arterial disease (“critical limb ischemia”) and end-stage renal disease have high rates of mortality and limb loss. Patients with both conditions are common, treatments are resource-intensive, and decision-making is nuanced and yet there are no rigorous data on outcomes and no guidelines on care. This project aims to determine national treatment outcomes and factors affecting treatment selection, and to help create clinical care guidelines and identify research priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to identify needed chemical probes as well as potential prototype drugs that inhibit the exonuclease 1 (EXO1) enzyme involved in DNA repair. A novel EXO1 inhibitor will allow us to provide a critical tool to test how DNA repair works inside normal and cancerous cells, and will also help towards the development of a new drug that blocks these pathways in cancer cells. This will be important for studying and treating breast cancer and other cancers in which these pathways are altered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Cell death and inflammation are two central elements in the pathogenesis liver fibrosis, the central process leading to increased morbidity and mortality secondary to liver disease. We have uncovered a novel role of the NLRP3 inflammasome as a modulator of hepatic stellate cell biology, the key liver cell involved in activation of the fibrotic program and liver fibrosis. The studies in this application will focus on targeting novel mechanisms of inflammation, cell death, and fibrogenesis to inhibit or reverse the development of fibrosis in order to prevent morbidity and mortality associated with progressive liver disease.

PHR: The proposed experiments will not only define the molecular and physiological signatures of dystonia but will do so in context of biological sex, a known risk factor for the disorder but one that is largely unexplored. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The project proposes to combine several state-of-the-art technologies to understand the molecular control of bone-specialized blood vessel formation and remodeling during long bone defect repair and reconstruction. Using the obtained knowledge, our goal is to create a biomimetic periosteum with growth factor releasing property, simulating the highly organized and functional periosteum for reconstruction of large bone defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysine specific demethylase-1 (LSD1) is an epigenetic regulator of gene transcription involved in the pathophysiology of elevated blood pressure and likely renal damage in Blacks. This project investigates whether Blacks who carry the risk allele for LSD1 (rs587168) have greater evidence of renal damage and whether a genetically driven anti-hypertensive approach proves superior in controlling blood pressure and mitigating renal injury. The findings of these investigations may lead to a new approach in treating a subset (~30%) of the essential hypertension population (Black LSD1 risk allele hypertensives) and have the potential to reduce Black- White disparities in health outcomes secondary to poor blood pressure control.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative A deficit in our understanding of the molecular defects that underlie the development of heart disease represents a critical barrier to the design and implementation of therapeutics that more fully address its molecular pathogenesis. The present application will identify a novel mechanism that potentially regulates the endogenous antioxidant and inflammatory responses of the heart in diabetes. These findings are expected to provide new targets for intervention and lead to the development of innovative therapies for a leading cause of mortality and morbidity.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differences in the responses of mosquito populations to malaria interventions, both within species and between species, may impact intervention effectiveness, yet important aspects of this diversity remain poorly characterized. In this study, I will use a combination of field and laboratory data together with advanced computational methods to examine differences in vector competence between mosquito species and migration patterns within mosquito species. The results will improve our understanding of the current persistence of malaria parasite transmission.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Infertility is a disease that affects 1 in 10 women in the United States and a leading cause of female infertility is having an abnormal number of chromosomes (aneuploidy) in eggs and embryos. This proposal investigates genetic variants found in women who are predisposed to having more chromosomally abnormal eggs than would be typical for their age group. The outcome of this work, knowledge of the effect of these genetic variants on egg development, will lay the foundation for development of genetic tests that could help women and their physicians to non-invasively assess predisposition to having chromosomally abnormal eggs and thus infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Influenza viruses are rapidly mutating RNA viruses and the causative agent of about one billion annual respiratory virus infections and 500,000 deaths worldwide, and viral resistance has developed to all available treatment options. We recently generated novel and compelling evidence that influenza virus infection triggers lung innate immune cells to suppress helpful antiviral immune responses, perhaps to reduce harmful immuno- pathology. We propose to determine the mechanisms regulating viral clearance versus lung pathology, as this knowledge will provide the rationale to develop novel therapeutics augmenting the antiviral immune response while preventing detrimental immunopathology, greatly improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Developmental Language Disorder (DLD) in adulthood is severely under-researched, and the consequences are dire: adults with DLD are less likely to seek post-secondary education4 , have extended bouts of unemployment, and higher rates of depression. The current project takes a fundamental step toward illuminating what underlies these profoundly negative effects by characterizing language abilities and mechanisms that explain language deficits in adults with DLD. The proposed research will lay the groundwork for legislative efforts to provide service provision for adults with DLD, and prompt applied research to improve the transition from youth to adulthood in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our group has developed cutting-edge technology - “on-the-fly” time-resolved cryo-electron microscopy (EM) - that, for the first time, facilitates visualization of novel protein conformations, including those transiently occurring during catalysis. In this application, we will apply this technology to address biologically and clinically relevant knowledge gaps in HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT) biology, with specific focus on the incorporation of nucleosides and nucleoside inhibitors, nucleoside inhibitor resistance, and the relationship between DNA synthesis and ribonuclease H activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

Our proposal seeks to understand the effectiveness and equity of federal emergency funding that directly supports nursing home staffing, with an overall goal to develop a framework by which to guide future nursing home responses to public health emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The ever-increasing production and use of chemicals, potable water reuse, climate change, growing populations, and intensive farming are factors that drive drinking water contamination, which has been linked with epidemic diseases such as cancer, obesity, and impaired mental functions, and has particularly hazardous effects on fetal, infant, and child health. My studies will combine state-of-the-art high-resolution mass spectrometry with innovative high-throughput in vivo and in vitro effect-directed analyses to expand the coverage of current drinking water monitoring strategies, together with a novel statistical mediation approach to assess host microbiota interactions in the zebrafish model, as affected by drinking water contaminants. I will develop effective and scalable assessment tools for the identification and prioritization of complex contaminant mixtures in urban and rural drinking water; establish the foundation for the discovery of biomarkers of exposure to drinking water contaminants in future studies; and facilitate the translation of our results to study participants across Oregon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will reveal a critical molecular switch that controls the senescence-associated secretory phenotype, an important tumor regulating mechanism. These molecular insights may provide the scientific rationale to ultimately develop novel strategies to overcome therapy relapse and/or resistance for cancers including ovarian cancer, the most lethal gynecological malignancy in the United States. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burden of human illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity is an established risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes (T2D), yet for reasons that are unclear, many obese individuals will never develop T2D as a result of increased adiposity. This study will identify molecular factors associated with T2D in obese individuals and characterize what happens to these factors following T2D remission and substantial weight loss from bariatric surgery. Results of this work may lead to an improved understanding of how T2D develops and identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: RORgt+ lymphocytes (gdT17 cells and ILC3s) play an important role in infection/inflammation and mitochondrial control of immunity beyond ATP generation has emerged as a new concept. The proposed experiments will provide novel insights into the molecular mechanisms of action of mitochondrial transcription factor A (Tfam), a key factor for mitochondrial respiration, in regulation of RORgt+ cell maintenance and function and its role in regulation of small intestine tissue remodeling, infection and inflammation. Better understanding of RORgt+ lymphocyte biology regulated by Tfam may eventually provide novel means to treat human disease (e.g., helminth infection and inflammatory bowel disease).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a genetic heart disease that leads to thickening of the heart muscle, ultimately reducing cardiac function and potentially inducing sudden cardiac death in young adults. Almost 50% of HCM-linked, pathogenic mutations occur in the sarcomeric protein cardiac myosin binding protein C (cMyBP- C), however, the mechanism by which cMyBP-C mutations lead to HCM is largely unknown, limiting the development of targeted therapeutics that could treat the underlying effects of the mutation instead of simply lessening the symptoms. To address this, this project aims to study both the structure-function and energetic pathophysiological mechanisms that underly a highly penetrant HCM-inducing mutation in cMyBP-C utilizing HCM patient derived cardiomyocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunosuppression within patient tumors poses a critical challenge that limits the breadth and efficacy of cancer  immunotherapies designed to establish antitumor immunity. Delivery of molecular signals that activate innate  immunity is a powerful strategy to transform tumors to an immunoactivated state and stimulate cytotoxic T-cell  responses that control tumor growth. This research proposal will leverage a new family of immune signaling  proteins to discover novel molecules for stimulating antitumor immunity in human cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a devastating disease with no cure. Early identification of heart disease onset and progression in DMD patients using novel imaging biomarkers and deep learning will help to improve length and quality of life in this vulnerable population. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs) is freely available software that provides image registration, segmentation, and other basic biomedical image processing and analysis functionality. ANTs has contributed to thousands of published studies spanning many areas of research, including in key public health areas such as cancer and heart, lung, and brain disease. This project will ensure that ANTs is available to basic scientists and clinical researchers in the future, as well as implement innovations that will allow even more investigators to take advantage of the tool's capabilities in their scientific work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Macrolides and aminoglycosides comprise the frontline treatment against M. abscessus. However induction of resistance pathways either by exposure to the drugs or the host environment result in a poor treatment efficacy. In this proposal we will undertake an in- depth structure-function characterization of two novel resistance pathways involving the ribosome associated proteins- HflX and ABCFs. This work will also provide the first demonstration of changes in bacteria within the host environment that result in increased resistance to aminoglycosides.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: HIV-1 can persist in T cells and macrophages but there are few strategies being explored to eliminate infected macrophages. The proposed studies are based on our preliminary observations that HIV-1 activity can be irreversibly blocked by chemicals that suppress cellular gene expression. We will explore the mechanism by which these inhibitors block HIV so as to pave the way for a novel strategy to block the persistence of HIV-1 in some anatomic compartments of HIV-1 infected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative:  Vision loss exacts an enormous toll on individuals and on society, and progress has been slow in developing therapies for restoring vision in the blind. To greatly reduce the time required to develop effective cures for blindness, we have a new way of imaging the retina that can provide information about whether retinal cells benefit from new therapeutic approaches. This novel functional imaging technique will be applied to evaluate photoreceptor replacement therapy in the fovea, the area of the retina that mediates high quality vision. Success in restoring vision at this location will provide strong evidence that this type of therapy could restore usable vision in patients and regenerative therapies should move rapidly into clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified unique macrophage responses in humans who naturally resist Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection despite heavy exposure. The aims of this proposal are to uncover proteomic determinants of this macrophage resistance and define the underlying cellular mechanisms and Mtb-host protein interactions. Once key protective pathways are identified, they can be augmented with targeted host-directed therapies that improve killing of drug-sensitive and drug-resistant Mtb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles (EVs) hold great promise as biomarkers for minimally-invasive disease detection, but most current EV analysis methods are low-throughput and require EV pre-isolation steps, which can greatly decrease their reproducibility, and are impractical for clinical use. To address this problem, we have developed a rapid, robust, and isolation-free nanoparticle-based EV assay that directly quantitates tumor-derived EVs in serum or plasma samples to diagnose pancreatic cancer (PC), including early disease, with high reproducibility, sensitivity and specificity. This proposal is designed to automate and further improve the accuracy and reproducibility of our novel assay with a single vesicle resultion for PC diagnosis, and perform analytical validation of this assay according to Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute guidelines in CLIA- certified laboratory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative – Roswell Park Ovarian Cancer SPORE The Roswell Park Ovarian Cancer SPORE brings together laboratory and clinical investigators with the collective focus to tackle some of the most important translational research challenges in ovarian cancer. The three Individual Research Projects focus on innovative approaches to generate effective anti-tumor immunity and overcome multiple mechanisms of tumor immune escape. Our SPORE fosters the recruitment of new ideas and investigators through the Career Enhancement Program and Developmental Research Program, promotes the integrated utilization of four shared resource cores, and encourages active engagement of patient advocates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL – NARRATIVE This program project will bring together leaders in disease-focused neuroscience, systems biology and bioinformatics to address important problems in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) research that are both unresolved and understudied. The proposed experiments could elucidate molecular and cellular mechanisms of neural network dysfunction and cognitive decline in AD and promote the development of novel therapeutic strategies to block them. Sharing the highly diverse data sets we will generate and disseminating the novel integrative approaches we plan to develop for their analysis could also enhance the progress of many other groups working in AD research or biomedicine in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Restrictive eating disorders are a debilitating and life-threatening group of psychiatric illness characterized by restricted dietary intake. At present, there are no studies investigating the potential neurobiological impacts dietary restriction may have on the developing brain, particularly white matter, which does not mature until the third decade of life. Using state-of-the-art image processing tools and already collected data, this proposal will generate important and currently unknown information about the interplay between brain development and severe dietary restriction, which may assist in the identification of critical developmental periods of increased vulnerability or optimal periods for clinical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters utilize many mechanisms to ensure efficient nutrient uptake while regulating toxins. Regulatory domains are not conserved in all ABC importers, indicating more variability in ABC importers beyond the current Type I/II classification scheme (Rice, Park et al., 2014). The proposed research will define the mechanism in which transporters can shut off transport based on environmental cues, which is a critical, but often overlooked, aspect to understanding basic nutrient uptake and survival mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The Immunogenomics Core will be responsible for accurate and reproducible monitoring of immune and genomic changes in peripheral blood and tumor microenvironment in patients with ovarian cancer. The Immunogenomics Core will leverage the expertise of Center for Immunotherapy and Shared Resources at Roswell Park. Centralization and standardization of the performance of the immunologic and genomic assays will facilitate head-to-head comparisons of the immune/genomic signatures and changes being induced by cutting-edge immunotherapies in the Roswell Park Ovarian Cancer SPORE. The Immunogenomics Core personnel will work closely with Individual Research Project Leaders and Core Directors for accomplishing the projects and discovering novel findings through the immunologic and genomic data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Robust computational methods can be used to greatly reduce the time and funds in environmental health research and help environmental scientists and toxicologists to prioritize the future directions of research. This novel matrix completion algorithm called Coupled Matrix/Tensor-Matrix Completion (CM/TMC) and Coupled Matrix/Tensor-Tensor Completion (CM/TTC) has great potential in discovering molecular targets and target tissues of environmental exposures. The outcome of the proposed study will assist in filling the data gap between the novel chemicals produced annually and the toxicity assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Coloboma, a developmental defect in eye structure characterized by a hole or cleft in the eye, is a condition estimated to occur in ~1:10,000 live births, and a significant cause of blindness worldwide. It results from disrupted development of a specific structure in the eye called the choroid (or optic) fissure; however, despite its importance, we have a poor understanding of the crucial initial step of choroid fissure formation at the cellular or molecular level. Here, we aim to determine the mechanisms governing choroid fissure formation and its regulation by signaling pathways, tissue-tissue interactions, and metabolism, using the small freshwater teleost fish Danio rerio (zebrafish), and a combination of live microscopy, computational methods, and molecular genetics.

PHR: Project Narrative: Clostridium difficile infections (CDI) have been categorized as one of the top 5 “urgent” public health threats by CDC. Host factors including genetics and immune mediators are key regulators of CDI pathogenesis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall objective of this project is to reprogram the ovarian tumor microenvironment (TME) with an “armed” oncolytic vaccinia virus for local delivery of a CXCR4 antagonist (OVV-CXCR4-A-Fc) to minimize the potential for high rates of systemic toxicities. We will determine whether intraperitoneal OVV-CXCR4-A-Fc is safe and triggers a transformation of the TME from tolerogenic to immunogenic in a first-in-human clinical trial focused on patients with platinum resistant/refractory EOC. We plan to integrate immunologic and proteogenomic profiles to provide an exhaustive characterization of the interface between the TME and the immune system in order to examine the molecular mechanisms that generate functionally distinct effector/memory T cells against shared antigens, neoantigens and how vascular checkpoints regulate tumor-specific T cell trafficking into the ovarian TME.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Stable maintenance of telomeres is critical to preserve genomic integrity, and studies have found that defects in protein complexes that ensure telomere maintenance, could lead to various human diseases including cancer. The overall goal of this project is to provide detailed knowledge of the mechanisms that allow conserved shelterin and CST complexes to ensure stable maintenance of telomeres by controlling DNA replication at telomeres and attenuating DNA damage responses. Since proteins involved in telomere maintenance and DNA damage responses are very well conserved between fission yeast and humans, we expect our findings to help guide future studies of telomere regulation mechanisms in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Synovial sarcoma (SS) is an aggressive malignancy driven by the SS18-SSX oncofusion that is refractory to chemotherapy leading to a high mortality rate. Here, we identify a remarkable therapeutic vulnerability to both genetic and pharmaceutical disruption of the SUMOylation pathway, including with the in-clinic SUMOylation inhibitor TAK-981, that is dependent on SS18-SSX. We provide data the mechanistic basis is through deSUMOylation-mediated re-distribution of BAF complexes leading to DNA damage, cell death, and frank tumor regressions in mouse models of SS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance The Developmental Research Program of an NCI SPORE is the incubator of the cutting-edge, potentially paradigm-shifting research that will be tested to become the next generation standard-of-care. The Roswell Park Ovarian Cancer SPORE will provide two complementary advantages as a mechanism for supporting translational research: 1) a constructive review process provided by the Executive Committee, which facilitates evolution of hypotheses, and 2) a rapid review and award procedure which allows immediate and flexible funding of new ideas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic alcohol consumption leads to hepatocellular injury, fat accumulation, and liver inflammation and sometimes leads to liver cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma. We have found that changes in phosphorylation status of UBC9, an essential enzyme required for SUMOylation (post-translational modification), is associated with altered inflammatory response and liver function. Our proposal aims to investigate how phospho UBC9 modifications in liver macrophages can be controlled and may provide a therapeutic target for alcoholic associated liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE Acute pancreatitis is an acute inflammatory process resulting in damage to pancreatic parenchyma with an annual incidence ranging from 5 to 45 cases per 100,000 persons. Recent studies indicate that   30-40% of patients develop diabetes mellitus or impaired glucose tolerance within three to four years of  even a single episode of acute pancreatitis   the autoantibodies associated with Type 1 diabetes (T1D) are found in people with a history of  pancreatitis, indicating that pancreatitis-related diabetes poses long-term burden and significant risk of  comorbidities as frequently as in other patients with diabetes The Type 1 Diabetes in Acute Pancreatitis Consortium (T1DAPC) will investigate the incidence, etiology, and pathophysiology of diabetes following acute pancreatitis with an emphasis on the auto-immune processes that result in T1D as well as the incidence, time course, and relationship to pancreatitis severity, the roles of pancreatitis etiology, genetic and genomic risk factors, environmental and biological factors, and potential biomarkers for the development of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: MicroRNA isoforms (isomiRs), tRNA-derived fragments (tRFs), and rRNA-derived fragments (rRFs) are important classes of regulatory RNAs most of whose members are uncharacterized. To help researchers study these molecules, we will build a) specialized tools to correctly mine these small RNAs from human and mouse deep sequencing data, and b) specialized databases to organize, and make available, knowledge about these small RNAs that we will distill from tens of thousands of NIH SRA datasets. To help researchers keep up with the fast pace of the field, we will also build c) a “hands-free” system that will update these databases by automatically mining each month newly-added datasets to NIH’s SRA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The ultimate long-term objective of the Career Enhancement Program (CEP) is to develop novel ways to reduce the burden of ovarian cancer, through translational, clinical, and population-based research. A prerequisite for achieving this objective is a continual influx of newly independent researchers with interest, experience, and expertise in ovarian cancer. The CEP of the Roswell Park Ovarian Cancer SPORE will support the career development of the next generation of translational ovarian cancer researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: ZFX is a transcriptional activator with large effects on the human transcriptome in multiple cell lines. Despite preliminary data from the Farnham Lab that demonstrates almost complete overlap of ZFX binding to thousands of promoter regions in several cell lines, the sets of genes activated by ZFX are surprisingly unique to each cell line. To determine how ZFX regulates cell type-specific gene expression while binding to the same set of promoters, this proposal will identify ZFX protein binding partners and other transcription factors bound to promoters of ZFX regulated genes in multiple cell lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop and demonstrate the clinical imaging performance of high resolution, clinical time-of- flight positron emission tomography detectors that achieve 100 ps FWHM coincidence time resolution. This detector technology can facilitate PET systems with substantially enhanced reconstructed image signal-to-noise ratio and contrast-to-noise ratio, which can be exploited to improve lesion detection and quantification, or greatly reduce injected radiation dose or scan duration, making PET more accurate, safe, and practical across a wide variety of imaging studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project aims to provide a commercial alternative to the Neuropixels probe and associated electronics that will enable feature parity in recording capability, but also be usable in scientific applications currently unaddressed by the existing Neuropixels probe. By coupling the proposed probe to powerful datalogging electronics, we will offer a way to scale channel counts to above 3000 without the need for cables between the animal and a computer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The protein BRAF is a key switch in a signaling pathway that controls cell growth and proliferation, and mutations that activate this switch are a frequent cause of cancer. We are working to understand how this switch works, how cancer drugs that target it and its partner MEK interact with it, and how cancer-causing mutations alter its structure. In the long term, our work should lead to more effective and less toxic treatments for cancers caused by BRAF mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed intergenerational research study would increase our understanding of cognitive resilience in late-life older adults, and examines the relation of midlife biomarkers of brain and cardiovascular health in offspring and cognitive resilience in parent. Preserving cognitive resilience through early, mid, and late life biomarkers is a topic of high public health significance, since designing of preventive strategies through life course can offer stronger potential for slowing or reducing the risk of developing cognitive loss in late-life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  African Americans have the highest incidence and mortality rates from colorectal cancer over any other major racial or ethnic group in the United States, but it is not fully clear what drives the aggressiveness of disease in these patients. We discovered that pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL6 are persistently released during inflammation and directly impede specific repair processes centered around the DNA mismatch repair protein MSH3 such that subsequent mutations within DNA accumulate, and associates with poor patient outcome. We aim to understand the contribution of MSH3 dysfunction to the poor survival outcome of African American colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American (AA) older adults have more than twice the prevalence of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) compared to non-Latinx White older adults; thus, there are more AA caregivers. Formal care (paid care services for older adults usually associated with a healthcare institution) is essential to the treatment and management of ADRD and associated with better quality of life, and African American adult daughters, the largest group of caregivers of African American persons living with dementia, must navigate decision-making related to formal care. This project seeks to identify key factors associated with the formal care decision-making process for African American persons living with ADRD and to improve the quality of life of African American parent-adult daughter dementia dyads by designing and testing a structured prototype intervention to support these dyads and their families with the formal care decision-making process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adult drinkers with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), compared to their non-ADHD peers, are at increased risk for experiencing alcohol-related problems and developing alcohol use disorder (AUD). The proposed project assesses individuals both in the laboratory and in their own natural environment to study associations between executive functioning, craving, and alcohol-related behaviors over a one-year period to inform etiological models underlying ADHD and AUD. Findings will identify opportunities to tailor prevention and intervention approaches aimed to reduce alcohol-related risks for young adults with ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by protein aggregation and cognitive decline and patients with Alzheimer’s disease can experience neuropsychiatric symptoms including hallucinations and delusions, which are also characteristic of schizophrenia. We recently discovered that protein insolubility is increased in a subset of postmortem brains from patients with schizophrenia and therefore, hypothesize that the overlapping proteomic changes associated with protein aggregation in schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s disease will implicate genes and proteins, and thus specific cellular processes, associated with neuropsychiatric symptoms and psychosis observed in Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal may provide evidence that the mechanisms responsible for aggregation in schizophrenia contribute to the neuropsychiatric symptoms that occur in Alzheimer’s disease, particularly those observed in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The spread of tuberculosis is a global health crisis leading to over one million deaths annually. The global burden of tuberculosis is a threat to the health of all Americans, and directly relevant to the mission of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, given the easy transmission of the disease through the air and the emergence of drug resistant strains that are difficult to treat. Moreover, there exists an increasing population of Americans with enhanced susceptibility to TB due to factors associated with compromised immune systems, including: HIV infection, the use of anti-rejection and anti-inflammatory drugs, as well as natural decreases in immunity associated with an aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This application tackles the novel idea that coupling between KCC3a, pendrin, and NCC maintains potassium and acid-base balance in response to the consumption of alkaline and potassium-rich foods but drives potassium wasting in alkalosis. KCC3a-mediated potassium secretion will be reduced in distal nephron-specific KCC3a knockout mice but increased in distal nephron-driven pendrin knockout animals, and in Gitelman syndrome. Consumption of an alkaline-rich diet stimulates phosphorylation of the Na-Cl cotransporter, NCC, leading to increased Na+ and Cl- reabsorption and maximizing the secretion of K+ through KCC3a.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with chronic pancreatitis experience severely debilitating pain. Unfortunately, only ~25% of these chronic pancreatitis patients achieve meaningful pain relief with current standard of care for pain management, highlighting the urgent need for objective biomarkers to stratify pain type and pain severity. This proposal is designed to discover (Specific Aims 1 and 2) and validate (Specific Aims 3 and 4) such pain biomarkers in plasma and/or urine, which have the potential to significantly improve pain management for chronic pancreatitis patients so that the majority can enjoy a meaningful pain relief.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a laser-engraved wearable molecular sensing patch that can continuously monitor a panel of key cardiometabolic biomarkers. This project spans across chemistry, engineering, cardiovascular medicine, and clinical nutrition to explore the novel method of monitoring key cardiometabolic biomarkers in patients with pre-diabetes and obesity. This platform has the potential to modulate the patient-specific cardiometabolic risk factors in the pre-diabetic and obese individuals, with translational significance to mitigate clinical manifestation of major adverse cardiovascular events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Infections caused by the opportunistic fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus range from a chronic inflammatory and fibrotic process known as chronic pulmonary aspergillus to an acute life-threatening pneumonia known as invasive aspergillosis. This study will employ newly developed model systems to understand how lung fibroblasts coordinate with the immune system to protect the lung from this infection, with the long-term goal of using this information as a foundation to develop novel treatment strategies to enhance pulmonary defenses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prospective memory failures represent a significant public health issue because medicine nonadherence is associated with poor treatment outcomes, disease progression, and billions of dollars annually in avoidable direct healthcare costs. Education and instruction on how to offload prospective memory intentions onto the environment rather than relying one’s own memory ability will improve healthcare outcomes and quality of living for older adults. This work aligns with NIH’s mission because offloading represents an easy and effective method to reduce prospective memory errors in healthy older adults and individuals with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Capsular polysaccharides (CPSs), by which most pathogenic bacterial surfaces are decorated, have been used as the main components of glycoconjugate vaccines against bacterial diseases in clinical practice worldwide. Due to inadequate understanding of how the immune system interacts with these complex vaccines, their design and production have often been empirical, yielding poorly characterized, heterogeneous, and variably immunogenic vaccines, with poor immune responses in high-risk populations such as the elderly and patients with weak immune systems. Through the mechanistic knowledge attained in this project, we propose to establish a new-generation vaccine development platform to produce knowledge-based vaccines that are target-specific, structurally designed, highly immunogenic, and protective, produced at much lower cost and allowing much wider use on a global scale than current vaccines to control or eliminate a wide variety of infectious diseases.

PHR: When we encounter a virus or a tumor in our body, we use specialized sensors to detect these threats. Our goal is to understand how DNA-sensing works and control it to improve immune health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The study of persons with or at-risk for autosomal dominant Alzheimer’s disease (ADAD) had made significant contributions to our understanding of AD in general. In collaboration with investigators in Mexico, we have identified a large number of families there with this otherwise rare form of AD. Therefore, there is a substantial population of persons with or at-risk for ADAD available for and motivated to participate in research. To date, little systematic research has been performed in this population in Mexico, in part due to a lack of resources and infrastructure. In this project we propose to facilitate research in ADAD in Jalisco state by providing the technology for research and clinical genetics as well as funding and training to develop a cohort that will prospectively be followed using standardized clinical and cognitive measures, enabling additional research studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The education, mentoring, and training of underrepresented groups for professional research careers in the biomedical sciences through the North County San Diego Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program will serve to advance the goal of NIGMS to increase diversity in the scientific workforce. The Bridges initiative is designed to assist Bridges Scholars in transferring to a four-year institution, completing their B.S. degrees, and eventually obtaining careers in the biomedical sciences. These underrepresented community members are not represented in the professional research workforce of the nation and consequently we lose a significant talent that can make meaningful contributions to the health and quality of life of the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most lethal hematological malignancy, and alternatives to chemotherapy such as differentiation therapy are greatly needed. We recently found that the H3K9 histone acetyltransferase KAT6A cooperates with the H3K9ac reader protein ENL to promote stemness and proliferation in AML. Here, we aim to determine the molecular mechanisms by which KAT6A and ENL cooperate to drive leukemogenic gene expression programs, and to identify the genetic subtypes of AML that are most sensitive to KAT6A inhibition.
