IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Auditory verbal hallucinations (AVH) are major causes of distress and disability in psychosis. Emerging evidence suggests that some people who experience AVH are capable of developing voluntary control over their onset and offset, but very little is known about the mechanisms underlying this ability. We propose a coordinated approach to understanding voluntary control over AVH, with the goal of generating knowledge capable of rapid translation into new treatments based on enhancing control over AVH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne muscular dystrophy heart failure is ubiquitous and is now the leading cause of death, however there is limited mechanistic understanding of disease progression and currently no effective treatments to prevent or limit the progression. This proposal is designed to train Dr. Forum Kamdar in cardiac tissue engineering and extracellular matrix dynamics, to aid in her transition to an independently funded physician-scientist in neuromuscular cardiomyopathy. In this project, she will develop a 3D heart model using dystrophic heart cells derived from patient skin cells, using advanced physical technology to understand the molecular basis of this devastating disease, and to test ideas for developing effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease is a significant public health concern, and identifying opportunities for early intervention is critical to developing effective interventional strategies. Diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DW- MRI) has shown that subtle changes in cerebral white matter are prognostic for disease progression, but quantitative interpretation of these measures in existing large studies is confounded by protocol, scanner, and site effects. This study will translate recent advances in harmonization of DW-MRI to improve specificity of white matter microarchitecture metrics (aim 1), translate connectivity analyses (aim 2) for existing large Alzheimer’s Disease neuroimaging studies, and enable robust single subject inference for abnormality detection and prognosis (aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TRIM5 proteins constitute a powerful innate cellular defense machinery against important human pathogens such as HIV- 1 and other retroviruses. The continuing goal of this R01 project is to understand the detailed molecular mechanisms by which TRIM5 recognizes and inhibits HIV-1. Our studies on this naturally-evolved antiviral enriches understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of HIV-1 replication, and also identifies viral vulnerabilities that can be exploited to fight HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lesions that arise in the genome compromise its integrity and need to be properly repaired since loss of repair or misrepair leads to chromosome loss and genomic rearrangements, which are associated with many tumor types, in particular of the breast and ovary. Defects in repair also sensitize tumors to particular therapies. This project addresses fundamental questions about the tumor suppressors BRCA2 and RAD51 paralogs, which are involved in homology-direct repair, and addresses underexplored areas of research, including how cells lose the intact copy of genes, how mutant genes revert, and DNA repair in the fallopian tube.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: Project Narrative This application brings together the clinical strengths and large acute pancreatitis patient population of Virginia Mason Medical Center's Digestive Disease Institute and Benaroya Research Institute's expertise in autoimmunity and type 1 diabetes to understand the incidence, clinical course, and potential mechanisms of autoimmune mediated diabetes after acute pancreatitis. The theme of this application is that knowledge gained from studying autoimmune diabetes after pancreatitis will provide key insights as to mechanisms of disease in typical type 1 diabetes. Our underlying hypothesis is that failure or delay in resolving the immune response to tissue injury in genetically at risk individuals leads to engagement of the adaptive immune system, antigen spreading, and ongoing beta cell destruction in type 1 diabetes occurring both naturally and post-acute pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) improves the pain from end-stage osteoarthritis, but the substantial swelling early after surgery is theorized to lead to decreases in strength and physical function. We will explore whether an inelastic, adjustable compression garment reduces swelling and improves strength and function compared to the current standard of care (elastic compression). This study has high potential to transform current postsurgical management and rehabilitation recommendations after TKA with a simple, cost-effective intervention and to improve the health of the millions of individuals who will undergo TKA annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative       The proposed studies in adults with SAPHO and chronic nonbacterial osteomyelitis (SAPHO- CNO), an  understudied and disabling autoinflammatory disease, will significantly advance our understanding of how  patient- reported symptoms and advanced imaging with whole- body MRI could improve disease activity  assessments in the clinic, and will help identify potentially modifiable factors and symptom groups that are  predictive of developing severe bone damage for earlier intervention. The discovery of mutations in  inflammatory pathway genes may shed light on the spectrum of disease symptoms and complications in  SAPHO- CNO, and these findings could be used to guide future clinical trials testing different treatment  strategies in adult patients. Future research directions stemming from this work include the development of a  patient- reported disease activity tool for use in the clinic, identification of novel biomarkers for earlier diagnosis,  and deepening our understanding of long- term disease complications and responses to treatment, all of which  would directly benefit adults with SAPHO- CNO.

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH. The loss of striated muscle mass and function in patients with a rare neuromuscular disease significantly compromises quality of life and is often fatal. The proposed studies will develop novel adeno-associated viral capsids for improving the efficacy and safety of muscle-focused gene therapeutics. Ultimately, these capsids will be incorporated into a gene therapy program for inclusion body myositis and Duchenne muscular dystrophy and will be licensed to other commercial programs targeting these and other neuromuscular disease indications.

PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in the United States and worldwide. In this proposal, we combine whole genome sequence analysis of COPD and related pulmonary function traits with comprehensive gene expression and proteomic measures from multi-ethnic cohorts including African American, Hispanic and European ancestry participants. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Clinical and Translational Science Collaborative (CTSC) at Case Western Reserve University has created a solid foundation to enhance the quantity and quality of Clinical and Translational Science (CTS) among its partners. This proposal brings an enhanced focus on health equity reflected in the theme Catalyzing Linkages to Equity in Health (CLE Health) and expands its reach to research professionals and special populations through the addition of two new partners to join our core group of five independent collaborators. The CTSC’s collaborative interdisciplinary environment coalesces around a shared mission to improve health and eliminate disparities by 1) facilitating and expediting innovation in multicenter CTS, 2) supporting novel approaches that address gaps in CTS, and 3) training a robust, diverse CTS workforce at all levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Many patients with retinal degenerative diseases are eventually suffering vision loss due to no therapeutic treatment. While electrode-based retinal prostheses have been most widely used to restore photoreceptor functions, they face many hurdles when this method is applied to a high-resolution neural stimulation. Based on direct optical stimulation, the proposed thermal stimulator will simplify its safe implementation and significantly improve spatial and temporal resolution over the current methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative. This proposal is relevant to public health and will have an important positive impact because there are currently no therapeutic strategies designed to alleviate negative affective states and cognitive dysfunction that accompany alcohol dependence and withdrawal and persist into protracted abstinence to promote excessive alcohol consumption. The benefits of the current proposal are the inducible and conditional genetic as well as chemogenetic manipulation of kappa-opioid receptor systems in combination with comprehensive behavioral phenotyping in motivational, negative affective and executive function domains. This research should provide a foundation for personalized therapeutics designed to reduce maladaptive behavioral regulation in alcohol dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Achilles tendinopathy is a painful condition that does not fully resolve in 20-60% of patients following conservative treatment. In this ancillary study, we will determine how calf muscle coordination impacts tendon disease and patient outcomes using our innovative high-density surface electromyography interface. By determining the mechanistic link between muscle coordination and outcomes, we will generate critical new evidence to support personalized rehabilitation protocols aimed at improving outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The present study aims to determine whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) over the left angular gyrus (AG) along with verbal learning of semantically related and unrelated word lists will improve word list learning performance in two variants of probable Alzheimer’s disease (AD): typical, amnesia-predominant AD and atypical, aphasia-predominant AD (also known as logopenic variant primary progressive aphasia with AD pathology). In addition, we will evaluate two brain mechanisms of tDCS-effects, i.e., whether functional connectivity between the stimulated area and its connections in the default mode network, and the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA modulate word-list learning in the two AD variants. Finally we will identify neural, cognitive and physiological predictors such as sleep, that may moderate tDCS effects, in order to be able to identify responders to tDCS and optimize neuromodulatory treatments of neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (OVERALL P01) Dengue is a major public health problem worldwide and is complicated by four distinct yet cross-reactive sero- types, such that prior infection with one serotype can either protect or enhance a subsequent infection with a different serotype – posing a major challenge for vaccine development. This Program Project addresses the critical need to improve understanding of the human antibody and B and T cell response to dengue virus infection and vaccination and to identify immune correlates of protection and pathogenesis. To this end, our consortium of world-renowned investigators is applying state-of-the-art immunological methods in the context of long-term ongoing clinical and epidemiological studies of dengue as well as studies of vaccinated populations and human challenge models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Finding and addressing sex and gender differences in effective health care research and treatment are critical actions toward the goal of improving the health and wellbeing of all Americans. To achieve this goal, the UK BIRCWH seeks to continue training and supporting our next generation of academic researchers to recognize sex and gender differences in conditions that disproportionately affect Kentuckians. In this training and mentoring program for emerging researchers, we focus on 3 health concerns that disproportionately affect Appalachian Kentuckians: Substance use, violence against women, and lifespan changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (UC BERKELEY, CORE A) Dengue is a major public health problem worldwide, and it is critical to improve our understanding of the human immune response to dengue virus infection and what elements of immune response are associated with protection from or susceptibility to disease. This Program Project should help define immune correlates of protection and contribute to efforts to successfully develop an effective tetravalent dengue vaccine that confers long-term immunity to all four DENV serotypes. The Administrative Core (Core A) will provide crucial coordination functions to ensure regular and fluid exchange of ideas, data, and reagents between P01 investigators as well as compliance with NIH and local institutional requirements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: CORE B Dengue is a viral disease with a high global burden, yet currently, the only licensed dengue vaccine cannot be widely administered because it can increase severity of dengue disease. Comprehensive characterization of the protective and pathogenic features of immunity in the context of natural dengue and dengue vaccines is urgently needed to improve control efforts. Core B will support this Program Project, which directly addresses these themes, by: epidemiological and phylogenetic analyses of natural infection and vaccine cohorts; experimental designs, sampling strategies, and analysis plans for within and cross-Project studies; and application of statistical and machine learning approaches to interpret high-dimensional adaptive immune characteristics and to identify immune correlates of protection, pathogenesis, and dynamics of anti-dengue virus immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (CORE C) Dengue is a major health problem worldwide and is complicated by 4 distinct yet cross-reactive serotypes. This P01 addresses the critical need to improve understanding of human B and T cell responses to dengue virus infection and vaccination and identify immune correlates of protection from or susceptibility to disease. Core C will continue the Nicaraguan Pediatric Dengue Cohort Study to provide key samples from natural repeat dengue virus infections. It will also ensure efficient management and distribution of samples and data from the cohort and other human subject studies to Projects, collaborate on the selection of samples, and maintain P01 databases and the project workspace.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (PROJECT 1) Dengue is a major public health problem worldwide and is complicated by the existence of four antigenically distinct yet immunologically cross-reactive serotypes. It is critical for development and evaluation of dengue vaccines, treatments and diagnostics to improve our understanding of the human immune response to dengue virus infection and identify what elements of the antibody/B cell response are associated with protection from or enhancement of disease. This project uses state-of-the-art immunological methods in the clinical and epidemiological context of our long-term studies in Nicaragua and synergizes extensively with the other Projects and Cores in the P01.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project develops a revolutionary new two-photon laser scanning microscope system based on a technological breakthrough called Light Beads Microscopy. This microscope will enable unparalleled in vivo calcium imaging of individual neurons nearly simultaneously in one or more regions of the mouse cerebral cortex, only limited by the rate that it takes the tags to fluoresce, meaning wide volumes of the brain can be recorded within the same time it would take a conventional two-photon microscope to capture a much smaller number of neurons. As a result, new avenues of neuroscience research will become possible providing promise for the elucidation of novel biological mechanisms associated with human brain disease, and ultimately the basis for developing novel therapies to prevent and treat complex brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) are living longer due to the success of anti-HIV therapy to suppress HIV, yet they still experience neurocognitive impairments that are worsened in many cases by chronic cocaine abuse, and vice versa. The mechanism for such HIV/cocaine-induced brain dysfunction is not entirely clear; but a component that should be carefully looked at is the aberrant effects of the anti-HIV therapeutic medicines themselves on the brain, which are similar to those induced by HIV and cocaine. In this study, we will determine the effects of such anti-HIV medicines on the brain neurons in the context of HIV/AIDS and cocaine abuse (both cause neurocognitive impairments), and will do so in small animal models of them; and that can potentially shed some lights on the role of anti-HIV drugs in the brain, elucidate how HIV, anti-HIV drugs and cocaine alter the brain function, and provide a novel therapeutic approach for treating HIV/AIDS and cocaine addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The human B cell and antibody response to dengue virus infection is correlated with protection against disease, but the molecular features of this response are incompletely understood. In this project, we will follow up results from the initial Program Project and isolate and characterize in depth human monoclonal antibodies to dengue virus from subjects in the Nicaraguan Pediatric Dengue Cohort study, working in close collaboration with other Projects and Cores. The studies will use serotype-specific and cross-reactive antibody clones and advanced next generation deep sequencing immune repertoire techniques to determine the molecular, structural and genetic basis for the human antibody response to dengue.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI) therapy, while can successfully treat certain cancers, leads to various autoimmune toxicity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A better grasp of the factors that influence Mycobacterium tuberculosis permeation will enhance drug discovery efforts for a pathogen of enormous public health significance. We posit that there are multiple barriers to molecule entry, and that the relative importance of each depends on M. tuberculosis cell envelope structure, molecule structure, and the ultimate destination of the molecule within the cell. To test this model, we will develop and deploy methods that are high-throughput and report arrival to specific cell compartments, in turn enabling us to comprehensively query both bacterial and molecular determinants of M. tuberculosis impermeability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will establish the feasibility, acceptability and credibility of a novel live video dyadic resiliency intervention, Resilient Together for Dementia (RT-D), aimed at preventing chronic emotional distress and preserving quality of life among dyads at risk for chronic emotional distress early after a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease or a related dementia (ADRD). Both persons living with dementia (PWDs) and their spousal care-partners experience high levels of clinically elevated emotional distress, which can become chronic without treatment and negatively impact the health, quality of life, communication, and care-planning of both partners. A tailored dyadic intervention delivered over live video to this at risk population during the window of opportunity when PWDs can participate has the potential to prevent chronic emotional distress and preserve quality of life for PWDs and their loved ones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of death in the US, and treatment options are limited—we lack methods to assess a patient’s risk of deterioration at admission. An improved ability to classify patients early after injury will allow us to identify those who may benefit from aggressive interventions versus those who can safely be observed. The goal of the proposed project is to develop and assess a series of predictive models incorporating immune proteins from peripheral blood to aid in the prediction of which patients are at low-risk for complications and poor outcome after TBI.

PHR: Project Narrative Public health relevance: This is project will develop and apply computational tools for analyzing large-scale data from genomic and complex disease studies to gain understanding the molecular mechanisms of complex diseases, Additionally, this project will develop novel risk prediction models to advance preventive medicine for complex diseases. Finally, the project will develop computational tools to aid improving reproducibility of biomedical research. All three aspects are fundamental in complex disease studies, where the knowledge will eventually lead to new and reliable treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Insulin degrading enzyme (IDE) is postulated to use large-scale motions between the N- and C-terminal domains to selectively unfold amyloid peptides, leading to necessary stabilization of the catalytic cleft prior to substrate degradation. We will use integrative structural approaches to better understand the molecular basis of substrate recognition and regulation of IDE. The success of our studies will allow us to selectively modulate the degradation of amyloid b and glucose regulating hormones through the development of innovative IDE-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Temperature is critical to all life activities and regulates biological processes at various levels. Cells not only detect temperature changes through their unique temperature-sensitive molecular machineries but also adapt with appropriate responses to maintain their inherent functions. Ability to create well-defined nanoarchitectures that can stimulate and detect these thermal interactions can lead to the development of powerful research tools to investigate basic biological processes and ultimately allow advanced therapeutics and diagnostic agents for treating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive muscle contraction and trauma often result in acute muscle injury, triggering the need for cellular repair. Defects in muscle repair contribute to and exacerbate chronic disorders like muscular dystrophy. The proposed studies will lead to an improved understanding of the mechanisms regulating muscle resealing and rebuilding, helping to guide therapeutic strategies aimed at improving muscle repair capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because substance use disorders (such as opioids, tobacco, and alcohol) are common, costly, and contribute to poor health outcomes. We are proposing the development of a method that helps researchers identify individuals with complex variations of these disorders in large data sets linked to genetic data in hopes of finding novel prevention and treatment interventions. The proposal is relevant to the National Institute on Drug Abuse’s emphasis on “…supporting and conducting basic and clinical research on drug use…and the underlying neurobiological…mechanisms involved.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE IDENTIFYING METABOLIC VULNERABILITIES IN LUNG CANCER Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide, and common therapy for both NSCLC and SCLC includes surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy. Many of the driver genes mutated in lung cancer are transcription factors and are difficult to target therapeutically and have been dubbed “undruggable”. Our goal in this application is to develop a deep molecular understanding of the metabolic pathways regulated by key drivers in lung cancer using sophisticated and novel mouse models of lung cancer, patient derived samples and organoids, and state-of-the-art approaches in the analysis of metabolites to identify metabolic vulnerabilities in lung cancer as potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT 1 NARRATIVE IDENTIFYING METABOLIC VULNERABILITIES REGULATED BY THE P53 FAMILY IN LUNG CANCER p53 is commonly mutated in human lung cancer, including lung adenocarcinoma, lung squamous cell carcinoma, and small cell lung cancer (SCLC), and is part of a family of genes, including p63 and p73, that interact extensively in human cancer. Project #1 will identify metabolic pathways utilizing novel mouse models of lung cancer with p53 gain of function and p63/p73 mutations found in human lung cancer, and cutting-edge metabolomics and genomics techniques to unveil novel therapeutic targets for lung tumors with p53 mutations or alterations in p63 and p73. Project #1 will also identify metabolic pathways regulated by p73, altered in 10% of human SCLC, a recalcitrant disease that lacks targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the WHO seasonal influenza epidemics causes 3-5 million illnesses and about half a million deaths each year, and a major cause of morbidity and mortality from influenza infection is caused by secondary infection with bacterial pathogens. This project focuses on the role of an innate immune cell subset, the macrophage, and in particular cell death responses in the overall ability to clear complex respiratory infections with minimal morbidity and mortality. This will allow us to better understand a fundamental concept of complex respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative There is a severe underrepresentation of African individuals in genetic studies of neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), including intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorders, and attention deficit disorder. We propose to address this inequity through the NeuroDev Kenya project, which aims to collect blood and clinical, medical and demographic data from 800 Kenyan children and adults with NDDs, as well as their parents, and age- and ancestry-matched unrelated controls. We will share all data (phenotypic and genetic) and materials (blood DNA) from the study, and integrate the project with extensive capacity building activities. NeuroDev will create a critical foundation for NDD genomics research in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE INVESTIGATING CYSTEINE ESSENTIALITY IN LUNG CANCER Cysteine plays a crucial role in cellular survival and proliferation by generating multiple functional biomolecules, but the factors influencing the cellular response to cysteine starvation are incompletely understood. We have found that lung cancer cells are dependent on exogenous cystine due to a lack of transsulfuration capacity, but exhibit a heterogeneous response to cystine limitation. This work will evaluate the influence of metabolic circuits, cellular genotype, and microenvironmental factors on cellular responses to cystine limitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progress in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) research will benefit from new tools for detecting behavioral changes that occur in early disease stages, when therapies are likely to be most effective at halting or reversing disease progression. We propose to develop a new AI-based method for detecting subtle behavioral changes in late- onset AD mouse models that lack clear behavioral impairments when tested with traditional behavioral approaches. The proposed research will contribute a new urgently-needed tool for understanding and measuring behavioral changes in AD and will increase the usefulness of mouse models of late-onset AD for the development of new therapies aimed at improving behavioral and cognitive health in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE ROLES AND MECHANISMS OF ACTION OF METABOLIC VULNERABILITIES OF SCLC To identify new therapeutic targets for small cell lung cancer (SCLC), a recalcitrant disease that lacks targeted therapies, we performed state-of-the-art mass spectrometry-based screens for SCLC-specific changes in the ATP binding proteome, expressed proteome, and the metabolome. We identified metabolic hubs that are selectively up-regulated in both treatment naïve and chemoresistant SCLC and showed that combined pharmacological inhibition or genetic loss of MCT lactate transporters and the PFKFB3 glycolytic enzyme provokes SCLC metabolic collapse, growth arrest and cell death. Using new and established mouse models of SCLC, patient-derived SCLC tumors and circulating tumor cells from SCLC patients, Project #3 will assess the roles of MCT transporters and PFKFB3 in controlling the metabolism, development and maintenance of SCLC, will test if co-targeting MCT and PFKFB3 delays or eliminates emergence of resistant disease, alone or when combined with standard-of-care chemotherapy, and will identify additional metabolic vulnerabilities of SCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is the second most common form of dementia and has unique symptoms that lead to more frequent hospital visits, shorter survival, and increased strain on family caregivers, yet no LBD-specific caregiver interventions exist. This study will determine whether a practical, LBD-specific educational intervention delivered by trained and experienced LBD caregiver peer mentors can (1) improve the wellbeing of current LBD caregivers and their care recipients, and (2) provide a successful framework for harnessing the knowledge of expert caregivers to support future caregivers in LBD and other dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this Phase II proposal is to develop a commercially viable wearable device as a forearm bracelet, for rapid, on-site testing for opioids and other narcotics with wireless alerts. We demonstrated the feasibility of this approach in Phase I. The Phase II effort will focus on further development and optimization to provide ultra-high sensitivity (ng/mL detection range), enhanced drug specificity, long-term durability, low power consumption, and cost-effective production. Upon completion of Phase II, 20 devices will have been produced and will be ready for commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT 4 NARRATIVE: METABOLIC AND FUNCTIONAL REPROGRAMMING OF  IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE MYELOPOIESIS IN LUNG TUMORS This application will identify an elusive metabolic mechanism centrally governing the function and expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) in lung tumors, which could significantly increase the efficacy of promising approaches for cancer immunotherapy. Specifically, information gathered from this effort is expected to: 1) provide insights into the metabolic signals underlying the tolerogenic polarization of MDSC in lung tumors; 2) set the foundation for the development of novel strategies to functionally reprogram myelopoiesis in cancer; and 3) enhance the effectiveness of major anti-cancer treatments including radio, chemo, and immunotherapy by transforming “cold” tumors into “hot” malignancies highly infiltrated by reactive T cells and reprogrammed immunogenic myeloid cells that sustain significant anti-tumor activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the only treatment option for the ~38 million people living with HIV. However, life- long adherence to ART is associated with neurological and neuropsychiatric side effects. Notably, the comorbid condition of cocaine use exacerbates these deficits. This proposal will assess the combined effects of HIV-1 integrase inhibitor-based antiretroviral therapy and chronic cocaine use on neuronal dysfunction and neuropsychiatric circuit reorganization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Childhood trauma exposure, particularly in the form of interpersonal violence, increases risk for alcohol use disorder (AUD), posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and their co-occurrence, perhaps through complex interactions of molecular genetic risk, and trauma-related disturbances in neural development; however, knowledge is limited in this area due to limitations of prior research, including lack of longitudinal data in multiple domains and reliance on outdated genetic designs. Using cutting-edge statistical genetics techniques and results from existing “big data” genome wide association studies, aggregate genetic risk scores indexing risk unique and common to these disorders will be integrated into sophisticated longitudinal analyses of adolescent and young adult neural connectivity and risk for adult AUD and PTSD. Results from this study will shed light on these important public health conditions and will yield important implications for prevention and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wnt5a-Ror signaling is one of the key cell-cell communication systems that controls embryonic tissue morphogenesis, and its dysregulation causes birth defects and cancer metastasis. We propose a multidisciplinary research program aimed to elucidate how the originating cells release Wnt5a signals, how the responding cells perceive and process these signals. Knowing the mechanisms underlying Wnt5a-Ror signaling will help us better understand the pathogenesis of the associated human diseases, thus facilitating the therapeutic development for cancers driven by aberrant Wnt5a-Ror signaling.

PHR: CORE 1 PROJECT NARRATIVE  ADMINISTRATIVE CORE The Administrative Core serves as the central node for all Projects and Cores of the Program Project Grant (PPG) with the overarching goal of providing resources and facilitating interactions between the laboratories involved. The Administrative Core has 3 goals: 1.) to provide administrative services including organization of meetings and annual retreats, 2.) to ensure robust integration of project and core activities with the highest level of scientific rigor and reproducibility of data, and 3.) to support internal and external resource and data sharing. These goals will be accomplished through the efforts of the leadership of the Core Leaders and two PhD level support staff, the Program Management Director and the Administrative Director.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Prepregnancy obesity predisposes affected offspring to adverse long-term health outcomes, including cognitive dysfunction; yet, the underlying pathophysiology remains unclear. Our interdisciplinary study in a mouse model for diet-induced obesity will test the two-part hypothesis that (1) Western diet-induced dysbiosis of the maternal gut microbiome is causally related to offspring neurocognitive dysfunction and (2) antenatal targeting of the maternal gut microbiome can improve offspring brain development and cognitive outcomes. Successful completion of the aims will reveal the impact of Western diet consumption on the structure and function of the maternal gut microbiome and microbially-derived metabolome during pregnancy, elucidate the molecular and neurophysiological mechanisms by which opportunistic pathogenic bacteria increased by Western diet consumption impair host cognitive function, and identify targeted modulation of the maternal gut microbiome as an innovative approach to improving cognitive health outcomes in children affected by maternal prepregnancy diet-induced obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a high-pressure freezing instrument with the buffer exchange capability (HPF-X) for time- resolved cryo-vitrification of cells and tissues with a goal to study ligand-induced biological processes at high spatiotemporal resolution. Biomedical applications of this technique include nanoscale imaging of rapid protein- protein interactions (e.g., receptor-effector coupling), post-translational modifications (e.g., phosphorylation), and protein-membrane dynamics (e.g., exo- and endocytosis). Our custom-built high-pressure freezer with the buffer exchange capability will allow full control, versatility, and potential for adoption and modification by other researchers based on their project needs, which cannot be achieved with off-the-shelf HPF instruments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proper assembly of membrane proteins as folded subunits or macromolecular complexes, is of critical importance to cellular physiology, yet we do not have a fundamental understanding of the physical reasons why membrane proteins assemble in the hydrophobic environment of the membrane. In this project, we are studying the equilibrium dimerization reaction of the CLC-ec1 Cl-/H+ antiporter as a model system to dissect the thermodynamic driving forces underlying membrane protein association in lipid bilayers. The results from this study will identify the molecular mechanisms for how protein sequence, lipid composition and general anesthetics modulate stability, and thereby lay down a physical foundation for the development of new strategies aimed at correcting stability defects in membrane protein folding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Multi-Tagger is an automated tool for assigning publication types and study designs to biomedical articles, preprints and manuscripts. We propose to develop Multi-Tagger 2.0, to handle a wider variety of study designs, articles, users and use cases, and to ensure that the data are disseminated in a form that is appropriate to each different type of user. These studies will indirectly impact on human health by greatly enhancing retrieval of relevant articles by a wide range of biomedical end-users, including groups studying the effectiveness of medical interventions, those studying preclinical animal models of human disease, and pharmaceutical companies developing new drug treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the process of photoreceptor development is crucial for revealing molecular mechanisms that cause inherited photoreceptor dystrophies as well as for proposing therapeutic approaches that aim to restore visual function via the regeneration of lost photoreceptors. While significant progress has been made in understanding the signaling cascades that regulate photoreceptor development, the role of epigenetic mechanisms in this process has been explored to a lesser degree. The objective of our study is to explore the role of the DNA demethylation pathway in photoreceptor normal and pathological development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herpesviruses are important human pathogens that can have devastating effects in neonates and immunocompromised individuals, yet there is no cure for any herpesvirus and treatment options are lacking. Here, I dissect the mechanism of an essential feature of the herpesviral lifecycle - viral genome packaging - by exploring the role of a unique accessory factor required for packaging and by developing an assay to monitor packaging in vitro. Detailed mechanistic insight is essential to understand the mechanism of current antiherpesviral drugs and to facilitate the identification of new targets for antivirals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Senescence of cancer cells is a common outcome of antitumoral therapies which can affect the functionality of T cells; still, it is unclear how senescence influences T cell function. In this project, I aim at dissecting how triggering of senescence in cancer cells promotes an antitumoral, T cell-mediated, immune response. The results of these studies will inform on how to potentiate conventional cancer therapies by favoring tumor immunosurveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development and function of the nervous system requires the establishment of exquisitely selective cellular interactions between neurons and supporting cells. The axonal endings of pain-sensing sensory neurons are wrapped by specific types of skin cells into structures called ensheathment channels, which are conserved from worms to mammals and thus likely play critical roles in the development and function of pain sensors. To better understand how epidermal ensheathment contributes to establishing and maintaining functional pain-sensing neurons, this proposal uses zebrafish larvae as an accessible model for studying how axons and skin cells recognize each other, how skin cells wrap around axons, and how ensheathment contributes to sensory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Resilience, defined as successful development and coping despite exposure to adversity, is primarily studied in high-income countries (HICs), which is problematic, as most children grow up in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) where they are at the greatest risk for profound adversity exposures. The proposed research addresses this critical knowledge gap regarding pathways towards resilience by combining sophisticated data analytic techniques applied to longitudinal multimodal brain imaging, high-dimensional behavioral assessments, and comprehensive defining of environmental exposures (both adverse and protective) from a well-established and deeply-characterized birth cohort of adolescence with significant adversity exposure living in Cape Town, South Africa. Here, we examine neuro-environmental pathways supporting adolescents’ emotion regulation behaviors with the goal of improving precision and inclusivity in recognizing and characterizing resilience to socio-economic, structural, health, and interpersonal adversities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposal seeks to understand the heterogeneity of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and how it might differentially control the microenvironment of functionally distinct brain regions. The results of this work will address fundamental questions about BBB differences in transport, metabolism, and signaling according to function, thus yielding critical knowledge about BBB dysfunction associated with neuropsychiatric diseases and aging. In addition, by specifically investigating the BBB role at the nucleus accumbens shell, we aim to study molecular mechanisms of addiction in hopes to uncover therapeutic targets for treatment or prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE: Chronic itch is a significant clinical problem, affecting nearly 10 to 20% of the general population and negatively impacts the quality of life and productivity of those affected. No universally effective treatments are available for chronic itch due to a lack of understanding of the mechanisms underlying the production and regulation of chronic itch. The current proposal aims to identify the cells and molecules involved in regulating the itch sensation in the skin in the hopes of finding novel drug targets for treating chronic itch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia is diagnosed in over half a million U.S. ED visits by older adults each year and has high mortality. Currently, emergency physicians lack the tools to reliably diagnose pneumonia and deliver life-saving care to the correct patients. This proposal seeks to improve diagnostic accuracy thereby improving patient care and outcomes by: investigating novel serum tests; deriving and piloting a new diagnostic pathway; and applying group concept mapping to prepare for successful validation and implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although significant progress has been made in developing new drugs in kidney cancer, there are no biomarkers to guide treatment decisions post-operatively in patients with localized kidney cancer. Majority patients, particularly those with high-risk features in their tumors relapse after surgery; therefore, making it necessary to develop a biomarker to help identify these patients as well as to guide treatment in the adjuvant setting. In this proposal, I will investigate strategies to identify novel transcriptomic and metallomic biomarkers of poor-risk kidney cancer, to determine if we can identify patients most likely to benefit from adjuvant therapies, minimize exposure of toxic drugs to those at low risk of recurrence and overall improve the outcomes of patients with kidney cancer.

PHR: This project will be a substantial contribution to public health by systematicallydeep annotating thefunction of new genes (NGs) in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. These systematic annotation results will be performed through ChimerAnno (a tool for functional annotation of human chimeric genes), FGviewer (a tool for visualizing multi-tiered functional features of fusion genes), NGeffector with DeepChIP (a tool for predicting NG downstream effectors with enhanced transcription factor binding site prediction with deep learning), DeepCLIP (a tool for providing evidence of origin of NGs for trans-splicing mechanism) and hBPAI (a tool for feature extraction of human new genes' breakpoint (BP)). The application of these approaches on all kinds of human BPs of new genes will be integrated into NewGeneDB, New Gene annotation Database. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding how long-lived protective immunity mediated by CD8 T cells is established and sustained in tissues is of significant importance to human health. Establishing residence in tissues requires adaptation of CD8 T cells to diverse and dynamic metabolic environments encountered in distinct organs. Defining the metabolic adaptations of CD8 T cells in specific tissue environments informs our understanding of how these cells protect against pathogens and tumors and maintain function at tissue barrier sites and informs the strategic design of therapeutic and protective vaccines to protect from infection and malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Alcohol researchers have long sought to disentangle the precise relationship between intoxication and sexual encounters. Examining the relationships between intoxication and sexual health have been important for public health researchers in developing effective prevention and intervention programs to counter a number of serious alcohol-related problems. In order to assist the development of more effective intervention programs, but also importantly further our understanding of the relational processes that are involved within these intoxicated sexual encounters, the aim of this qualitative research proposal is to identify and analyze the key elements operating by conducting in- depth qualitative interviews with 200 young adults (18-25).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (AD/ADRD) are the most common neurodegenerative disease of aging, affecting millions of Americans and increasing in prevalence each year. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human gut microbiome plays an important role in human health, yet the molecular mechanisms by which microbes interact at the cellular and ecosystem scale are largely unknown. This research program will develop a new framework to elucidate the genetic determinants that govern the behaviour of microbial communities across scales. Through genetic engineering of gut bacteria, we will investigate the collective ecological and metabolic phenomenon that emerge from the interactions of individual microbial traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will characterize genetic variants that alter immune function and thereby decrease the risk that a tuberculosis-infected patient will progress to active symptoms, which can inform the development of therapeutic and vaccine strategies that augment resilience against progression. Elucidating how immune phenotypes are altered by genetic background will also refine our understanding of basic immune physiology and shed greater functional light on the genetic component of risk for other infectious and inflammatory illnesses. Finally, this work will produce a powerful novel method for association testing in single-cell datasets—Covarying Neighborhood Analysis—that represents a marked advancement in our ability to characterize disease states, therapeutic mechanisms, and basic physiology by defining with unprecedented flexibility and granularity the cell populations whose abundance is altered by any phenotype of interest.

PHR: The KL2 Core is an essential component of the Georgia Clinical & Translational Science Alliance (Georgia  CTSA) and designed to respond to the critical needs of training a new and diverse generation of clinical and  translational research (CTR) investigators who will carry out high impact research and translate new  discoveries to improve health for diverse communities. The KL2 Core also provides critical CTR training infrastructure at the Georgia CSTA partner  institutions through support of a Master of Science in Clinical Research (MSCR) program and a Certificate  Program in Translational Research (CPTR).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: Defective DNA repair is a double-edged sword. It leads to increased genomic instability and accelerates tumor development and progression, but it also renders tumors more vulnerable to anti-cancer treatments, including inhibitors targeting immune checkpoints and cell cycle checkpoints. We propose to investigate essential DNA damage repair genes and pathways both in vitro and in vivo with the goal of exploiting these pathways and defects for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) are at a higher risk for thrombosis and vascular complications after any vascular procedure, which can be potentially devastating. Over the last decade, our work identified uremic solutes (compounds that accumulate in the blood under compromised kidney function) as potent thrombogenic solutes. The current proposal delineates new mediators of this complication, and successful completion of this project may yield new biomarkers for thrombosis in CKD patients at risk, and may uncover new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project seeks to use a combination functional lung imaging and inflammatory biomarker assessment to more comprehensively interrogate the lung's response to bronchoscopic volumetric reduction as a treatment for late-stage emphysema. Through a better understanding of the alterations in ventilation, perfusion, and inflammatory burden that this intervention precipitates-and which are assumed to be the primary mechanisms through which it improves lung function-we will also address the discrepancy which many patients experience between the achievement of clinically significant functional gains and the failure to experience a commensurately improved quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 2. PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is a critical developmental period in which alcohol use and sexual violence often first occur, and sex disparities in these outcomes emerge. Through the proposed K01 career development training and research, the candidate will build expertise in social and developmental psychology, adolescent alcohol epidemiology, and advanced statistical techniques to examine the ways in which gender expression and related socialization processes operate within adolescent social networks and explain the onset of and sex-disparities in alcohol use and sexual violence. Findings will identify the mechanisms underlying these interconnected public health problems in adolescence and will inform prevention efforts to address alcohol use disorders and sexual re- victimization during adulthood, ultimately reducing the considerable social, economic, and medical costs associated with these public health crises to the US healthcare system and society.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to meet future public health needs of the nation this educational training program provides exceptional research training to MD, MD Ph.D or PhD trainees in adult and pediatric rheumatology and immunology to study autoimmunity and rheumatic diseases. It will train the next generation of translational and clinical research investigators to take advantage of new breakthroughs in understanding disease pathophysiology and the resultant potential for development of innovative therapy in both adult and pediatric rheumatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The molecular mechanisms underlying how the alcohol intoxication experience is remembered as rewarding are poorly understood. This work will reveal a transcriptional pathway through which alcohol alters gene expression, altering reward circuit dynamics. This will further inform how alcohol co-opts the brain’s natural reward circuits to result in alcohol cravings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Lewy body dementia (LBD), encompassing dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and Parkinson disease dementia (PDD), is the second most common cause of dementia, and both are caused by abnormal aggregation and accumulation of a protein, α-synuclein (aSyn), in the brain. At present, advances in the treatment of these conditions are critically hampered by the lack of non-invasive, inexpensive biomarkers that can provide accurate diagnostic and prognostic information. This project will assess aSyn in punch biopsies of the skin, using new “seeding assay” diagnostic methods performed by two independent laboratories.

PHR: NRG Oncology NCORP research will significantly impact cancer prevention, screening, control and care delivery, and bring state-of-the-art treatment trials to community centers where most cancer treatments are delivered. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. How mammalian peripheral sensory neurons encode cold remains poorly defined, despite the essential nature of cold detection to human survival and the prevalence of cold hypersensitivity in several pain etiologies. The goal of this proposal is to systematically and unequivocally define a new role for the voltage- gated sodium channel, NaV1.1, in physiological cold sensing and cold allodynia using approaches that span ion channel biophysics and mouse behavior. Results from this study will deepen our basic understanding of thermal- sensing mechanisms and how they are highjacked during pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Distress (e.g., depression and anxiety symptoms) in older adults with cancer and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) represent a significant public health burden for them and their caregivers in terms of impaired quality of life, that impact their coping abilities and communication (e.g., future health care planning). The COPE+ intervention is a promising mental health and communication treatment for older adults with cancer and MCI, and their caregivers. The proposed study will conduct a pilot study to test a brief (6-week), tablet- based, personalized intervention that includes family caregivers, in this at-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand and interrogate the differences in skeletal muscle progenitor cells (SMPCs) compared to adult satellite cells (SCs) both molecularly and functionally to enable generation of more regenerative cells from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs). Generation of the most regenerative SMPC or SC-like cells from hPSCs could improve our ability to model muscle diseases in a dish and have the potential for use in personalized cell replacement therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We previously showed that the mechanical properties of tissues are an emergent property, arising only from the when the components of the tissue (cells and the extracellular matrix) are combined. The overall goal of this competing renewal proposal is to expand our understanding of complex tissue mechanics to specifically include viscosity, to define how cells, the matrix, and forces acting on tissues combine to determine tissue mechanics, and to determine the impact of these mechanics on cell behavior. The model tissue in this proposal, as in previous project periods, is the normal, fibrotic, and cirrhotic liver.

PHR: Project Narrative The Geisinger Cancer Institute NCI Community Oncology Research Program (Geisinger Cancer Institute NCORP) builds upon a strong foundation of cancer research from our rich experience with National Cancer Institute (NCI) collaborations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Claudin channels define paracellular flux of ions and small molecules across the tight junction, and their dysregulation can contribute to many intestinal diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. We will use in silico, in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo models and first-in-class claudin cation channel blockers to study mechanisms of claudin-2 and -15 controlled cation flux. We anticipate that our findings will provide insight into mechanisms of nutrient transport and diarrhea in the gastrointestinal tract and potentially lead to novel drugs to benefit human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is an inflammatory skin condition that causes chronic ulcers and profoundly affects quality of life and mortality. PG is the prototypical misdiagnosed wound which can lead to mismanagement such as unnecessary treatment with intravenous antibiotics or unneeded surgical procedures (including limb amputations). The aims of this project are to determine the best diagnostic approach for PG, and to unravel real- world treatment outcomes for current therapeutic approaches, redefining the therapeutic landscape of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Physical frailty and cognitive impairment are prevalent age-related conditions that often co-occur and are strongly correlated with depression in older adults. Studies on the burden and development of these two conditions in nursing home residents are limited, and the findings on the underlying mechanisms between physical frailty and cognitive impairment and the role of depression and antidepressants on their progression are inconsistent. In the dissertation phase of this project, the candidate will characterize the prevalence, heterogeneous clinical presentation, and trajectories of physical frailty and cognitive impairment in older U.S. nursing home residents; for the post-doctoral phase, the candidate will elucidate the relationship between physical frailty and cognitive impairment as well as explore the impact of depressive symptoms and antidepressants in the development of both conditions in U.S. community-dwelling older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall purpose of this project is to understand the mechanism by which the cholecystokinin (CCK) B- receptor is activated in liver injury and NASH and how this activation increases the risk for hepatocellular cancer (HCC). Epigenetic regulation of the CCK receptor will be studied and cross-talk with chemokine receptors. Several murine models of liver injury and a transgenic CCK-BR-knockout mouse model will be used to investigate whether stem cells or liver progenitor cells express the CCK-BR and if a CCK-receptor antagonist can decrease the risk of HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Outcomes in schizophrenia (SZ) may improve significantly with early intervention as opposed to reversal of morbidity, however, all currently available antipsychotics are effective on similar pathways, treatment failure or partial response is common. Therefore, there is a critical need to identify new biological processes that contribute to the pathology early in the illness. Proposed studies aim to identify a specific bioenergetic abnormality in early SZ and establish a mechanism that can be targeted for the treatment of this abnormality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health departments increasingly use predictive models to make decisions on the best policies to reduce infectious diseases in the United States. Yet there is limited evidence on how these predictive models are used by public health departments and whether their use translates into policies that reduce infectious diseases. The proposed research aims to develop predictive modeling tools for California public health departments to allocate targeted vaccines to their highest-risk populations, and then study the implementation and public health impact of using these predictive tools to guide real-time vaccination policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Obesity and diabetes have reached epidemic proportions in modern society, with great costs to health care systems. This proposal will uncover the influence of chronic sleep restriction and circadian disruption, both independently and in combination, on metabolic health. The findings from this project will inform the development of biological and behavioral interventions to promote healthy weight in not only overweight or obese individuals, but also individuals at risk for obesity who live on restricted sleep schedules and/or work on extended duration, rotating, or permanent night shifts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to create a state-of-the-art Dietary Biomarker Development Center at Harvard University to systematically catalog validated metabolomic signatures of important food sources of protein and carbohydrates in the US diets. This will be accomplished by combining cutting-edge metabolomics technologies with controlled feeding studies and well-established observational cohorts for the discovery and validations of novel biomarkers of food intake. The findings will contribute to the accelerated discovery of objective and robust dietary biomarkers, thereby facilitating precision nutrition research to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preeclampsia, classically defined as new-onset hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation, affects 3-5% of all pregnancies worldwide, carrying devastating health consequences for both mother and offspring. While it has been found that (1) placental and circulating levels of cell-free mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) are elevated in preeclampsia and (2) DNase I inhibits mtDNA-mediated platelet activation and thrombus formation in other disease processes, the effects of DNase I on the hypercoagulable state characterizing preeclampsia are unknown. The potential therapeutic application of DNase I to modulate hypercoagulability and associated thrombosis in the placental and systemic circulation would constitute a major paradigm shift in treatment of preeclampsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study aims to identify and characterize genetic loci underlying coronary artery disease in populations of African ancestry. We will efficiently leverage the existing resources of the Population Architecture using Genomics and Epidemiology Consortium, Million Veteran Program and other established cohorts to create the largest-ever sample size for a study of an African-ancestry population comprehensively phenotyped for CAD and related cardiometabolic traits. The outcome of this study will provide a better understanding of the genetics of CAD and its risk factors in this high-risk population and has a strong likelihood of leading to measures that can help with the control and prevention of CAD in populations of African ancestry.

PHR: Project Narrative Prune Belly Syndrome (PBS) is a severe human urologic disorder with poorly understood genetic causes. DNA mutations in the X-linked gene filamin A (FLNA) identified in PBS cases will be tested to find their dysfunctional effects critically altering bladder detrusor smooth muscle development and disrupting binding to distinct partners, to guide future treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) have an increased incidence of cancer, especially lymphoma and lung cancer, compared to the general population and to date relatively little is known about the safety of standard immunosuppressives for RA in patients with active or recently (< 5 years since diagnosis) diagnosed cancer. Little is also known about how to support decision-making for these patients who have at least two major comorbid conditions and may be under the care of multiple different specialists. The central focus of this proposal is to advance the evidence-base around use of immunosuppressive medications among patients with RA who have active or recently diagnosed cancer and to provide a foundation for shared decision making to ensure alignment between treatment decisions and the values, goals, and preferences of individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will determine the efficacy of eHealth Mindful Movement and Breathing (eMMB) for improving postoperative pain, psychological distress, and other surgical outcomes among women undergoing surgery for suspected gynecologic malignancies. eMMB is a brief intervention that adapts yoga with the intention to remove key barriers to participation around the time of surgery and mitigate the transition from acute to chronic pain. If eMMB is efficacious, this low-cost intervention has the potential to be widely implemented and generalizable to other surgical procedures, and thus to substantially reduce the growing population affected by chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Psychological suffering has been identified as a driver of opioid misuse in individuals with cancer on opioid therapy. However, there are no interventions that target this known problem in this unique population with increased vulnerability to develop substance use disorder (SUD). Therefore, the goals of this study are to: (1) examine the feasibility and acceptability of a novel behavioral intervention to reduce the risk of opioid misuse in cancer patients on opioid therapy by way of reducing psychological suffering; (2) pilot test the refined intervention for this high-risk population; and (3) estimate effect sizes for a future, adequately powered RCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kidney transplantation (KT) is a rapidly-expanding, lifesaving intervention for people living with HIV (PLWH) and end-stage renal disease, yet the landscape of serious post-transplant infections and associated risk factors including immunosuppressive regimens remain undefined. This proposal aims to utilize national KT cohort data to characterize the burden, timing, and spectrum of infections in HIV+ KT recipients, with comparison to HIV- KT controls, in order to evaluate modifiable risk factors and guide potential targeted monitoring and prophylaxis. In addition, we seek to understand whether there are differential infectious risks associated with HIV+ organ donation within the emerging population of HIV-to-HIV KT recently legalized under the HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) Act and under study through the HOPE in Action clinical trials group.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study examines the role of intergenerational social mobility on persistent Black/White differences in adverse birth outcomes across generations in the United States, focusing on the Deep South. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Seminar (GRS) on Immunometabolism in Health and Disease have highly interdisciplinary programs that bring together international experts, early-stage investigators, and trainees to discuss emerging concepts, approaches, and opportunities at the interface of cellular metabolism and innate and adaptive immunity. The research topics have been carefully selected to address both mechanistic roles for cellular metabolism in myeloid and lymphoid cells, and therapeutic implications of these functions in a wide variety of immune-mediated diseases (e.g., infectious disease, allergy, autoimmunity, cancer, atherosclerosis, obesity, and diabetes). Moreover, the Immunometabolism in Health and Disease GRC and GRS aims to foster interactions between academia and industry, and to help seed and cultivate the next generation of diverse scientists in this critical cross-disciplinary field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the current management protocols for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) focus on the underlying disease, rather than addressing coagulopathy, and result in staggeringly high mortality rates for both humans and animals. We have developed fibrin-specific nanogels (FSNs) that site-specifically deliver anti-clotting drugs while also enhancing fibrin cross-linking and formation, providing a solution for both the prothrombotic and hemorrhagic DIC phenotypes. Loading FSNs with both a fibrinolytic and an anticoagulant has the potential to provide an enhanced effect on improving DIC outcomes, with the potential of overcoming the limitations of current therapies and saving lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss, often resulting from cochlear sensory hair cell dysfunction, greatly impacts the quality of life for millions of people. We aim to understand the mechanisms that regulate the processing and localization of specialized auditory protein complexes in hair cells, and explore the impact of hearing-loss-related mutations on these processes. Our research is expected to reveal novel molecules and mechanistic checkpoints in hair cell protein processing, potentially offering new targets for therapeutic interventions to address hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Neural tracking of natural speech provides an exciting new window into human communication abilities. However, many basic questions about what the neural tracking reflects, and how it could be utilized in the diagnosis and treatment of hearing disorders, remain unanswered. This project will characterize the cochlear, neural, and cognitive contributions to age- and hearing-loss-related changes in the perception and neural responses to speech.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will provide novel insight into the biomechanical forces and regulatory processes that drive ovulation while simultaneously providing me with scientific and leadership skills to be a successful clinician- scientist. I propose that during ovulation, progesterone decreases expression of a calcium channel, TRPV4, which promotes fluid accumulation in the ovarian follicle and leads to a disproportionate increase in pressure on the region of the follicle wall that will rupture to release the cumulus oocyte complex. Quantifying the biomechanical forces and regulators that drive follicle rupture during ovulation will lead to improved understanding of anovulatory infertility and to the development of novel non-hormonal contraceptives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF), Thunderclap headaches, and Nairobi sheep disease, are dangerous emerging human and animal diseases caused by nairoviruses that can potentially cause widespread health and economic devastation. Recently, nairoviruses have been shown to share a conserved evasion mechanism that hinders the human innate immune response. This proposal serves to investigate and leverage that mechanism through synergetic molecular, cell based and in vivo means in order to will provide information for the development of selective and broad-based anti- viral treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Human cytomegalovirus is among the most common congenital infections and can cause severe, lifelong symptoms for a developing fetus. In this proposal, I aim to elucidate how placental trophoblast cells defend against HCMV infection and how these defenses could in turn drive placental dysfunction. Studies such as this are critical to understand how viruses and other pathogens can cross the placenta, gain access to the fetus, and ultimately cause congenital disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite effective antiretroviral therapy (ART), HIV resides in infected cells as integrated proviruses and persists lifelong. The source of HIV-induced immune activation remains obscure. We will use cutting-edge, state-of-the-art single-cell multi-omic profiling methods to examine HIV-induced chronic immune activation in people living with HIV under suppressive antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The impact of limited drug delivery and immune evasion have rendered the aggressive and invasive brain cancer, glioblastoma (GBM), virtually uncurable with current therapeutic approaches. Therapeutic focused ultrasound (FUS) can safely deliver energy to the brain to reach a therapeutic threshold that results in a variety of bioeffects, including temporary blood brain barrier opening (BBBO) and activation of a local immune response. The goal of this proposal is to utilize advanced imaging approaches like PET-CT to study how FUS can be applied to improve the brain delivery and antitumor effects of anti-CD47 immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cholestatic liver disease, such as primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), is a critical clinical problem associated with high morbidity and mortality but no available FDA-approved treatment due to the limited understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms. Noncoding RNAs, such as long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs), circular RNA (circRNAs), and microRNA (miRNAs), are important regulators of various physiological and pathological processes. The focus of this application is to examine the role of lncRNAh19-mediated dysregulation of circRNAs (CircEdil3 &CircAff3) in cholestatic liver injury and further identify the underlying cellular/molecular mechanisms for developing potential diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for PSC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral nerve injuries are common and debilitating conditions affecting more than one hundred thousand people annually in the US. Prognosis for recovery of severe nerve injuries is poor, as high-grade axonotmetic and neurotmetic injuries usually do not spontaneously recover. The overall goal of this study is to develop a new optical imaging approach to understand the processes associated with nerve degeneration in live animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The vertebrate retina comprises many microcircuits working together to process information necessary for us to navigate the visual world. Although we have a good understanding of some key circuits, many others remain elusive. This is because there has not been an opportunity to map all cells and their detailed connectivity within a retina. This project will enable labs to work collaboratively to generate a complete connectome of an adult mouse retina, a key model system for studying visual processing and for understanding how cellular and circuit perturbation, such as loss of photoreceptors and their connections, contribute to vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arrestins underlie critical neurobiological signaling cascades of clinical relevance like nociception and addiction. This project will examine the validity of utilizing the cannabinoid 2 receptor as a means of creating a tractable research platform for the structural characterization of molecular interactions required for arrestin recruitment. This will enable continuing development of arrestin biased, GPCR-targeted pharmaceuticals designed using nuclear magnetic resonance-based approaches to enable more efficacious pharmacological profiles.
