IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fundamental aging processes appear to be root-cause contributors to most of the disorders and diseases across the lifespan that account for the bulk of ill health, disability, and health costs. The goal of the nation-wide Translational Geroscience Network (TGN) is to rapidly accelerate translation of geroscience-guided lifestyle, nutritional, and drug interventions that target these fundamental aging processes from biological discovery and pre-clinical validation to testing in human subjects. Through its efforts in planning, facilitating, and coordinating these studies, the TGN has enormous potential to impact public health through delaying, preventing, alleviating, and treating multiple disorders and promoting healthspan, the period of life free of disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parental participation in the care of hospitalized children has many positive outcomes, including helping parents to develop confidence in caring for their children, but there are many barriers to parents’ participation. This study will help us to understand how social determinants of health unique to each family influence parental participation and parenting confidence among parents of children diagnosed with congenital heart defects. The study findings will provide important information that can be used to develop new ways to improve the health of children with congenital heart defects and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Spirochetes cause several serious diseases in humans and periplasmic flagellar motility is crucial for virulence by all pathogenic spirochetes. The novel studies outlined in this proposal are to delineate periplasmic flagellar assembly, orientation, bacterial morphology, and motility that are distinctive in the spirochetes. The virulence-associated flagellar structural proteins can lead to the development of a structure-based pharmacological agent to treat or prevent diseases caused by the spirochetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a common childhood condition that can have serious negative immediate and long-term consequences. Many of these consequences are likely related to the resulting hearing loss that OME can cause but characterizing that hearing loss is limited by challenges associated with behavioral audiometric testing in young children. The goal of this work is to improve the diagnosis and understanding of OME and its associated hearing loss, including the development of an objective and non-invasive automated estimate of that hearing loss, as well as determine how variations in OME and its related hearing loss impact binaural processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Deficits in sensory processing are common in brain disorders, but the neural substrates of these deficits are poorly understood, and the treatments for them are limited. Evidence suggests that higher-order auditory processing is subject to modulation by dopamine signaling in the striatum—a process that may go awry in diseases like schizophrenia. The current study will combine genetic circuit manipulations with in vivo imaging and behavior to link activity in specific dopamine projections and the modulation of specific striatal neuron types to auditory perception deficits that may be relevant to psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: HPV causes 5% of cancers worldwide including 30% of head and neck cancers. While the majority of HPV infections are cleared by the innate immune system, long-term infections, occurring when the virus evades the innate immune system, can result in the formation of cancer. Completion of the proposed studies will enhance our understanding of how and why HPV attenuates the cGAS/STING pathway, a key innate immune pathway in the detection of viral infections and DNA damage, specifically in head and neck cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapies for the disease of contractile muscle are extraordinarily difficult to develop and have a track record of significant adverse effects during clinical trials, including patient death. We will develop an in vitro model of contractility using both human and murine cells that can be used to pre-clinically test these therapies in a way that can translate results from animal to human studies. We will also use the platform to assess the viability of a revolutionary novel genetic medicine for Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus can cause infections within nearly all tissues in a host and treatment of disease is complicated by antimicrobial resistance. Energy balance and metabolism are critical to S. aureus viability; yet we know little about how S. aureus adapts its metabolism to persist in diverse infection sites. This proposal will investigate the role of a lipoic acid transfer protein in promoting S. aureus metabolism and virulence, which has the potential to expand our knowledge of host-microbe interactions and open avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is estimated that more than 10 million people fall ill with tuberculosis (TB) ever year, but less than 7 million were diagnosed and linked to care in 2021. We will assess the overall effectiveness and implementation of a novel TB case finding intervention implemented in India during the post-treatment period and will develop a model to help target the intervention among high-risk households. Optimizing this intervention and bringing it to scale could result in substantial reductions in time to TB diagnosis and treatment, thereby improving patient outcomes and reducing transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nephrotoxic drug-induced kidney injury effects millions globally each year, leading to massive individual patient and widely national socio-economic burden. In this injury setting, endothelial cells have been hypothesized to transdifferentiate to a fibrotic phenotype through a mechanism known as endothelial to mesenchymal transition (EndMT). This proposal aims to understand the maturity of endothelial cells within a novel in vitro kidney model, while also further understanding the molecular and cellular mechanism of EndMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophages’ precise regulation of inflammation is vital in maintaining homeostasis and preventing excessive or insufficient inflammation observed in critical illnesses like sepsis, affecting 1.7 million US adults annually. One method of control is endotoxin tolerance, which is the ability for a secondary innate immune response to be diminished to prevent a hyperinflammatory or persistent response upon repeated exposure to endotoxins. This project aims to investigate the role of dynamic macrophage metabolism reprogramming in modulating the inflammatory response during endotoxin tolerance, potentially uncovering novel metabolic targets for managing critical illnesses such as sepsis and promoting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is the most common inheritable form of renal disease and affects 1 in 1000 individuals. Mutations in polycystin genes cause the formation of kidney cysts for which there is no cure, resulting in renal failure and the need for transplantation. This proposal will apply a novel scientific approach to understand polycystin dysregulation by relevant disease-causing mutations reported in patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though accelerated aging is robustly correlated with health and well-being during adulthood, little research has examined it’s predictive and functional relevance during early childhood. This study seeks to examine accelerated aging as a predictive pathway to explain how early life stress impacts children’s behavioral and cognitive functioning. This project will additionally elucidate the association between accelerated aging and children’s observed behavioral regulation and cognition during the first few years of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to compare structural and functional features of the uterotubal junction in women with and without endometriosis, and to develop a miniature minimally invasive endoscope for endometriosis diagnosis. This work could profoundly advance our current understanding of an important yet critically understudied segment of female anatomy and identify microstructural features that can be used towards endometriosis diagnosis. The endoscope has potential to reduce the burden of undiagnosed endometriosis, enabling early and accurate diagnosis of endometriosis, timely treatment, and improved health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are more than 130 million emergency department visits in the U.S. each year, and many emergencies involve injuries and illnesses related to the brain, including stroke, seizures, traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury, pain, addiction, and neurodegenerative diseases. To help advance research in these areas, this national Emergency Medicine Research Career Development Program in the Neurological Sciences (EMRCDP-NS) aims to increase the number of emergency medicine clinician-scientists conducting successful and transformative research on neurologic (i.e., brain) disorders. To achieve this, we will identify, recruit, and support promising emergency medicine researchers at the beginning of their careers and ensure they have the time, mentorship, and training needed to effectively perform research that can improve the care of patients with neurologic disorders in the emergency department.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodevelopmental disorders can be driven by primary defects in neurons or as secondary effects from al- tered formation of neighboring tissue such as the meninges or skull. Neurodevelopmental disorders can cause lifelong cognitive and motor impairments and uncovering their underlying mechanisms is important for develop- ing therapeutics. This proposal investigates development of the meninges, a protective covering for the CNS, to better understand why alterations in its formation impacts brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to identify and model networks involved in processing tactile information in the ventral nerve cord of the fly, Drosophila melanogaster. This research will shed light on how different types of neurons support the fly’s ability to respond to tactile stimulation from different areas on the leg. Insights from this project will expand our understanding of how the nervous system organizes sensory information and may direct future research on how deficits in this tactile circuit may impact behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is a highly deadly cancer with the potential for improved outcomes in patient survival using combination immunotherapies. This research seeks to investigate the mechanisms of how these therapies alter the communication between immune cells to recognize and fight this cancer. Understanding these mechanisms will result in better treatments that utilize the immune system to eradicate cancer and lead to fewer deaths from this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) affect 2-5% of the school-aged population, with up to 90% of individuals meeting criteria for a co-occurring mental health disorder. Yet, not a single mental health intervention has been developed for this population. The current project will adapt Dialectical Behavior Therapy for Adolescents (DBT-A) for individuals with FASD and conduct a feasibility trial of these adaptations in a community mental health clinic utilizing an implementation science framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance: Our long-term goal is to develop community-based, behavioral interventions to prevent age-related cognitive decline and ADRD in at risk populations across the lifespan. This study addresses a critical gap in our understanding of the use of exercise in the prevention and treatment of accelerated age-related cognitive decline in older adults with CKD and mild cognitive impairment. By combining cognitive function assessment with MR-imaging, we will be able to evaluate the brain-behavior response to exercise and discern the relationships at a level previously not conducted in this population and thus, the potential clinical impact is high and readily translatable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: To advance the national “Ending the HIV Epidemic” (EHE) initiative and NIH Office of AIDS research priorities as well as to help close our regional gaps, the proposed Midwest Developmental Centers for AIDS Research (D-CFAR) seeks to advance transdisciplinary research, foster multi-sector collaboration and nurture emerging investigators addressing HIV/AIDS. These objectives will fill a geographical niche, leverage rich existing institutional resources, supply critical additional resources and thereby advance a transformative research agenda. At a moment when the EHE initiative has re-energized the response, an investment in research infrastructure for HIV can help create and deliver timely scientific insights to optimize momentum against the HIV pandemic in our region and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is a debilitating psychiatric illness with inadequate treatment options. Negative reinforcement theories of OCD assert that compulsive behaviors are performed to avoid obsession- evoked anxiety, and clinical studies have implicated the medial orbitofrontal cortex (mOFC) as a key region mediating excessive avoidance in OCD and a potential treatment target. In this proposal, we will investigate how the mOFC encodes negative reinforcement learning in mice and dissect the relative contributions of projection- specific mOFC neural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ACCESS implementation strategy seeks to support syringe services programs in adopting, implementing, and sustaining opt-out HIV/HCV testing through external facilitation and funding to increase the reach of HIV/HCV testing in people who inject drugs (PWID). We urgently need a strong evidence base to prove that the ACCESS strategy can help us increase diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of HIV in PWID. We seek to set the foundation to build, implement, and scale-up a new standard of care for comprehensive HIV services for PWID in non-stigmatizing settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disaggregating longitudinal patterns and correlates of alcohol and cannabis (AC) co-use in young people who are already engaged in alcohol use is essential to informing potential targets for clinical and public health intervention, particularly for providers in states navigating the emergence of novel recreational cannabis laws (RCLs). The F31 applicant will identify latent profiles and transition patterns of adolescent AC co-use (e.g., additive or substitution effects) and examine how multidimensional SES (mSES) and cannabis policy context are associated with these trajectories. The training plan is designed to provide rich training in adolescent development, addiction, advanced longitudinal modeling, and an initial exploration into differential patterns for underrepresented youth, providing critical protected research time for the applicant to build and launch a career as an independent NIH-funded scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There have been major changes in the landscape of prescribing controlled substances (eg, benzodiazepines, opioids, and stimulants) in the US over the past three decades including a steady increase in prescribing opioids for two decades (1990-2010) followed by sharp decreases in opioid prescribing and major increases in stimulant prescribing, especially among middle-aged and older adults. The shifts in medical use of prescription drugs have important implications for the etiology of nonmedical prescription drug misuse and associated consequences; however, there has been relatively little consideration of the developmental relationships between the initiation and discontinuation of medical use of prescription medications and subsequent substance-related adverse consequences (eg, drug overdose deaths, all-cause mortality, substance use disorder symptoms) within the same individuals. This renewal will help inform clinical, prevention, policy, and regulatory efforts by identifying trajectories of medical use of prescription medications from adolescence up to older adulthood and by examining how these trajectories are associated with other drug use and adverse consequences using US nationally longitudinal samples while considering variations by age, cohort, sex, race/ethnicity, and education.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise plays a vital role in the physical fitness and well-being of patients diagnosed with multiple myeloma. The proposed research sub-analysis will examine the effect of a prehabilitative aerobic and resistance exercise intervention in patients with multiple myeloma scheduled to receive autologous stem cell transplant, designed to assess the feasibility of exercise. This research will address the question of whether novel timing, prior to autologous stem cell transplant, is an intervention strategy that improves muscular strength in multiple myeloma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: COLD SPRING HARBOR LABORATORY CONFERENCE  MECHANISMS AND MODELS OF CANCER  August 13 - 17, 2024  Cancer is a collection of deadly diseases that will afflict one out of every two to three people in the developed world during their lifetime. In recent years, great progress has been made in understanding how cancer develops and progresses. Ever more sophisticated and elegant models of human cancer have been developed for most types of cancer, and we understand in great detail the molecular and cellular changes that promote disease development. Collectively, these advances are improving both the quality of life and overall survival of cancer patients. Yet despite these advances, huge challenges remain. While “targeted” therapies can result in dramatic clinical response, these are typically transient, necessitating that we understand resistance to develop rational drug combinations. Immune-based therapies have led to remarkable responses-including cures—in select patients, but the side effects of these therapies can be substantial and most cancers remain refractory to current agents. To stimulate innovation and cross- disciplinary interactions in this rapidly advancing field, we propose to convene a group of outstanding basic and clinical researchers studying the development and progression of cancer in a variety of model systems, in an international meeting entitled Mechanisms and Models of Cancer at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in August 2024.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The realization of Plasmodium vivax's ability to invade red blood cells of Duffy negative individuals and occurring commonly in Africa changed the paradigm of our understanding of Plasmodium vivax biology. However, the underlying mechanisms of this phenomenon are yet to be understood. This proposal will provide career development, through didactic and mentored training, for a promising MD/PhD student to investigate potential mechanisms using a combined in vitro and in vivo approach that leverages advanced genomic and bioinformatic techniques.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with epilepsy who continue to have seizures while on medication can benefit from surgical removal of the brain region generating these seizures. This could lead to higher success rates for these surgeries and a reduced need for invasive testing for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms coordinating epithelial cell polarization, apical lumen formation and ciliogenesis in kidney cells. During five previous funding cycles we have demonstrated that polarized endosome transport and cell division plays key roles in targeting proteins to the apical plasma membrane and identified the proteins that are required for this process. In this study we will identify the function and regulation of these polarity organizing proteins, as well as their role in apical lumen formation and ciliogenesis during normal kidney development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Up to 90% of individuals who misuse cocaine also co-use alcohol [4, 5] and this co-use may vastly influence not only vulnerability to cocaine use but also maintenance of cocaine use and responsiveness to various behavioral and pharmacological treatments [7-9]. As a result, the research proposed in this application will examine all three aspects of drug misuse to determine how ethanol self-administration influences vulnerability to initial cocaine reinforcement, maintenance of cocaine self-administration in the presence of nondrug alternative reinforcers, and responsiveness to pharmacotherapies. Results from these studies should aid in the development of personalized medicine strategies for individuals who co-use cocaine and alcohol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria, and in doing so, regulate their abundance, evolution, and virulence. In this project, we want to investigate bacteriophages that infect Salmonella Typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, and investigate their prevalence and genetic diversity in a setting where typhoid is endemic. We will also use genetic and biochemical tools to dissect the molecular mechanisms of the ongoing arms race between different strains of the Salmonella Typhi and its circulating bacteriophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Current malaria vaccines are largely ineffective in individuals previously infected with Plasmodium, the causative agent of malaria, compared to Plasmodium-naïve individuals. The studies outlined in this proposal will both determine how prior Plasmodium infection impacts the humoral response to a subsequent vaccination and how to modify immunization techniques to overcome impaired immunity. These studies have the potential to impact how we approach vaccination of Plasmodium-experienced individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Hydrogen sulfide regulates energy metabolism by functioning as a respiratory inhibitor and a substrate. Respiratory inhibition results from sulfide binding to the heme and copper centers of complex IV in the electron transport chain. This study will elucidate an unexpected connection between sulfide and cellular copper homeostasis that is relevant to the long-term effects of sulfide on energy metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research examines the role of cochlear suppression in auditory processing of complex dynamic sounds that vary in sweep rate and direction (i.e., frequency sweeps). Key insights on the mechanisms of spatiotemporal processing have come from human behavioral masking experiments and direct physiological recordings in mammals using these stimuli, but cross-species differences and the invasive nature of physiological methods make it challenging to infer function in humans. By leveraging non-invasive otoacoustic and behavioral measures to study cochlear suppression and its dependence on sweep rate and direction, the proposed study will both improve our understanding of cochlear function important for human communication and provide a foundation for understanding how this might be affected by hearing impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication between cortical areas is thought to occur via direct and transthalamic pathways. The specific functions(s) of each pathway and their relative contributions to cortical communication are important and unresolved questions. Given the severe financial and quality-of-life consequences that follow from disruption in cortical communication and thalamic processing, such as occurs with many forms of epilepsy and illnesses affecting vision, it is important that we understand how the thalamus and cortex interact to meet the processing needs of the brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Significance: The proposed project could rapidly accelerate a promising new treatment for chronic complex TBI that is supported by strong preliminary data and builds upon compelling research findings. If allopregnanolone (ALLO) is efficacious and well-tolerated in this population, a larger Phase 2 or Phase 3 randomized controlled trial (RCT) would be the next logical step for this molecule - which has the potential to address an urgent unmet clinical need for Veterans with chronic complex TBI and commonly co-occurring conditions such as depression and pain symptoms, and to positively impact functional outcome and quality of life in this population. A longer-acting formulation of ALLO is also a possibility and under development in our laboratory. In the interim, the proposed pilot RCT using intravenous ALLO would provide critical pharmacokinetic data in this chronic complex TBI cohort, in addition to potential initial clinical signals for therapeutic efficacy and biomarker candidate identification to inform future efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: FDA guidelines stipulate that all new drugs be tested for dangerous side-effects on the heart as part of preclinical research; however, the current tests are poorly predictive of both dangerous and safe drugs leading to unwarranted attrition and dangerous drugs reaching clinic. Human cardiomyocytes derived from donor tissue (iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes) are widely considered to hold great promise for clinical trial in a dish studies of drug cardiotoxicity. This STTR proposal is to commercialize a high throughput platform to accurately identify drug candidates that have cardiac side effects, in particular adding the ability to detect the type of primary heart cell damage common with anti-cancer drugs in a fully automated (high throughput) robotic assay for the first time, to improve the efficiency of preclinical research and the safety of human clinical trials, which will also likely have the added benefit of reducing animal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visual processing in infancy is a critically important aspect of healthy development, and understanding typical development of visual processing has public health benefits. By furthering our knowledge about how cortical maturation and individual differences in experience shape the development of mature looking behaviors, this project will add significant knowledge about development in typical populations. Visual impairments in infants and children are increasingly caused by prenatal cerebral damage (e.g., cortical visual impairment) that impacts higher-level visual functions such as attention and processing of cluttered scenes (Ben Itzhak et al., 2019; Chang & Borchert, 2021; Hatton et al., 2007), and research like that proposed here will be essential for future assessment and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Time restricted feeding (TRF) in a model of diet induced obesity (DIO) significantly reduced aortic damage and improved endothelial function. Th17 cells are an inflammatory CD4+ T cell subset that are upregulated in the aorta with DIO and reduced with TRF indicating a potential role of Th17 cells in mediating the reduced damage with TRF. The main goal of this project is to identify the mechanism of the role of Th17 cells in improved aortic damage and endothelial function with TRF in DIO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Kurshan, Peri T. Project Narrative  Mutations in synaptic cell-adhesion molecules such as neurexins are highly associated with neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders and often lead to defects in synapse formation, although the molecular mechanisms by which this occurs are still largely unknown. In this proposal, we seek to understand the cell-intrinsic mechanisms by which presynaptic cell-adhesion molecules including neurexin are localized to synapses and contribute to their maturation. As a result, this research will have the potential to reveal novel therapeutic approaches to target diseases associated with defects in this critical class of synaptic proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Regionalized myocardial fibrosis is commonly observed in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and is a risk factor for postoperative left ventricular dysfunction as well as sudden cardiac death. The proposed studies aim to demonstrate a mechanistic link between a prolapsing mitral valve and abnormal mechanical forces that promote regionalized myocardial fibrosis, and will further dissect the cellular, mechanical, and molecular changes that initiate and sustain regionalized myocardial fibrosis in MVP. Completion of this proposal will identify new biological pathways that can be targeted for patient benefit, and lend support for modification of existing surgical guidelines to minimize sudden death and postoperative dysfunction in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the causative agent of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Despite growing evidence that T cells play a vital role in combatting COVID- 19, very little structural information is currently available on the interaction of SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell receptors (TCRs) with their peptide–MHC (pMHC) targets. We propose to address this knowledge gap by using X-ray crystallography to determine three-dimensional structures of TCRs from COVID-19 convalescent patients bound to selected SARS-CoV-2 T cell epitopes and HLA-A2 or HLA-B7.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one of the leading causes of death and disability in the USA, where nearly 2 million individuals are diagnosed with TBI each year. Survivors of TBI experience life long disabilities which can signiﬁcantly affect their quality of life and productivity. Mild brain injuries remain difﬁcult to diagnose given the overlap in their clinical presentation with other conditions. In addition, individuals with TBI are at high risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD), particularly among genetically predisposed individuals with the apolipoprotein E (APOE) ε4 allele. As such, there remains a critical need for availability of non-invasive blood markers that can help diagnose and identify underlying pathology that may be indicative of their future risk of developing AD. The work proposed will apply state of the art mass spectrometry technology to identify blood lipid metabolites as biomarkers of TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of obesogenic cardiometabolic disorders (CMDs) is increasing alarmingly worldwide. Previous large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have reliably identified CMD-associated variants; however, their cell-type-specific mechanisms have remained largely elusive. To address this scientific knowledge gap and further our understanding of gene expression at a single cell level, we will perform single nucleus RNA-sequencing in 300 subcutaneous adipose tissue samples to generate fine-scale estimates of cell-type proportions; identify study-wide and personalized cell-type-specific differences corresponding to cardiometabolic trait levels; and characterize GWAS variants that underlie CMDs by altering cell-type-specific expression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs) are remnants of retroviruses that were integrated into human genome millions of years ago. Although HERVs are generally suppressed in the current human cells, we found that LTR5_Hs, a special HERV species that is found only in the genome of humans but not monkeys, is uniquely activated in early-stage gamete precursor cells, which release retrovirus-like particles from their surface. This project will attempt to determine possible roles of LTR5_Hs in development of the human gamete precursor cells, testing a hypothesis that production of sperm and eggs in the normal human body is dependent on reactivation of this otherwise suppressed viral DNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the extent to which cognitive training is susceptible to placebo effects, and if so, whether such effects can be magnified/harnessed, would greatly aid the development and evaluation of treatment regimens for a host of disorders where deficits in cognitive function are amongst the core symptoms (e.g., ADRD in particular, as related to older adults, but also ADHD, schizophrenia, TBI, MCI, etc.). Thus, the proposed research cuts across the bounds of numerous NIH agencies, contributing to the missions of the NIA, NCI, NEI, NIMH, NIAAA, NINCD, NIDA, NINDS, in that all of these agencies work with populations who can gain direct benefits from successful approaches to mental fitness, and the NIH's greater mission to seek knowledge that will result enhanced health and a reduced burden of disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with chronic, life-limiting illness and acute respiratory failure are at high risk for poor patient- and family-centered outcomes and represent a patient population in need of high-quality palliative care. This project will address our limited knowledge regarding palliative care for these patients and their family members by examining temporal trends in quality indicators of palliative care. Knowledge gained from this study will guide future research to improve palliative care delivery and outcomes for patients with acute respiratory failure and their family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Partnership to Assess Viral and Immune Landscape Intersections with Oncology for People Living with HIV Program (PAVILION) will bring together experienced research sites and world-renowned HIV, human papillomavirus, Epstein Barr Virus, and cancer researchers to offer a novel contribution to the HIV-Associated Malignancies Research Center network. The PAVILION theme is research of understudied, virus-associated tumors that disproportionately impact men and women living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa with the overall goal of providing the data necessary to inform prevention and therapeutic strategies to reduce the burden of cancers among people living with HIV and cancer in this region. This partnership will directly address the urgent need to mitigate a rapidly rising cancer burden that is largely comprised of infection-associated cancers in two partnering low- and middle-income countries (South Africa and Zimbabwe) that have among the highest prevalence of HIV infection in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Na-Cl cotransporter in the distal nephron is a major component of Na+ homeostasis and its dysregulation leads to salt wasting or increased blood pressure. The transporter is also highly responsive to changes in plasma K+ through a cascade of kinases which function is tightly regulated. This application describes studies designed to provide new insights into the roles of KS-WNK, Cab39, and Sall3 in modulating this kinase- mediated regulatory pathway.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framed within our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 People living with HIV (PLWH) have significantly higher cancer incidence compared to people without HIV for cancers caused by HPV (cervical, vulvar, anal, penile, and oropharyngeal), and altered immunity, not simply immunodeficiency, is one proposed mechanism driving this excess risk. The tumor viral and immune milieu are likely major factors contributing to these cancer disparities among PLWH, but few studies have examined the factors (viral and immune) that underlie differences in the cancer burden by HIV status, which is critical information needed to develop improved cancer prevention and treatment strategies for PLWH. Project 1’s overall goal is to inform the development of effective prevention and treatment strategies for HPV-related cancers among PLWH in SSA through thorough investigation of the viral and tumor immune factors associated with HPV- cancers and treatment outcomes using viral and immune profiling tools and high-dimensional technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative- Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ) is a ligand sensitive nuclear receptor which functions as a master regulator of adipogenesis and has broad relevance in metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes. Transcriptionally activating PPARγ ligands that bind to a C-terminal structured ligand- binding domain promote insulin sensitization and have been used clinically for type 2 diabetes treatment; however, it remains poorly understood how the N-terminal intrinsically disordered AF1 region of PPARγ regulates nuclear receptor activity on a structural level. In this project I will use structural methods well suited for studying disordered proteins along with cellular studies to gain insight into how the AF1 region interacts with protein binding partners in a post translational modification-dependent fashion to tune PPARγ cellular functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Conjunctival squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is an eye cancer with unknown etiology that disproportionately impacts sub-Saharan Africa, a setting where presentation with advanced disease is common and prevalence of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is high. People living with HIV (PLWH), a population highly susceptible to virus-associated cancers, have a pronounced elevation of cSCC cancer incidence, suggesting a potential viral etiology for this tumor. Project 2 seeks to determine if EBV infection is causally linked to the development of cSCC in PLWH in sub-Saharan Africa, laying the groundwork for future development of EBV targeted therapeutics and early detection biomarkers of cSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 Body weight loss in pancreatic cancer, recognized as progressive wasting of fat and muscle, is frequent and severe, reducing quality of life and response to therapy and increasing mortality. In partnership with the other Projects in this Program, we seek to understand how the tumor, fat and muscle communicate to each other within the body of an individual with pancreatic cancer. Using tissues from mouse models and from surgical pancreatic cancer patients, and blood samples and clinical data from an ongoing pancreatic cancer clinical trial, we will apply advanced analytical techniques including at the single cell level to identify new molecular targets to improve treatment and quality of life in patients with pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DATA MANAGEMENT & STATISTICS CORE The overarching goal of the Data Management & Statistics Core (DMSC) for the artnership to ssess iral and Immune andscape Intersections with cology for People Living with HIV (PAVILION) is to provide comprehensive statistical design, data management, and analysis in support of conducting rigorous and reproducible research by PAVILION investigators who are working to make strides in understanding the proportion of tumors whose etiology is attributable to the human papillomavirus (HPV) and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) among people living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa including such rare tumor types as anal, cervical, conjunctival, oropharyngeal, penile, and vulvar cancers. The DMSC has designed a robust yet flexible pipeline that builds upon the extensive infrastructure and long-term international collaborations established by the PAVILION partnering investigators and leverages the extensive investment by Moffitt Cancer Center in biostatistics, bioinformatic, informatic, and computing capabilities as well as the depth and breadth of expertise in the analysis of basic, translational, clinical, and large-scale cancer epidemiological studies to address project aims and build biostatistical capacity at Stellenbosch University (South Africa) and University of Zimbabwe, the PAVILION low- and middle-income country (LMIC) sites. Further, the DMSC will provide education and training through lectures and mentorship in biostatistics to members and research staff, with the goal of building the expertise and capacity of the LIMC partner sites to lead future studies/trials. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CENTRAL LABORATORY CORE The overarching goal of the Central Laboratory (CL) Core for the artnership to ssess iral and Immune  andscape Intersections with cology for People Living with HIV (PAVILION) is to provide centralized biobanking and virologic and immunologic assessment of well annotated biospecimens in support of the proposed translational studies as well as future PAVILION pilot projects. The CL Core has designed a robust yet flexible pipeline and range of analytical methodologies that builds upon the infrastructure and long-term international collaborations established by the PAVILION partnering investigators in South Africa, Zimbabwe, the US, and Germany. The CL Core purposefully pairs this unique expertise with established laboratories in the low- and middle-income country (LMIC) partner countries to efficiently advance knowledge related to tumor and patient characteristics, which can then inform the development of effective prevention and cancer treatment interventions to reduce the burden of cancer for people living with HIV (PLWH) in LMICs disproportionately impacted by HIV. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Choline can be metabolized by the gut microbiome to produce trimethylamine, a precursor to trimethylamine N- oxide (TMAO) which is a metabolite contributing to the development of atherosclerosis, a highly prevalent condition in the US. The purpose of this study is to clarify the interplay between dietary intake, metabolism, the gut microbiome, and vascular health by examining associations between a novel dietary pattern predictive of biomarkers of TMAO production with metabolomic profiles, the gut microbiome composition, and retinal vessel caliber. This study aligns with NHLBI’s Strategic Vision and the precision nutrition research agenda described in the 2020-2030 Strategic Plan for NIH Nutrition Research as it has potential to elucidate how overall dietary intake influences a metabolic process with atherosclerotic effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will elucidate the patterns of single-neuron and population brain activity that underlie both human navigation and memory for spatial and non-spatial information. This work may produce new insights into the neural basis of memory beyond spatial cognition, as the same neural systems that underlie navigating and remembering spatial environments are also thought to be involved in non-spatial memory processes. We anticipate that our work will lead to new understanding and treatments for neurological disorders related to spatial disorientation or memory impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 3 Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a malignancy with staggering statistic, with ~8% of patients surviving five years after their initial diagnosis, and PDAC patients are especially prone to cachexia, a syndrome characterized by pronounced weight loss due to depleting skeletal muscle and adipose tissues that contributes to mortality in this disease. One hallmark of PDAC is the dense stroma consisting of activated cancer fibroblasts that surround each tumor, however, the role of these l cells in supporting tumor growth and cancer cachexia is controversial, and major gaps in knowledge exist regarding their contribution to cancer progression and cachexia. In this project, we propose to determine the function of the IL6/STAT3 signaling pathway, a pathway that could be targeted with existing drugs, in the communication between the stroma in the tumor and in peripheral tissues affected in cachexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DEVELOPMENTAL CORE The overarching goal of the Developmental Core (DC) for the P artnership to A ssess V iral and Immune L andscape Intersections with On cology for People Living with HIV (PAVILION) is to enhance capacity for HIV- associated cancer research through fostering the career development of junior investigators in South Africa, Zimbabwe, and the United States who have a demonstrated interest in infection-related cancer research among people living with HIV (PLWH). This goal involves two broad strategies: 1) implementing a program that generates and supports rigorous pilot research projects and 2) providing other training and educational resources to enhance skills necessary for long term career success, which represents a shift in the culture of research at PAVILION partnering low- and middle-income country (LMIC) institutions. The momentum created by this strategy would provide significant incentive for junior investigators at these sites to take advantage of pilot research funding opportunities while consolidating efforts to pursue career development within a supportive environment with highly experienced mentors, ensuring their long-term success as independent researchers that will meet the critical need for transdisciplinary, multi-institutional, and international partnerships to understand and potentially mitigate the rapidly growing cancer burden in Africa, where the prevalence of HIV infection remains high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our research centers on the essential processes coordinating the environment with cell growth and cell cycle progression in bacteria. Environmental variables dictate not only metabolic status and growth rate, but also morphology, development, and antibiotic sensitivity. Illuminating the regulatory circuits governing the relationship between the environment and bacterial physiology is essential to understand their contribution to antibiotic resistance and to assist in the design and development of approaches to defeat this problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poverty is an important contributor to poor short- and long-term HIV outcomes for pregnant people with HIV (PrPWH), and recent evidence suggests that part of poverty's negative effects on health outcomes are mediated by a reduction in mental bandwidth, an effect which may be magnified during pregnancy and the postpartum period. In this proposal set in Fond-des-Blancs, Haiti, I will characterize the relationship between mental bandwidth, HIV, and the perinatal period in an impoverished rural population, use a qualitative study to identify key characteristics of an unconditional cash transfer intervention for PrPWH with a goal of improving mental bandwidth, and assess this intervention using a Hybrid Type 2 effectiveness-implementation trial. This research is of high public health relevance because additional strategies are urgently needed to improve short- and long-term virological outcomes for this high priority population in order to prevent disease progression, development of drug resistance, transmission to partners, and perinatal transmission during current and future pregnancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal focuses on nebulin, a skeletal muscle protein that causes the debilitating nemaline myopathy disease, NEM2. Using innovative research directions and novel tools we will investigate the nebulin/Lmod2 dual regulation model of thin filament length regulation, the significance of weak actin-binding super-repeats in nebulin, and the role of the C-terminus of nebulin in the Z-disk structure and function. We will also investigate novel avenues for restoring force generation in NEM2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: U19 Program Narrative The proposed studies will explore the hypothesis that activation of neurons increases transport of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the perivascular spaces and in the ventricles via neurovascular coupling-mediated arterial dilation. We hypothesize that the transient changes in blood volume, that are most pronounced during sleep, act as a driving force for reciprocal transport of CSF. Studies linking neural activity, blood and CSF transport in the mouse and human brain will use an array of imaging approaches across multiple temporal and spatial scales, and will be unified in a computational fluid flow model.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: California Department of Food and Agriculture PAR-21-174  Project Period: 2021-2026 Project Narrative The main goal of the proposed project is to further develop, enhance, and sustain the California Food Safety Program to full conformance with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) Food Safety Modernization Act, Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, & Holding of Produce for Human Consumption (Produce Safety Rule) through short and long-term interagency collaborations; and continued extensive cooperation and coordination with the FDA, other state and local agencies, and industry. These activities are intended to further enhance the State’s Produce Safety Program and its ability to reduce, prevent, and respond to food emergencies and better align it with a national integrated food safety system. Achieving the goal will better protect and improve the health of the public by assuring that food is produced safely and unadulterated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1: PROJECT NARRATIVE  One of the major limitations of oncolytic virotherapy (OV) is poor intratumoral distribution. To overcome this problem our group has demonstrated that neural stem cells (NSCs) can be used as a cell carrier to enhance the delivery of a novel oncolytic adenovirus and increase the therapeutic efficacy of such combined strategy vs. local delivery of the virus alone. In this continued renewal, we focus on establishing the safety of repeat product administration utilizing a novel and implantable based catheter system, examine tumor microenvironment after product administration, and validate previously identified genes implicated in OV susceptibility as a biomarker for patient selection in a larger phase 2 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Acne significantly impairs quality of life and is associated with higher risks of mental health disorders. Little is known about how internal and external hormones interact on the burden and outcomes of acne, particularly for transgender persons requiring long-term hormone treatment. This proposal aims to identify and better understand the burden, experience, and outcomes of acne with the ultimate goal to improve skin, mental health, and quality of life outcomes from acne and hormone treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and high blood pressure is a leading contributor to cardiovascular diseases. Although the causes of high blood pressure are varied, many forms are characterized by increased levels of sympathetic nerve activity, and the reasons for this increased sympathetic activity are generally unknown. This project seeks to define the role that the sensory nerves of the kidneys play in increasing sympathetic nervous system activity and thereby increasing cardiovascular disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Schizophrenia (SCZ) is a disabling neurodevelopmental disorder that generally emerges in adolescence or young adulthood due to the confluence of genetic and environmental risk factors. There is a critical need to characterize biological pathways underlying the development of SCZ and other neuropsychiatric disorders. Using longitudinal neuroimaging and spatial transcriptomics, this project aims to elucidate brain biomarkers and neurobiological mechanisms related to genetic and clinical risk factors for psychosis spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tough fibrous interfaces between tissues are a common location of injury and source of pathology, pain and disability. Surgical repairs of interfaces that are desirable proceed in the absence of knowledge of the mechanisms that endow fibrous interfaces with toughness, and unsurprisingly have very high failure rates of up to a nearly unbelievable 94%. By developing and testing the first mathematical models for the toughness of this class of interfaces, we hope to identify the mechanisms of toughening definitively, and more broadly to provide technology that enables design of improved surgical procedures.

PHR: Mitochondrial poration by the BCL-2 protein BAK initiates apoptosis yet it remains poorly characterized and controversial. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle wasting and weakness are highly prevalent in many cancers, and particularly pancreatic cancer. Data from our lab has recently identified that the complement system is highly enriched in the skeletal muscle of people and mice with pancreatic cancer, and associates with the muscle wasting and weakness. In the current work we will investigate the various complement pathways, test targeted complement therapeutics, and explore the role of muscle specific complement activation in pancreatic cancer-induced muscle wasting and weakness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3: NARRATIVE Immunotherapy is a promising approach to treating cancer patients, yet its efficacy so far has been very limited in patients with high grade gliomas. Our work provides an opportunity to explore the B-cell-based vaccine (BVax) as immunotherapy. Our approach utilizes 4-1BBL+ B cells as a cellular platform to promote anti-tumor immunity. This innovative strategy utilizes inherent B-cell effector functions such as antigen presentation and subsequent T-cell activation (cellular immunity), and production of tumor-reactive antibodies (humoral immunity). The preclinical BVax proved to be highly efficient at eradication the tumor in mice. The proposed research project aims to take BVax from the bench and translate it to the clinic.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Narrative We propose to serve as a NARMS retail food surveillance collaborating laboratory. As a participant, we will routinely recover and contribute target pathogens and indicator bacteria to the NARMS surveillance program and support other agencies in Ohio investigating foodborne disease outbreaks. As part of the national NARMS network of laboratories, we will contribute to improved public health through the prevention of foodborne disease and reduced zoonotic transmission of antimicrobial resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) is among the most common forms of muscular dystrophy. FSHD is caused when toxic gene called DUX4 is turned “on” in muscle. We believe that therapies for FSHD should focus on eliminating DUX4. We have developed three strategies to accomplish this using gene therapy. In this study, we will test the ability of these approaches to treat muscular dystrophy in mice, and also determine their ability to avoid possible side unwanted side effects. We believe this study will provide potential treatments for FSHD targeting the DUX4 gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital Heart Disease (CHD) is a global health burden that is a significant cause of infant mortality. The proposed research seeks to understand how these birth defects develop by looking at non-coding genetic variants in an abundant, poorly understood class of molecules called long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). This study will evaluate genetic variation in the human genome that impacts lncRNAs and advance our understanding of their role in disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of children aged 3-17 year have diagnosed anxiety disorders and are at higher risk for poor performance in school, difficulties in social situations, and increased substance use. The proposed study aims to examine the influence of exposure to toxic stress across the first years of life on the gut microbiota, which has been found to alter neurodevelopment and subsequent behavioral inhibition, leading to anxiety symptoms in later childhood. Given limited public health resources, it is important to identify these specific targets for early intervention and thus the proposed research has strong potential for advancing the NIMH's mission of transforming the understanding and treatment of mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The introduction of clinical exome sequencing and whole genome sequencing has transformed our ability to diagnose patients with suspected genetic disease. However, up to 70% of patients with suspected genetic disease remain undiagnosed likely because their disease-causing variant(s) has yet to be discovered or the clinical significance of variants identified in genomic studies remains unclear. The BCM Center for Precision Medicine Modeling will support local, national, and international programs and individual researchers in the development of precision animal models that end the diagnostic odyssey of patients with undiagnosed, rare, and Mendelian diseases and serve as resources for pre-clinical studies investigating personalized medicine approaches to their care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a complex disease with high mortality and morbidity, especially when the right ventricle (RV) fails. This project will explore the proteomic signatures associated with phenotypes of RV failure and PAH mortality and understand the pathways that link metabolic and protein changes in these disease processes. The completion of this study will suggest molecular mechanisms of right ventricular adaptation and guide future research on therapeutic targets for right heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 4: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and lethal brain tumor due to its aggressiveness and ability to resist conventional radio- and chemotherapy. Elucidating the mechanism of chemoresistance is vital to developing an effective therapeutic intervention. This project proposes conducting a Phase 1 clinical trial of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF), an FDA-approved drug from the organ-transplant setting, in combination with standard chemo and radiotherapy for newly diagnosed patients with GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will introduce a new experimental platform paradigm to genomic studies of live cells and tissues that will allow scientists to be more creative, more productive, more collaborative and use fewer resources for their live cell genomics experiments. We will create new platforms that provide living cells growing in realistic 3D cultures that mimic actual tissues in the body and incorporate Internet-based remote control and analysis capabilities. We will deploy this technology to perform new, more robust and more reproducible experiments leading to discoveries in neurodevelopmental disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need to train new investigators to continue the scientific advances that have helped address the health consequences of obesity and type 2 diabetes. The proposed new Research Training Program in Metabolism, Obesity and Type 2 Diabetes will leverage the skills of a group of talented, experienced and well- funded mentors with the state of the art facilities and programs at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Center and a robust pipeline of outstanding MD, MD/PhD and PhD’s candidates to train the next generation of independent academic researchers addressing these important public health challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Drugs of abuse, like opioids, hijack brain circuits that govern adaptive motivation and decision making, yet the identity and function of such circuits remains largely unresolved. Gaining a deeper understanding of how such circuits generate both healthy and unhealthy motivation will greatly enhance our ability to target and treat those brain regions rendered pathological in psychiatric disorders like addiction. Here, I use gene transfer approaches and circuit manipulations to determine functions of the ventral pallidum in risky decision making, and seeking of addictive opioid drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Significance) There is a paucity of research examining the intersection of race, ethnicity, maternal safety bundles, doulas, and maternal outcome in Black women at increased risk of severe maternal morbidity and mortality. The proposed mixed-methods study is the first systematic investigation of pregnancy complications and outcomes among Black women with whom maternal safety bundles including racial disparities, hemorrhage, and hypertension have been utilized and through the analysis of secondary state level data, this study will examine perinatal care, maternal outcomes, and healthcare utilization of Black women at increased risk of severe maternal morbidity and mortality compared with non-Latino white women. Additionally, through individual interviews with Black women and focus groups with obstetric health providers and doulas, the study will examine disparities and improve care by creating and disseminating a set of practice recommendations for maternity care for Black women at increased risk of morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the world, heart disease is a critical problem. The proposed study will investigate the novel roles of a protein named YTHDF3 in the regulation of heart function. This work will improve our understanding of how heart muscle cells maintain their health, guiding the way for the development of new treatments for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will attempt to understand how in patients with a diseased heart valve, the altered blood flow causes changes in the atria and ventricles that makes them more likely to develop an irregular rhythm such as atrial fibrillation or premature ventricular contractions. Understanding these mechanisms will help provide a rationale for determining the appropriate timing of valve surgery. It will also help to decide which patients need treatment such as ablation of their atrial and ventricular irregular rhythms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: BIOSTATISTICS AND BIOINFORMATICS CORE: NARRATIVE The Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core (B&B) Core has three primary responsibilities: 1) development and maintenance of preclinical and clinical database functionality to support all Brain Tumor SPORE Projects; 2) application of bioinformatics pipelines for pre-processing and analysis of high-dimensional omics data to identify novel and significant avenues of research for all four Brain Tumor SPORE projects; and 3) biostatistical contribution to study design, data analysis and interpretation of results for all preclinical and clinical Brain Tumor SPORE Projects to ensure that all reported program accomplishments undergo rigorous evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Hearing loss is a major health problem that significantly affects the life quality of affected individuals. Many forms of hearing loss are genetic in origin and affect hair cells, the mechanosensors that convert sound induced vibrations into electrical signals. We propose here to show how the critical mechanosensitive structure of the hair cell is assembled, and how specific genes control that assembly. This information may eventually help guide therapeutic approaches leading to hearing restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research utilizes a new and technically innovative approach that provides a unique window into the biophysical and morphological bases for variations in the modes of synaptic transmission between vestibular sensory hair cell receptors and their afferent and efferent endings. This research will advance our understanding of the biological bases for dizziness, vertigo, imbalance, and vestibulo-autonomic disorders due to peripheral vestibular dysfunction and will provide a clear direction for future efforts addressing treatment for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Oncogene amplification on extrachromosomal DNA (ecDNA) is common in human cancers and drives rapid tumor evolution and poor outcomes. Despite recent advances characterizing their biology, the mechanisms by which ecDNA promotes tumor evolution are poorly understood. Through powerful combinations of new and established techniques, this project aims to elucidate how ecDNA drives tumor evolution with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The flow dynamics of the erythrocytes (red blood cells) inside the retinal capillaries reflects the function and the health of the retinal microcirculatory system. We will characterize the erythrocyte flow dynamics at the single retinal capillary level in the eyes of human subjects in normal health, in those with essential hypertension, and in those with diabetes, using novel adaptive optics high-speed ophthalmoscopy. This study will improve our knowledge of retinal microcirculation in normal physiological process and systemic disease and facilitate the development of novel treatment strategies for managing systemic complications of hypertension and diabetes that cause vision loss.

PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this project is to develop and implement a surveillance system for antimicrobial resistance of enteric bacteria in retail food outlets in Puerto Rico. The Puerto Rico Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Program’s primary goal is to enhance, strengthen and sustain surveillance for antibiotic resistance in retail food specimens within the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS). Comparison of bacteria isolates recovered from retail food with strains causing human illnesses contributes to improvements in food safety, facilitates outbreak investigations, and provides data to FDA for regulatory oversight.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: MASSACHUSETTS STATE DEPT OF PUB HEALTH
PHR: PAR-20-124 NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Enhance and Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens Massachusetts State Public Health Laboratory Project Narrative MASPHL will participate in this project by purchasing the required 33 products per month from retail locations in Massachusetts. Products will be tested for a combination of analytes as described in the provided protocols for 2022. Confirmed isolates of representative organisms from required products will be sequenced and analyzed, with analysis results shared with FDA via GenomeTrakr by PulseNet certified analysts. Isolates will be sent to FDA NARMS for antimicrobial susceptibility testing along with hard copies of electronic log sheets. Isolates will be retained on-site, along with copies of the log sheets.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Overall Project Narrative This cooperative agreement will enhance the capacity and capabilities of the New Hampshire Public Health Laboratory (NH PHL) in support of an integrated food safety system, with sample testing for food defense and surveillance being performed in all three areas of microbiology, chemistry, and radiochemistry. Human and animal food testing of microbiological and chemical contaminants including salmonella, pathogenic E. coli and toxic metals will be conducted using existing methods accredited by ISO 17025, and novel methods will be developed and expanded to enhance whole genome sequencing, detect cyclospora cayetanensis, allergens and radionuclides in food products. NH PHL will also enter agreements with regulatory agencies in New Hampshire for sample collection, and assist in validation of a novel method EAM 4.12 for the analysis of bottled water by ICP-MS.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: New Hampshire Laboratory Flexible Funding Model for Food Safety (LFFM)(U19)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common, potentially lethal, monogenic disease and is characterized by progressive cyst expansion. This project utilizes robust in vivo methodologies with a novel genetic suppression model of ADPKD to elucidate the emerging role of immune cells in cystogenesis. This proposal is relevant to public health for its potential to establish immunologic targets and signaling in ADPKD pathogenesis and identify noninvasive disease biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing burden of cardiovascular diseases among women under 60 years old is alarming; however, the unique pathophysiological risk factors causing this burden are unknown. Stress likely plays an important role in this early manifestation, potentially through reducing motivation to be physically active. This project will use data from NHLBI-funded study: Mental Stress and Myocardial Ischemia After MI: Sex Differences, Mechanisms and Prognosis (MIMS3) to investigate the role of stress and physical activity in a group of post-MI women and men to understand the importance these factors in this under-investigated population.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Of the 48 million Americans who suffer ~250 different kinds of foodborne illness each year, nearly 128,000 will need hospitalization and 3,000 will ultimately die from these entirely preventable diseases. Technological advances now promise to make large-scale food testing for key threats feasible, thereby intercepting dangerous foods before they enter households, and streamlining food protection strategies of the future. The Maryland public health laboratory has made major investments in its infrastructure over the past ~5 years, and now offers these extensive and proven capabilities to large-scale, multidisciplinary food protection through this cooperative agreement.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Contributing a comprehensive and integrated food protection laboratory hub from Maryland

PHR: Project Narrative The Wisconsin State Laboratory of Hygiene seeks to create a baseline of radiological levels found in Wisconsin’s raw milk and by extension, dairy products through the establishment of a statewide sampling, monitoring, and testing program. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: While heme in red blood cells is essential for transporting oxygen in the bloodstream, freely circulating heme is a cytotoxic threat that drives systemic inflammation and organ failure in sickle cell disease. This proposal tests the hypothesis that heme is also an essential driver of stimulus-evoked and ongoing, non-evoked pain in sickle cell disease. Understanding the role of elevated heme in the maintenance of pain behavior and sensory neuronal hyperexcitability will aid in the development of novel therapies that reduce the immense burden of SCD pain without the punishing side effects of opioids and neuropathic pain medications.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative To inspire a new generation of underrepresented minority (URM) students to pursue research careers in cardiovascular disease (CVD) and related comorbidities, we propose a five-year, disparities-focused research training program for undergraduate college students from the United States Virgin Islands (USVI). An eight- week intensive summer research institute, the Cardiovascular Research Empowerment Workforce (CREW) aims to advance health equity by supporting the training and career development of the next cadre of underrepresented minoritized researchers. As the USVI is a designated health professional shortage area, the proposed program will strengthen the local healthcare infrastructure by preparing emerging scholars to conduct evidence-based research within the local healthcare context, succeed in graduate school, and pursue a cardiovascular-focused research career in the USVI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human congenital eye abnormalities are frequently caused by mutations in genes encoding DNA-binding transcription factors (TFs) and various components of signal transduction pathways. Mutations in TF PAX6 cause human aniridia, a panocular disease that displays absence or hypoplasia of iris together with abnormalities in all major eye tissues, including the cornea, lens and retina. The microphthalmia, anophthalmia and coloboma (MAC) ocular syndrome includes over 30 genes. Amongst them, PAX6, SOX2 and retinoic acid (RA) signaling play prominent roles in eye development. However, the molecular mechanisms and function of individual missense and nonsense mutations in PAX6 and SOX2 genes remain unknown and use of vitamin A offers correction of some of these abnormalities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social Determinants of Health have repeatedly been shown to have a significant impact on physical and mental health outcomes and may be a key driver of population level health disparities. This investigation seeks to understand how primary care providers understand, evaluate, and seek to address these social conditions in the outpatient primary care context. The overarching goal is to improve primary care management of patients with complex social conditions in such a way that appreciates and addresses the influence of multiple factors on the provision of social care in the clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a worldwide health problem that increases the risk for hypertension and cardiovascular disease; however, the molecular mechanisms connecting obesity with hypertension and optimal therapies to lower blood pressure in this disease remain unclear. This proposal will test the hypothesis that angiotensin-(1-7), a protective hormone of the renin-angiotensin system, engages inhibitory signaling pathways within the hypothalamus of the brain to lower blood pressure in obesity hypertension using innovative transgenic mouse models combined with gold standard physiological, pharmacological and molecular approaches. The findings from this proposal will provide new insight into how angiotensin-(1-7) interacts with the brain to lower blood pressure as well as the potential for targeting Ang-(1-7) as a new treatment for obesity hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 10% of patients using current hypertensive therapies show resistance to these treatments, leading to uncontrolled blood pressure and increased adverse outcomes. As phospholipase C (PLC) activity is at the core of hypertensive signaling, the proposed research will identify which isoforms of diacylglycerol kinase and phospholipase D regulate PLC signaling through phosphatidic acid production. Therefore, this project is relevant to public health as it will aid in the discovery of isoform-specific antihypertensive targets that are less susceptible to resistance.
