IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adaptive immune system is responsible for mounting responses to specific pathogens based on previous encounters, known as immunological memory, which can provide long-lasting protection. This project will investigate a critical way in which genetics can influence the ability of our immune system to distinguish what is foreign from what is self. Such studies are essential to understand how vaccine responses may differ between individuals, and serve as a potential basis for effectively designing personalized immunization strategies to increase vaccine efficacy for diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes technology, such as insulin pumps and continuous glucose monitoring devices, can help improve glucose control for people with type 1 diabetes (T1D), which keeps them at lower risk for diabetes complications, but many Latinx adolescents, who make up the largest marginalized ethnic group of youth with T1D in California, use these devices less often and have less optimal glucose control compared to White youth. The goals of this project are to work directly with Latinx youth, their families, and diabetes care team members in California to develop DREAM, Device use Reimagined through Education And Mentorship, a virtual peer group (VPG) intervention that will encourage and support the use of diabetes devices in Latinx adolescents with T1D. With these stakeholders, the researchers will design and pilot test the feasibility of DREAM, and the results of the study will be used to improve the use of diabetes technology and clinical and patient-centered outcomes for Latinx youth with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Columbia University Senescence Tissue Mapping (CUSTMAP) Center is a highly collaborative effort that builds upon long-standing and established collaborations between Columbia University Irving Medical Center (CUIMC), The University of Edinburgh, New York University (NYU), and the New York Genome Center (NYGC). Using state-of-the-art spatial genomics technologies and drawing upon tissues available from a diverse patient population in Upper Manhattan, CUSTMAP will generate three-dimensional maps of senescent cells in healthy tissues from the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) and the skin. The experimental approaches, workflow, and computational tools implemented by CUSTMAP provide a unique platform for driving transformative discoveries of novel molecular, cellular, and regional correlates of age-related changes in cellular senescence in human tissues, which can be generalized to other tissue types and efficiently shared with and deployed across the SenNet Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are double-membrane bound organelles that perform many cellular functions, including the generation of energy via respiration. Spatial organization of the mitochondrial inner membrane is crucial for efficient energy production, though the mechanisms that generate mitochondrial architecture are poorly understood. The proposed work will determine the mechanistic and functional roles of the evolutionarily- conserved MICOS complex, a key modulator of mitochondrial morphology, and identify novel regulators of its function with the long-term goal of identifying therapeutic approaches to alleviate diseases with underlying mitochondrial dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative The field of precision oncology continues to evolve with the overarching goal of providing cancer patients with enhanced diagnostic/prognostic capabilities and efficacious treatments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Individuals at risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease that are amyloid-β positive, but are still cognitively normal, exhibit a characteristic change in brain connectivity prior to the onset of clinical symptoms. However, the cause for these changes in brain connectivity are still unknown. In this proposal, I will use state-of-the-art neuroimaging techniques, such as in vivo two-photon microscopy, wide-field optical imaging, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy, to investigate changes in neuronal and glutamate activity and its impact on network connectivity response to amyloid-β exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hispanics adults with type 1 diabetes (T1D), despite their disproportionate burden of acute complications (hypoglycemia and diabetes ketoacidosis) and related emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and death, remain largely disenfranchised from continuous glucose monitoring (CGM), an efficacious technology to mitigate these inequities. To increase CGM uptake in low-income, Hispanic adults with T1D receiving diabetes management in federally qualified health centers (FQHCs), the proposed mixed-methods study, with a pilot randomized control trial (RCT), will assess the feasibility of our study protocol, including our multi-level intervention informed by the Socio-Ecological Model. If the proposed multi-level intervention is found to be feasible and RCT findings indicate the intervention, relative to the control condition, shows promise, we anticipate a large-scale, multi-site RCT to follow to provide rigorous evidence in favor of our CGM intervention model to improve T1D outcomes in vulnerable Hispanic adults receiving diabetes care in FQHCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Randomized controlled trials are the gold-standard for studying diseases and treatments but have many limitations including significant expense, limited generalizability, and small cohorts that are inadequate for studying subgroups. Electronic health records data contain rich data on large and representative cohorts, but they are susceptible to bias due to their observational and uncontrolled nature. We will develop new computational tools integrate these datasets and harness their distinct advantages, enabling us to study patient groups who weren’t included in major clinical trials and promote greater equity in healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) and Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) are paradigmatic cancers of the blood system that have dismal clinical outcome and cure rates have not improved in 50 years for the majority of patients. Research has shown the existence and critical role of pre-leukemic stem cells (preL-SC) and their subclonal complexity in MDS and AML pathogenesis, progression, and therapeutic resistance. The proposed research will study preL-SC subclonal complexity in patient samples and murine models, identify mechanisms of transcriptional dysregulation governing preL-SC, and test novel pharmacological approaches directly targeting preL-SC-relevant mechanisms in MDS, AML, and related pre-malignant conditions.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative FDA Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (U19) Cooperative Agreement, FOA PAR-20-105 The proposed projects that will be performed within California Department of Public Health, Food and Drug Laboratory Branch will greatly enhance the capacity and capabilities of California's human and animal food testing to support the State integrated food safety system. The application includes multiple tracks under Microbiology, Chemistry, and Special Projects disciplines. These projects, when properly funded, will provide quick emergency response testing and surge capacity in large scale events, produce large amount of data through surveillance activities to find contamination trends and identify emerging issues for food supplies, and expand the methodologies, types of analytes, and food matrices through method development and validation activities.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens in Texas and Oklahoma PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this study is to determine the prevalence of antimicrobial resistance among Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli and Enterococcus isolated from retail samples of chicken, turkey, beef and pork and from Enterococcus, Vibrio, Aeromonas and lactose fermenting bacteria from seafood purchased from grocery stores in Texas and Oklahoma using standardized methods so comparisons can be made to other national locations participating in the cooperative agreement. Achieving this goal will contribute to our understanding of the burden and magnitude of antibiotic resistant bacteria, in retail meat, poultry and seafood products distributed in the South-Central United States. Specifically, the results of this project will provide isolates for further characterization by national monitoring programs as well as novel sequencing data to support risk assessments, develop models and guidelines for antimicrobial stewardship, and create regional and national mitigation and control strategies to combat the spread and potential dangers derived from antimicrobial resistant (AMR) and multidrug resistant (MDR) foodborne pathogens that are present at the terminal end of the food supply.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens in Texas and Oklahoma

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to elucidate the role of the lipid droplet and PLIN2 in the initiation and maintenance of the senescence phenotype. This work is significant as PLIN2 has clearly been shown to modulate inflammatory states but its ability to regulate the proinflammatory phenotype of senescence has yet to be established. By focusing on this novel niche in senescence, this proposal will lay the groundwork establishing PLIN2 and the LD as central to senescence and its associated inflammatory secretome, thus unveiling a novel mechanism by which senescence contributes to tissue dysfunction.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Drug-resistant bacterial infections pose a serious and growing public health threat globally. The primary goal of our continued participation in the NARMS retail food surveillance program is to improve the detection and surveillance for antimicrobial resistance among enteric bacteria in raw retail meat commodities and seafood by providing data obtained from select stores in the state of Washington. Data obtained from investigations conducted by the lab will assist in developing pre-approval safety evaluation of new animal antibiotics, determining parameters for the antimicrobial use in veterinary medicine, and the ability of public health and partners to provide information for the development of new interventions to reduce resistance among foodborne bacteria. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Washington State Public Health Laboratories NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program Application 2021-2022. Retail Meat Surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Massachusetts, Boston (UMass Boston) and Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) Partnership is committed to further developing a shared rigorous and collaborative transdisciplinary cancer and disparities-related research program that is primed for “Bridging the Divides: Innovations to Address Gaps in Cancer Disparities Research, Education, Outreach and Infrastructure.” Sophisticated research projects are proposed across several areas of basic biomedical and population sciences that will employ evidence and methods to converge upon and impact cancer and cancer health disparities at multiple levels of analysis. These projects, together with state-of-the-art Outreach and Research Education Cores and creative Research Design and Analysis Core and Genomics Cores, will serve to build research capacity and infrastructure at UMass Boston, expand the cancer disparities platform and community outreach programs at DF/HCC; and make, at an elevated level, significant advances to the science of cancer control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: Seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) is a prophylactic antimalarial regimen of sulfadoxine- pyrimethamine (SP) and amodiaquine (AQ) recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for preventing malaria episodes in children under 5 years of age in highly seasonal transmission settings. The purpose of the proposed study is to assess for potential long-term impact of SMC on malaria severity and immune response among children after they quit SMC program through a longitudinal cohort study. The study will provide data on the effectiveness of SMC in relation with compliance and valuable information on the burden of malaria when children are no longer in the program. It will also contribute to understanding the underlying biological basis of potential rebound of severe malaria and anemia after SMC and evidence basis for pursuing SMC strategy beyond current target age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will utilize Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) to optimize smoking cessation treatment for HIV clinical care by directly targeting patient barriers to quitting and clinical care barriers to reaching and effectively treating a broad heterogeneous population of smokers living with HIV. Given that over 75% of the 1.2 million persons living with HIV in the U.S. receive HIV clinical care annually, the results of this study will have a significant public health impact by optimizing a cost-effective, sustainable and immediately scalable smoking cessation package tailored specifically for the HIV clinical care context. Findings will also add to scientific knowledge by providing a clear basis for further improvement of cessation interventions for smokers living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Novel mass spectrometry-based technologies will be developed to create molecular atlases of the mouse brain impacted by Alzheimer’s Disease and healthy control. The proposed innovations in mass spectrometry imaging and single-cell mass spectrometry measurements and multiscale data fusion, in combination with unique mouse models of Alzheimer’s Disease, will reveal the temporal and spatial signatures of neuronal vulnerability in Alzheimer’s Disease and the effects of hippocampal neurogenesis on disease progression. The spatially and chemically resolved molecule portrait of healthy and Alzheimer’s Disease impacted brains will help elucidate the molecular mechanisms of disease progression and identify new biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: ASEHL Project Narrative-Overall SFY21-25 By maintaining and enhancing ISO/IEC 17025 for food testing, the Alaska State Environmental Health Laboratory (ASEHL) will continue to deliver both scientifically valid and legally defensible data to its clients. The clients, including the Alaska Food Safety and Sanitation (FSS) Program and U.S. FDA, will benefit by receiving enhanced customer service, consistent turnaround times, and little to no down time. Accreditation allows ASEHL to satisfy Standard 10 of the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) as the primary designated testing facility for the Food Safety and Sanitation Program (FSS). FSS is in full conformance to MRFPS standards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lowe syndrome is a lethal disease characterized by cataracts at birth, mental retardation and kidney problems that unfortunately lead to early death of affected children. Although this genetic condition was described almost 70 years ago, there is no specific treatment against available to patients. However, this project will change that scenario by testing 4 candidate drugs (including FDA-approved compounds) capable of restoring activity to some Lowe syndrome protein patient variants and reverting cellular phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing is used commonly in early detection programs for prostate cancer, a single test result may be unreliable due to the tendency of PSA levels to fluctuate (both biological and analytical variation). False-positive PSA elevations are a cause of significant concern that may lead to anxiety, unnecessary antibiotic use, additional and costly clinical-work up with imaging, and/or risky, invasive prostate biopsies. We will analyze blood samples and clinical data from the world's largest randomized trials of prostate cancer screening and treatment—the United States Prostate, Lung, Colorectal, and Ovarian (PLCO) Cancer Screening Trial, the Swedish Göteborg population-based screening trials (Göteborg-1 and Göteborg-2), and the United Kingdom's Prostate Testing for Cancer and Treatment (ProtecT) trial—as well as biomarker and clinical data from the Multiethnic Cohort (MEC), to better understand these fluctuations in PSA levels, how to distinguish between aggressive and insignificant prostate cancers, and when to perform prostate biopsy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall) To protect the public health during a nuclear or radiological event the FDA provides protective action guidance for food and animal feeds to limit radiation dose from consumption (FDA 1998) If an event releasing alpha and/or beta emitting major dose contributing nuclide(s) happens, a high load of food samples will need to be screened for the alpha and/or beta emitters to assist official with making decision to protective public health (Cunningham 2014). For this purpose, the Illinois Emergency Management Agency seeks to develop its capacity and capability in screening of alpha and beta emitters in foods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop new 30-MHz, high-frequency ultrasound, plane-wave CMUT row-column instrumenta- tion and signal-processing techniques to determine subtle changes in complex intracardiac blood ﬂow patterns in mouse models of cardiovascular disease. Progressive changes to ﬂow characteristics in transverse aortic con- striction mouse models of cardiomyopathy will be analyzed for ﬂow disruption prior to and during the development of left ventricle hypertrophy or dilatation and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Pennsylvania Telehealth Research Center in Cancer Care (Penn TRC) will apply insights from communication science and behavioral economics to design and test synchronous telehealth strategies, supported by asynchronous elements, to improve effectiveness and equity across the cancer care continuum, with an emphasis on understanding mechanisms of action. We focus on lung cancer as an exemplar model for telehealth across the care continuum, from screening to treatment to survivorship. The Penn TRC will produce new fundamental knowledge with the potential to transform cancer care delivery, equity, and outcomes for millions of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop new tools for integrative analysis of relationships among brain imaging measures. Despite the rise of multi-modal imaging studies and the proliferation of derived measures available from each modality, very little work has explored relationships between modalities. The methods developed as part of this proposal will fill this critical gap in the field, and yield biomarkers of both healthy brain development and abnormalities related to executive dysfunction in youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis, the body’s response to a bloodstream infection, is often life-threatening. Timely administration of appropriate antimicrobials is critical for successfully patient outcomes. However, current diagnostics for identifying and characterizing the infection, necessary for selection of the appropriate antimicrobial, rely on blood culture and require several days to provide results. As a consequence, physicians have to rely on empirical treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics, which may be ineffective to the patient’s infection, exposes patients to the risk of complications, and exemplifies poor antibiotic stewardship. The efforts described in this proposed Phase II program will advance the maturity of a novel, fully automated test capable of characterizing clinically important resistance mechanisms in bloodstream infections in only a few hours and without cultures. Success in this effort will result in a diagnostic device addressing a significant unmet need, ready for transfer to manufacturing and verification & validation for FDA clearance and market launch.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Funding Opportunity PAR-21-174 Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food, and Forestry  Project Narrative  The Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food, and Forestry will be able to reduce the potential threat to public health from ready-to-eat fruit and vegetables by developing, implementing and maintaining an Oklahoma Produce Safety Program that is in alignment with the FDA Regulation “Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption,” otherwise known as the Produce Safety Rule. This program will provide outreach to growers of ready-to-eat fruits and vegetables to educate and provide guidance concerning food safety issues associated with the growing of ready-to-eat produce and the regulatory requirements of the Produce Safety Rule. This combination of outreach and regulatory oversight should significantly reduce the risk of foodborne illness associated with the consumption of ready-to-eat produce.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Path C Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food, and Forestry Cooperative Agreement Program with FDA to Implement a National Produce Safety Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, we propose to employ a novel strategy to convert endogenous reactive glial cells to new neurons (also called reprogramming) for functional recovery after spinal cord injury (SCI). We hypothesize that reprogramming reactive glial cells to local new neurons may promote self-repair by the formation of new neural circuits for functional recovery. To test this hypothesis, three specific aims are proposed to determine 1) the functional integration of reprogrammed neurons; 2) the anatomical integration of reprogrammed neurons into local neural circuitry; and 3) the functional roles of descending supraspinal and/or propriospinal pathways over reprogrammed neurons in promoting forelimb functional recovery in a model of cervical 5 dorsal hemisection (C5 DH).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Angiogenesis is a dangerous and often visually devastating feature of many ocular pathologies, including corneal neovascularization, and pathologic angiogenesis also contributes to a variety of other diseases including cancer, heart disease, and arthritis. CMG2 inhibitors dramatically reduce pathologic angiogenesis in the cornea, but the role of CMG2 signaling in angiogenesis is not well understood. We recently discovered that CMG2 is required for endothelial cell chemotaxis, and here we propose to determine the mechanism by which CMG2 mediates the migration toward a growth factor source that is required for angiogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) is a substantial health problem that with a prevalence of 18% is the second highest cause of work-related diseases in the USA. There is an unmet need for more specific immunotherapies to treat ACD, which is caused by intricate interactions among neuro-mediators, skin resident cells, and migratory leukocytes. The present application proposes to investigate relevant mechanisms of these cellular and neuroimmune networks to provide fundamental physiopathologic insight for the development of specific immunotherapies for ACD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vision impairment has devastating effects on human perception and quality of life. The major blinding diseases, such as age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and glaucoma, involve the permanent loss of retinal neurons. The proposed research will study neuroprotection mechanisms using advanced molecular and genetic approaches, and test new therapeutic strategies for retinal degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In adults with obesity seeking treatment, weight loss should be composed almost exclusively of fat mass, but loss of lean mass and bone are unintentional consequences of weight loss, which has detrimental effects on health by mitigating improvements in insulin sensitivity, contributing to weight regain by reducing energy expenditure, and increasing the risk of frailty, falls, and fractures. Preclinical and early clinical data suggest that bimagrumab, an investigational new drug for obesity that inhibits the activin type II receptor (ActRII) inhibitor, may be anabolic to muscle and bone. We hypothesize that in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 65 adults with obesity randomized to bimagrumab, semaglutide (which is FDA-approved for weight loss), or placebo, bimagrumab will result in metabolic improvements in muscle, visceral fat, and bone vs. semaglutide or placebo as an adjunct to a lifestyle intervention for weight loss over 52 weeks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide and obesity is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis and other metabolic diseases. My exciting data show that weight loss induced by caloric- restriction promotes resolution and remission of atherosclerosis and I propose to study the underlying mechanisms. My studies will uncover novel pathways responsible for the concomitant resolution of obesity and atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This project will leverage data on Medicare enrollees Parts A, B, and D, air pollution (PM2.5, NO2, and ozone), PM2.5 major components, weather variables, greenness, and multiple ZIP code level Census factors to estimate the link between individual and simultaneous exposure to air pollution, PM2.5 major components, weather and greenness and Parkinson’s Disease (PD) exacerbation of symptoms. We will develop and apply new and existing methods to characterize a complex set of possible effect modifiers and identify multiple risk and protective factors that determine vulnerability in PD, and develop open-source R packages, promoting full transparency and reproducibility of findings across different study populations. This project will provide the foundation to inform actionable policy to help slow the PD disease burden and improve the quality of life for millions of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though it is known that intraoperative hypotension occurs at an alarming frequency in patients at the extremes of age undergoing general anesthesia, the underlying mechanisms thereof remain unclear. In order to prevent the significant morbidity and mortality associated with intraoperative hypotension in this population, it is incumbent upon us to determine unique properties of young and aged individuals that put them at increased risk. We propose to use an integrated in vivo and in vitro approach to determine how vascular mechanisms lead to the increased risk of intraoperative hypotension in this population, allowing identification of organ perfusion - based definitions of hypotension, optimal treatment strategies for when hypotension occurs, and development of safer anesthesia regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because spondyloarthritis is the most common form of childhood arthritis in large parts of the world and there is a critical need for studies to evaluate existing and emerging targeted therapies for this understudied condition as well as physician scientists to conduct them. This project is directly aligned with the program announcement (PA-20-186) as the goals are to expand the training, mentoring, and career development of physician scientists pursuing patient-oriented research in rheumatology and to facilitate the design of efficacy and effectiveness studies of emerging targeted therapies such as inhibitors of the IL-17/IL-23 and JAK-STAT pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Macrophages are powerful cellular components of innate immunity; on the one hand they play a pivotal role in defending against pathogens, cancerous cells and other harmful stimuli by being immunoreactive, and on the other hand, they contribute to tissue homeostasis by being immunotolerant to harmless antigens and beneficial microbes. Too much or too little of either of these two states (immunoreactive vs. tolerant) can serve as triggers and perpetuate diverse human diseases. Using novel computational approaches, we have charted a formal model for macrophage response to infections, and revealed hitherto unknown important genes that regulate the process of macrophage polarization; we plan to identify potential therapeutic targets that can reprogram macrophage response in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication about goals of care is one of the most important aspects of care for patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and their family caregivers, yet the lack of this communication is a major shortcoming in our healthcare system. We propose an NIH Stage III hybrid efficacy-effectiveness randomized trial to evaluate a novel intervention that promotes and enhances goals-of-care discussions for patients with ADRD and their family caregivers. We hypothesize the intervention will improve documentation of goals-of-care discussions and other important patient-centered outcomes for these patients and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proteins-only biomolecular condensates are a crucial part of normal cellular processes and their mis-regulation is at the heart of various pathologies. Unfortunately, current understanding on what sequence motifs promote the assembly of such condensates and the biophysical principles that regulate their composition and dynamics has been limited. Discoveries from this work will provide a framework in fundamental understanding of these condensates and bring new opportunities to prevent, diagnose, and treat condensate-driven diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, cancer clinical research is predominantly performed at academic medical centers, partially due to the operational challenges and limitations of resources at community sites. A core premise of the NCORP network is expanding the reach and execution of cancer control, prevention and cancer care delivery research deeper into community settings which will diversify trial participants and accelerate promising treatments through clinical trials and into broader use. The CROWN Consortium supports the NCORP mission by leveraging a network of community sites throughout Wisconsin and northern Michigan with a shared mission, training, procedures, and clinical resources, and will be able to provide the necessary clinical support to offer improved enrollment numbers and diversity, enhancing study outcomes and reducing disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transcriptional cell states are correlated with clinical outcomes and therapeutic sensitivity in pancreatic cancer, but the mechanisms regulating cell state specification and tumor cell plasticity are not well understood. This research proposal examines the mechanisms by which TGF-β specifies the pancreatic cancer basal cell state, investigates how TGF-β-mediated cellular plasticity drives chemo-resistance in organoid models and serially collected metastatic biopsies analyzed with single-cell RNA-sequencing, and applies pharmacologic and genetic screening techniques in isogenic state-variant pancreatic cancer organoid models to identify cell state-specific therapeutic vulnerabilities. These studies will advance our understanding of how tumor cell states and cellular plasticity regulate therapeutic sensitivity in pancreatic cancer and uncover new avenues for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis claimed 1.5 million lives across the world in 2018. With the rise of multi-drug resistant strains and lack of an effective vaccine for the adult population, tuberculosis remains an important public health concern. In this proposal, we aim to investigate lipid-based memory immune response and its potential role in protection in tuberculosis infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a prevalent disorder characterized by visceral (e.g., abdominal) pain and disordered motility (e.g., constipation and/or diarrhea) for which there are limited effective treatments. Serotonin (5-HT) in the gastrointestinal tract is thought to play a role in these symptoms; most 5-HT is produced in the intestinal epithelium, but it is unknown how 5-HT released from the epithelium influences surrounding nerves to initiate visceral pain and/or gut motility. The proposed experiments will investigate how decreasing or increasing epithelial 5-HT availability impacts visceral pain and gut motility, which will help to determine potential new epithelial-restricted targets for IBS treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of heart failure is increasing and deadly with 50% of patients dying within 5 years of diagnosis. I propose to test a novel hypothesis that excessive carbohydrate modification of heart proteins (O-GlcNAcylation) activates a powerful pro-growth pathway (YAP) to cause heart failure. If affirmed, this hypothesis may serve as a basis for new and improved heart failure therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Children with Crohn’s disease (CD) often have low bone mineral density (BMD) and altered bone structure, resulting in increased skeletal fragility and increased risk of fracture. The goals of this project are to examine adolescents with newly-diagnosed CD at baseline and one year later to evaluate the impact of CD inflammatory activity on bone marrow fat, BMD, bone turnover markers, and to correlate with peripheral blood immune parameters. This project has the potential to improve clinical care with new screening tools (i.e., magnetic resonance imaging) to identify patients at the highest risk for bone fragility, ideally prior to fracture; investigate novel measures of CD activity (i.e., bone turnover markers and immune cell and molecular signatures); and provide insights into potential new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Health care research has extensively studied pathogenesis or disease progression, but little is known about the complementary process of salutogenesis, or health restoration. This project will examine biochemical and functional changes associated with the reversal of age-related cognitive decline in mice, as a result of treatment with exercise and/or a botanical extract. Results will be used to design a computational model for future application to the study of multiple interventions on multiple body systems in animal or human studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Although the importance of a diverse biomedical science workforce is widely appreciated, individuals from under-represented minority groups continue to comprise a disproportionately small percentage of biomedical researchers in this country. Inspiring undergraduate science teachers can reverse this pattern, but too few scientists are trained as teachers, and even fewer are attuned to the needs of diverse student populations. By combining mentored postdoctoral research at The University of Pennsylvania with training in pedagogy and mentored teaching experiences at partnering minority-serving institutions, the PennPORT IRACDA program trains outstanding researchers and teachers and enhances educational opportunities for students at partner institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This K01 application proposes the development and testing of an interpretable, neurobiologically-inspired integration scheme for multimodal neuroimaging measures to investigate antidepressant treatment outcome in late-life depression (LLD). Training in 1) the neurobiology, clinical manifestations, and treatment of LLD, 2) diffusion-weighted imaging processing and analysis, 3) advanced methods, 4) human subjects, study design, and data collection will enable the applicant to complete the proposed research and progress to an independent investigator focused on investigating the neurobiology of late life anxiety and mood disorders through improved integration of multimodal neuroimaging measures. The goal of this proposal is to integrate complementary network measures from structural and functional MRI with clinical measures to generate biologically relevant features that can improve prediction of treatment outcome in LLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interface between cannabis use and stress is a particularly important focus for sex differences research in emerging adults. Given the dynamics at play in this critical stage when cannabis use is most prevalent, developmentally informed research is needed to guide tailored clinical interventions. We propose a study applying rigorous and innovative methods to elucidate sex differences in the nexus of cannabis use and stress among emerging adults with cannabis use disorder to guide the development of tailored treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adaptive Motif-Based Control (AMBC): A Fundamentally New Approach to Automated Treatment Optimization for Type 1 Diabetes This application comes from the developers of the UVA Automated Insulin Delivery (AID) System, which in 2012 was the first wearable artificial pancreas running on a smart phone, and in 2017 was built in Tandem’s t:slim X2 insulin pump to become Control-IQ – an AID system now used by over 270,000 people with diabetes worldwide. After this successful clinical translation, our academic mandate now is to open new horizons, design and test a new class of AID algorithms –Adaptive Motif-Based Control (AMBC)– which uses innovative adaptation-to-profile process to modulate the UVA-AID individual parameters for a person, by learning from this person’s CGM and insulin delivery patterns, and from the patterns of others stored in population databases; thus, unlike any other AID algorithm, the AMBC will use both a person’s own history and the history of others, to forecast and adapt to metabolic disturbances. The AMBC is expected to (i) be superior to current state-of-the-art AID systems in terms of glycemic outcomes and technology acceptance, and (ii) enable the transition from hybrid to full closed loop.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While most women who use cannabis will reduce their cannabis use during pregnancy, almost all women will return to cannabis use postpartum. Stress and progesterone may play important roles in the return to postpartum cannabis use but longitudinal investigations are needed to examine the relationships between stress, progesterone and return to cannabis use in postpartum women. The proposed study will help to inform the develop of gender-specific, targeted interventions that prevent postpartum return to cannabis use and improve women’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: To achieve optimal replication, HIV-1 encodes viral ‘accessory” proteins to that manipulate the host cell. Understanding the mechanisms by which host proteins targeted by the accessory protein Vpr repress HIV-1 replication, and how and why viral proteins such as Vpr deplete particular host proteins will provide new insights into the regulation of HIV-1 gene expression, regulation of cell cycle and regulation of innate immunity. This understanding may present new targets for eliminating reservoirs of HIV-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune response is highly active in ovarian cancer, but ovarian tumors do not respond well to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB). We propose to investigate whether inhibition of DNA damage repair by blocking the function of the protein phosphatase 4 complex during chemotherapy will increase immunogenicity in ovarian cancer and enhance response to ICB. Ultimately, such knowledge has the potential to inform the development of new therapies benefiting many types of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis is the most frequently used illicit substance by older adults, and its use among persons ages 50+ is rising. Little is known about the potential harms of cannabis use in this population such as its impact on cognitive decline and risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, and whether sex differences in stress and hormones influence these risks. We therefore propose to study regular cannabis-using older men and women to answer these questions to inform public health messaging regarding cannabis use and to identify potential clinical interventions for older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legalization of cannabis products for recreational use has increased rates of cannabis use and Cannabis Use Disorder across multiple vulnerable groups, including adolescents/young adults, pregnant women, and older adults. Despite legalization, the neurobiological impacts of acute and chronic cannabis use, and how they are affected by sex and age, largely remain uninvestigated. In this proposal, and the associated Clinical Projects 1- 3, we will investigate how the active components of cannabis impact learning and memory, relapse behavior, and brain function at the molecular level in vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Choosing the wrong health insurance plan could put patients at risk for poor health and economic outcomes, especially for patients with a chronic disease like diabetes. This study will use health economic research methods to assess patient preferences for health plans and the relationship between enrollment in a preference-aligned health plan and health care outcomes. Future research will develop a decision aid based on study findings to help guide patients toward a health plan that will improve their outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multi-level, multi-component longitudinal, mixed-methods study incorporates an intersectional lens in the examination of how intersectional minority stress and Black sexual and gender minority (SGM)-specific protective factors affect active suicide ideation over time, day-to-day, and within specific contexts both within and between populations of Black SGM youth. Participants will include 625 Black SGM youth aged 13 to 26 who will complete an online survey every three months over an 18-month period to examine moderating effects of Black SGM-specific individual and community protective factors on theoretical pathways of suicide risk, including intersectional minority stress, over time, with a subset of 450 completing one of three burst daily diary surveys to identify proximal correlates of suicide risk, including protective factors, and a subset of 180 completing an individual interview to explore in-depth effects of contextual factors on suicide risk among Black SGM youth. This research will help address social injustices that characterize mental health disparities among Black SGM youth by identifying novel, modifiable Black SGM-specific individual and community protective factors, and effects of structural factors on the experience of intersectional minority stress and suicide risk, that will inform the development of a culturally relevant theory of suicide risk and future tailored, strengths-based suicide prevention interventions for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid advances in laboratory technology and digital healthcare have created a new discipline that uses genetic information to individualize patient care. The Vanderbilt Genomic Medicine (VGM) Training Program at Vanderbilt University Medical Center trains MD and PhD post-doctoral fellows to become knowledgeable with the science and practice of genomic medicine. The program teaches research design and analytic techniques with the ability to apply these methods in a clinical setting to advance patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The emergence and spread of drug-resistant HIV is a major threat to ending the global HIV epidemic. HIV treatment programs across the world are transitioning to integrase strand transfer inhibitors. We propose establishing a global early HIV drug resistance detection system within the International epidemiology Databases to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA) and the Antiretroviral Therapy Cohort Collaboration (ART-CC). In this study, we will develop a better understanding of how dolutegravir resistance emerges in different HIV subtypes and different clinical contexts, and how genotypic resistance affects phenotypic susceptibility to dolutegravir.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer ranks as the second leading cause of death in men and women of all age groups in the U.S., and currently 1 out of 4 death in the U.S. is due to cancer. The severe adverse effects due to many anti-cancer therapeutic strategies currently in use are associated with their undesired effects on healthy, non-cancer cells. This project, therefore, is directed toward understanding cellular and molecular mechanisms that will help develop a specific cancer therapy that only kills tumor cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Due to very high numbers of child exposure to Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) especially among African American women, coupled with devastating effects of IPV exposure on child psychosocial outcomes, there is a critical need to prevent the adverse effects of traumatic exposures on psychosocial outcomes in the context of health disparities. The proposed work has the potential to provide the first culturally sensitive, evidence-and community-based intervention that simultaneously addresses the needs of African American women and children affected by IPV, and which can be scaled up due to high affordability and low requirements for educational and clinical background of paraprofessional caseworkers. Once the efficacy of the MISC-IPV intervention has been tested and proven, it will have the potential to be adapted and used to address other public health epidemics across the country that are impeding supportive parenting and positive child development, such as families in which one or both parents are substance abusers, have serious mental illness or other disabilities, and/or are absent from the home due, for example, to incarceration or death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE We will conduct a comprehensive analysis assessing the impact of policies regulating electronic nicotine delivery systems (e-cigarettes, or ENDS) on the use of ENDS, combustible tobacco, and cannabis. In particular, we will assess whether these policies differentially affect youth, young adult, and adult use and we will project the impact of policy changes on health outcomes. These complementary analyses will address the vital need for a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of ENDS control policies and will be disseminated to key stakeholders, guidingthe implementation of policies that will maximize population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to design, test, and optimize a novel wireless recording array for a neural speech prosthetic. Patients with various types of motor disorders such as Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Locked-in- Syndrome (LOS) can have difficulty or an inability to communicate. We aim to restore this ability by reading signals directly from the brain and translating them into speech. We will design and test novel high density, high channel-count electrodes to read from the brain at an unprecedented spatial scale. We will also develop wireless technology to enable this speech translation during everyday usage. With our advanced technology for reading the brain, we aim to literally give a voice to the voiceless.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Long-acting antiretroviral agents are expected to substantially improve the care of people living with HIV-1 by mitigating a number of pressing problems that include the necessity of daily administration of current HIV- 1 medications, suboptimal treatment adherence, and emergence of drug-resistant viral variants. The highly potent HIV-1 capsid inhibitor GS-6207 is an investigational principal component of long-acting antiretroviral therapy. We propose to study structural and mechanistic bases for the antiviral activity of GS-6207 and rationally develop second-generation compounds with a higher barrier to drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, systemic infections with antibiotic resistant organisms often result from resident gut bacteria and are associated with an extremely high mortality rate. Despite the significant burden of multidrug-resistant infections, knowledge of how antibiotic resistance is acquired or disseminated in gut bacteria and contributes to the development of systemic infections is limited. This study will use novel next- generation sequencing of the gut flora to understand the antimicrobial resistance gene dynamics that may increase the risk of bloodstream infections in patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: BEAMS NARRATIVE Childhood asthma leaves millions of children gasping for air and causes over two-hundred thousand hospitalizations each year, but we have no way to prevent it or cure it. In the Binational Early Asthma and Microbiome Study (BEAMS), we will determine which are the environmental microbes and their products present in the border city of Nogales, Mexico, that cause children born there to have four times less asthma than Mexican American children born in Tucson Arizona, just seventy miles north of the border. We will also determine the differences in microbial communities present in stools at both sides of the border, and the immune responses that asthma-protective microbes induce in both young children and mice, with the goal of using all this information to find ways to prevent asthma in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In ICU patients ventilation is carried out by a machine, to facilitate oxygen uptake in the lungs, and the respiratory muscles become inactive. However, mechanical ventilation is a two-edged sword: during mechanical ventilation the diaphragm – the main respiratory muscle - rapidly weakens and prolonged mechanical ventilation is required. The goal of this proposal is to understand why the diaphragm is so extremely sensitive to inactivity during mechanical ventilation, and it will test the novel concept that super-relaxed myosins and the giant elastic muscle protein titin play a central role.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IgE-mediated mast cell activation is widely thought to be detrimental in venom allergy and other allergic disorders, but recent research indicates that mast cells and IgE paradoxically can contribute to protective immunity against the toxicity of honeybee and other animal venoms. This proposal seeks to identify and characterize genetic modifiers that differentiate detrimental vs. beneficial functions of mast cell- or IgE/mast cell-associated immune responses in venom allergy. This project may uncover novel regulatory pathways that can be harnessed to ameliorate or prevent mast cell activation induced by insect venoms, medicines or foods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer is age as evidenced by the peak incidence at age 70 and older, which are largely estrogen receptor (ER) positive disease. ER+ breast cancers in the elderly are both clinically and biologically distinct from ER+ tumors in younger patients suggesting that these patients may benefit from different therapies. The proposed study will utilize molecular techniques and breast cancer models including matched patient tumor and plasma samples, patient derived organoids, and syngeneic rat models to examine the unique microenvironment and altered ER signaling in the elderly that could ultimately lead to improved diagnosis, outcomes, and therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Proper control of DNA methylation is essential for normal embryo development, alterations of which underlie a broad range of structural birth defects. We discovered specific functions for TET enzymes to keep DNA unmethylated during early stages of embryogenesis and also a previously unstudied protein called QSER1 that cooperates with TETs to regulate early developmental control genes. We propose genetic and biochemical experiments to determine the relative contributions of these factors to DNA methylation dynamics in order to understand fundamental mechanisms regulating early stages of organogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Gene therapy is a highly promising approach for the treatment of retinal blinding diseases, however, safe, efficient, and controlled gene delivery to the retina, particularly in the macula, remains a significant challenge. This project will develop an innovative biocompatible retinal-adhesive gel loaded with next-generation viral vectors as a new approach for safe and efficient targeting of photoreceptors and RPE via focal epiretinal gene delivery. As proof of concept, this novel gene therapy delivery system will be used to treat two well- characterized canine models of human retinal degeneration diseases: NPHP5-LCA and RPE65-LCA2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is a rapidly growing public health issue, but the role of subcortical structures in disease initiation and progression are not adequately understood. By combining electrophysiology, transcriptomics, and morphological analysis, we aim to identify adaptations that occur in single dopamine neurons in a model of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The results will lay the groundwork for future studies identifying novel therapeutic targets for preventing or slowing AD related deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Diabetes technology is advancing at a rapid pace, but large disparities in the use of continuous glucose monitors, insulin pumps, and automated insulin delivery systems exist for Non-Hispanic Black patients with type 1 diabetes. There are many barriers to technology use in minority patients, and culturally-sensitive, effective solutions are needed. Based on feedback from patients and families with lived experience as minorities with diabetes, we will develop and evaluate an intervention utilizing 1) remote monitoring of technology use with diabetes management assistance and 2) personal support by a community health worker who will serve as diabetes technology coach to address barriers to sustained technology use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis affects up to 3% of all children with >20,000 children undergoing major spinal fusion surgery annually at a cost of $5 billion. Identification of patients at risk for scoliosis curve progression or serious comorbidities is needed to implement prevention strategies but is hindered by lack of data from underrepresented minorities, including African Americans. In this project, we are setting a new research direction for our competitive renewal by proposing to study scoliosis in diverse populations and to improve genetic variant interpretation for all patients using high-throughput functional genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to identify the impact of fixational eye movements on neural representations in visual cortex in the central visual field. Over 9 million Americans have central vision loss from age-related macular degeneration. Results from this proposal will build a fundamental understanding of how retinal signals from the fovea are processed by visual cortex during natural visual behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to improve encapsulated cell survival, a major barrier to translating immunosuppression-free islet transplantation to the wider insulin-dependent diabetic population. It also aims to provide a monitoring tool for encapsulated cell health. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission as it focuses on restoring native insulin signaling to type 1 diabetes patients, with the potential to eliminate secondary complications of diabetes which impact hundreds of thousands of Americans per year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The sensitive period for phonetic learning between 6-12 months is one of the earliest milestones in language acquisition as the speech learning outcome of this period can predict individual language skills up to 6 years of age. The proposed project significantly extends the existing literature which only studied typically developing infants (i.e., Low-Risk), and focuses on infants with a family history of developmental language disorder (i.e., High-Risk). Understanding whether High-Risk infants already exhibit altered neural processes of speech during the sensitive period can not only expand language acquisition theories, but more importantly, help identify early markers of DLD which will further aid in the development of targeted intervention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A public health approach to the management of children and adolescents living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa has increased access to care but there remains a need for differentiated service delivery with intensified treatment and supportive strategies for children at higher risk of adverse outcomes. The clinical predication tools developed in this study will identify children at risk a-priori and avert unnecessary morbidity and mortality. This proposal will also define risk factors for TB disease in children living with HIV, identify those most likely to benefit from TB preventive therapy, and estimate the risk reduction associated with three different preventive therapy approaches; this knowledge will guide the design of prospective studies to investigate shorter tuberculosis preventive therapy regimens and inform evidence based TB preventive therapy strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As age-specific incidence rates of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) decline in the US, due, in part, to improvements in cardiovascular health, it is imperative that we study how favorable cardiovascular health promotes successful brain aging. We will apply advances in the field of neuroimaging to study brain network integrity by constructing maps of neural connections from multi-modal neuroimaging data on non- Latino White, Black, and Latino adults to determine how favorable cardiovascular health preserves brain network integrity, supports cognitive and motor functioning, and relates to ADRD neuropathologic burden. Given brain health is an important component of successful aging (as is reduced cardiovascular disease risk), this project has the potential to improve outcomes in less healthy older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our memories constitute a crucial aspect of our identities and are essential to our ability to function effectively in the world. Motor memories – the library of skills we accumulate over a lifetime of experience and practice – are especially key for our ability to perform the activities of daily life. Despite their importance, relatively little is known about how motor memories are created, then consolidated, in the cerebral cortex, and hence we seek to understand those processes, toward the eventual goal of helping to improve therapeutic approaches for stroke recovery and improvements to brain-computer interface systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will identify windows of fetal susceptibility to particulate air pollution exposure and characterize how air pollution impacts placenta signaling and regulatory mechanisms during mid-pregnancy and at term. Findings will advance our understanding of molecular pathways linking air pollution exposure with adverse pregnancy outcomes, including poor fetal growth, low birthweight and preterm delivery. This significant research advance has the potential to improve pregnancy outcomes by informing interventions focused on reducing exposure during vulnerable developmental windows and identifying early and relatively non-invasive placental biomarkers of air pollution exposure and pregnancy health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance:  Cancer is a complex disease in which multiple genetic, genomic, epigenetic, environmental, and other factors combine to influence one’s risk—and ultimately to mediate disease development and progression. While cancer researchers recognize this complexity, most analytical methods in use have been built around relatively simple approximations that fail to capture the multifactorial nature of cancer. I propose to develop advanced computational methods to explore the regulatory networks that govern cancer development and response to therapies, including differences in men and women.

PROJECT_TITLE: Unraveling the Complexities of Risk and Mechanism in Cancer

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence indicates that individuals with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) often receive suboptimal care at the end of life; however, its underlying causes and the strategies to effectively improve the quality of care at the end of life for ADRD have not been investigated well. Using an innovative database that includes comprehensive information on patient, physician, and health system factors, the investigators will identify key physician and health system factors (with a special focus on mutable factors, e.g., physician training in geriatrics and/or palliative care, and financial incentives targeted at health systems) associated with the quality of care for persons with ADRD at the end of life. This research has the potential to offer novel approaches for unraveling physician- and health system-level determinants of the quality of palliative and end-of-life care for persons with ADRD, and to provide a strong evidence base for developing actionable interventions that can effectively improve the quality of care for persons with ADRD at the end of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The ability to use coarse information about depth is critical to the safe execution of everyday tasks that require eye-hand coordination and navigating through the environment. This is particularly relevant to individuals with amblyopia whose depth perception is compromised because of an impaired ability to combine information from the two eyes. This proposal examines the basis for impaired depth and vision in the central visual field and examines the ability of the peripheral visual field to mediate depth information in amblyopia. These studies have implications for clinical tests that assess depth perception as well as training techniques to improve depth perception in amblyopia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is the leading cause of dementia in the United States. Variants in the apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is strongly associated with the risk of Alzheimer’s disease. In order to understand the molecular mechanisms of Alzheimer's disease and identify targets for therapy, this study will investigate how specific missense variants affect apolipoprotein E and protein interactions using mass spectrometry-based proteomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are wide disparities in home reading routines, kindergarten reading readiness and subsequent abilities, and numerous health outcomes, linked to inequitable access to reliable information and resources. Reading Bees is a new, free mobile application for parents that addresses these by providing clear, evidence-based literacy-related guidance and resources and awards for home reading behaviors, designed to efficiently complement existing pediatric, library and community programs. This 3-year project involves integration of new and enhanced app content (local resources, a Spanish version, LitCoin awards) and then conducting usability testing in three culturally distinct areas (Cincinnati OH, Miami FL, Huntington WV) with families from disadvantaged backgrounds, first in focus groups and then during clinic visits with use measured over 2 months, which will guide refinement and scaling into other areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Chronic Kidney Disease Prognosis Consortium (CKD-PC) was formed in 2009 to focus on improving the lives of patients with CKD. The CKD-PC now includes data on >30 million participants from >100 cohorts spanning >40 countries, and has provided evidence for a global definition of CKD, the acceptance of new surrogate endpoints in clinical trials, and the establishment of important risk tools for use in clinical care. In this renewal, the CKD-PC will build upon previous successes and continue to respond rapidly to changes in health care guidelines, delivery, and regulation to answer high priority questions facing the global CKD population.

PHR: TISCH CANCER INSTITUTE AT THE ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI Principal Investigator/Director: Ramon Parsons, MD, PhD Public Health Relevance Statement: The Tisch Cancer Institute provides an infrastructure to advance basic, clinical and population health cancer research, so as to prevent cancer in healthy individuals and improve the lives of cancer patients and their families in our diverse communities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Nearly one in five American adults who survived the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) are still suffering from post-acute COVID-19 syndrome (PACS), a complex systemic disease that manifests in fatigue and muscle weakness that substantially limits one or more major life activities. For older adults, having PACS coupled with an inadequate diet may compound their health deterioration and hasten their physical function decline. To ameliorate recovery, men and women aged 50 years or older with PACS will be randomized to a 16-week dietary intervention group (N=28) following the ‘Whole-Diet Approach’ based on the new Dietary Guidelines for Americans (DGA 2020-2025) with a focus on the intake of nutrients high in anti-inflammatory activities via foods and/or supplements (e.g., vitamin D, omega-3, whey protein) and will be compared to their counterparts who were randomized to the attention control group (N=28).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE CD8+ cytolytic T cells constitute an important limb of the immune response against tumors. Often, though, CD8+ T cells and their engineered derivatives such as CAR T cells become ‘exhausted’ in the tumor environment, devolving into a state with reduced ability to kill tumor cells. In this project, we will continue our longstanding collaboration to investigate intracellular mechanisms that determine whether a CD8+ T cell will or will not mount an effective immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders are characterized by cognitive abnormalities in offspring exposed to alcohol during pregnancy. One of the most common cognitive deficits in Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders involve impaired learning and memory and altered hippocampal function. A complete understanding of the neural bases of learning and memory deficits in Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders is needed to ultimately identify treatments that may mitigate impacts later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Leveraging multi-omics to maximize the scientific value of pediatric sepsis biorepository and advance patient endotyping. PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Children with sepsis—a life threatening condition due to an abnormal patient response to an infection— represent a mixed group with varying underlying biology. Our incomplete knowledge of disease mechanisms within subgroups of septic patients has prevented the development of the right drugs for the right patients. To address this problem, we seek to use our vast collection of blood samples from children with sepsis to find out whether an understanding of how genes are turned on and off can be used to improve sepsis outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 contains multiple essential components including conserved targets that may be amenable to drug design. Our understanding of HIV structure and how it incorporates its envelope protein has been mostly limited to studies of components in isolation. Here, we will combine cutting edge structural, computational, biochemical, and virologic approaches to reveal how key components interact in a native context within HIV intact virus particles and develop new drugs to block these crucial interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with type 1 diabetes also experience obesity, increasing the risk of future cardiovascular disease. Semaglutide is an anti-obesity medication that improves cardiometabolic risk factors in individuals with type 2 diabetes and obesity. This proposal aims to understand how treatment with semaglutide impacts cardiometabolic risk factors and the driving mechanisms of these risk factors in young people with both type 1 diabetes and obesity.

PHR: Project Narrative Understanding of Hox gene regulation, a central developmental regulatory circuit, through the design, build and delivery of very large engineered variants of the Hox gene cluster is the focus of the proposal. The HoxA cluster controls normal development and is implicated in oncogenesis, and thus this work will enhance understanding and potential engineering of normal development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Phosphatidic acid is a lipid signaling molecule whose aberrant production or accumulation can lead to many diseases, including several types of cancer, neurodegeneration, and susceptibility to infection. This proposal seeks to develop and apply cutting-edge toolsets to understand how cells regulate the production and metabolism of phosphatidic acid to maintain physiological processes that depend on it without tipping the balance away from homeostasis to favor pathological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Because disorders of hunger cause obesity and feeding disorders, it is unfortunate that the neurobiological basis for hunger is so poorly understood. This proposal, by studying the neural activity of hunger-causing AgRP neurons, is discovering previously unknown, feedforward mechanisms by which AgRP neuron activity, and hence hunger, is increased. Uncovering the basis for and function of this feedforward activation of AgRP neurons should provide important new insights in how the motivational drive, hunger, is created.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal gathers cases of brain hemorrhage from around the world to identify the genetic factors that either cause or protect people from brain hemorrhage. The larger the sample size, the greater the power of the study and the investigators plan to increase the analysis from the current largest of roughly 1,500 cases to over 20,000 cases of brain hemorrhage. Specific ethnic groups may be particularly susceptible to brain hemorrhage and our study focuses on these important differences by ethnicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A more diverse and inclusive scientific workforce is a strategy for ensuring that all Americans have access to high-quality, equitable, and effective health care. The proposed INSPIRE-US program aims to ameliorate social forces that have stifled the representation of racial minorities in the clinical and translational science workforce. This evidence informed program leverages best-practices known to promote career interest, research skill development, and the socioemotional support needed for undergraduates who identify as racial minorities to successfully join the clinical and translational science workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: About one fourth of women in the United States experience vaginal dysbiosis, a microbial composition lacking health-associated bacteria Lactobacillus and characterized by an increased susceptibility to vaginal infection. This proposal aims to reveal how a woman’s vaginal microbiome could naturally transition into dysbiosis and influence the immune system’s capacity to control infection. Specifically, we aim to define components of the vaginal microbiota that confer protection, thus providing tools for the development of prophylactic and therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) is among the first to test the efficacy of a behavioral intervention for achieiving durable increases in prevention effective pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) adherence among stimulant-using men who have sex with men (MSM). Smartphone-based contingency management for directly observed PrEP doses is a potentially scalable intervention platform that will be augmented by a brief, evidence-based ARTEMIS positive affect intervention. Findings from this RCT will inform the targeted deployment of limited public health funding to reduce HIV incidence in this marginalized, underserved population of stimulant-using MSM that is a high priority for novel HIV prevention interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atypical sensitivity to sensory stimuli is a hallmark of multiple disorders including autism, schizophrenia, fragile X and others. We propose to use a simple well-defined model with conserved signaling pathways to understand how disease-associated genes like neurexin and neuroligin affect brain function. We aim to use our model to develop new early diagnostic tools and identify new targets for therapeutic intervention in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite several ground-breaking advances in the treatment of lung cancer, the overall outlook remains dismal, necessitating the urgent development of preventive therapies. We have observed that use of the anti-diabetic drug metformin is associated with improved lung cancer outcomes selectively in patients who are overweight and obese and have linked this association to metformin-induced immunological changes in both humans and mice. With a clinical trial and mouse experiments, we propose to study if the anti-cancer immune effect of metformin occurs in obese subjects who have a high risk for developing lung cancer occurs so that the drug may be used for cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structured RNA elements are critical for regulating eukaryotic gene expression by diverse mechanisms, including at the level of translation. Our goal is to uncover fundamental rules governing control of translation by RNA structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Continuous glucose monitors (CGM) improve glycemic control, health related quality of life and treatment satisfaction in individuals with type 1 diabetes, and are recommended as standard of care practice in both children and adults with type 1 diabetes. Despite these benefits, CGMs are underutilized, particularly among minorities and individuals from underserved communities. In this proposal, we aim to develop the role and toolkit of a diabetes navigator, who will be implemented in the real-world clinical setting to help increase CGM uptake and sustained CGM use, as a means to improve glycemic control and mitigate disparities in care and outcomes across the lifespan for underserved individuals with type 1 diabetes.
