IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryo-EM data processing for structural biology improves and accelerates drug discovery that treats diseases and is driving innovation, economic growth, and happening in the pharma industry. Our proposed continuing education program aims to develop a portable continuing education solution with integrated data, software, workflow, and a sustainable computing environment that trains diverse cohorts of structural biology investigators to strengthen their Cryo-EM data processing skills, as well as enables them with a training solution that they could adapt and use in continuing education programs in Cryo-EM data processing at their home institution or local community. This enhanced research training program will have the potential to provide and scale sustainable continuing education in Cryo-EM data processing to a diverse group of individuals for a biomedical career of the future.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trisomy 21 is thought to broadly impact the development, transcriptome, and activity of many neural cell types. However, the extent to which DS alters each is conflicted and potentially overestimated by variability not due to trisomy. Reducing variability through “trisomy silencing” will increase the power to detect legitimate effects of trisomy 21 in different neural cell types, when during development changes occur, and which remain correctable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are currently no clinical biomarker tests available to assess risk of recurrence in women diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer or HER2+ breast cancer. The goal of this study is to validate an assay that measures expression of genes associated good prognosis. If successful, this could be the first clinical test available to guide therapy decisions based on risk of recurrence in triple negative breast cancer and HER2+ breast cancer patients.

PHR: Project Narrative The human and mouse endometrium can respond to acute or chronic injuries with scar-free regeneration. This application proposes an integrative set of studies that will define critical physiological and genetic pathways that regulate the remarkable regenerative capacity of the uterine epithelium upon injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Cognitive impairment associated with normative aging and with the early stages of Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias (ADOD) often result in loss of independent living, but few effective therapeutic strategies exist to predict, prevent, or treat it. Recent studies have suggested that altered neuroinflammatory signaling may play an important early role in normative aging, and in ADOD, but the mechanisms by which the complex interaction of pro- and anti-inflammatory pathways change over the lifespan, relate to changes in brain microstructure/morphology, or modulate cognition are unclear. The proposed research in this application will use state-of-the-art neuroscience technologies (CSF protein biomarker assays, PET imaging of activated microglia, MRI, NODDI, and cognitive assessment) in a naturally-occurring animal model of age- related cognitive impairment to identify early markers of neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration that are associated with age-related changes in brain morphology/microstructure and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative A major feature of substance use disorders is compulsive drug use: habitual drug-seeking behavior that is rigid, inflexible, and often triggered by particular cues and contexts in the user’s environment. The experiments in this proposal will help us understand the brain mechanisms by which drug-seeking, like other forms of reward- seeking, can initially be “goal-directed” – i.e., driven by the pursuit of a desired outcome, such as euphoria or relief from withdrawal – and later become habitual. In particular, we will investigate how different parts of the amygdala, a brain area involved in forming associations between cues and rewards, are involved in the initial acquisition of reward seeking vs. the formation of habits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Following weight loss, the new lower body weight is extremely difficult to maintain. Many studies have shown this is because individuals who lose a significant amount of body weight typically have a “Calorie Gap” post- weight loss, meaning that after weight loss, it requires fewer calories to maintain this new weight than it does for individuals at that same weight who never had obesity. A brain neurochemical, called orexin, drives calorie- burning. In this application, we will test whether peripheral administration of compounds mimicking orexin reverse this “calorie gap”, and thus prevent weight regain in animal models of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to test the effectiveness of a novel behavioral treatment for nondaily smokers; namely a smartphone app that engages app users in positive psychology exercises to bolster their positive affect as they undergo the process of quitting smoking. This app has been rigorously and iteratively developed with and for nondaily smokers. If found effective, it would be the first treatment for nondaily smokers found to be effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal addresses a significant clinical problem of obesity-mediated worsening of asthma. By assembling a multidisciplinary team of scientists, we propose to study a new mechanism, mitochondrial dysfunction, in the pathogenesis of obese asthma, a heterogenous disease currently without specific therapies. Our research findings likely provide several key targets including Parkin and TLR9 to treat obese asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Latinos have a disproportionately higher risk of cardiometabolic disease, further compounded by disparities in socioeconomic status. Although the role of nutrition education and physical activity has been investigated, evidence on culturally-adapted multicomponent synergistic interventions in this population is lacking, especially interventions that consider Latino ethnic heritages. This proposal aims to evaluate the feasibility of a culturally- adapted Teaching Kitchen (TK) model program, a multicomponent synergistic intervention (nutrition education, culinary training, enhanced movement and exercise, mindfulness training, and health coaching) in a sample of Latinos of diverse ethnic heritages and low income to reduce cardiometabolic risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The goal of this project is to engineer therapeutic immune cells that migrate to and accumulate in tumors, such that they can more effectively kill tumor cells. The resulting next-generation therapeutic immune cells could lead to much more effective therapies against a broad range of challenging solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most intriguing findings in the field of cancer immunotherapy is the recent demonstration that the gut microbiome regulates immune and clinical antitumor responses to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) in cancer patients. Here, we propose to identify whether a baseline beneficial and a detrimental gut microbiome predict clinical outcome and immune-related adverse events to ICB in cancer patients. We will also investigate whether fecal microbiota transplant convert ICB-refractory cancer patients into responders and impede the occurrence of serious adverse events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diverse subtypes of retinal ganglion cells send parallel outputomes to retinorecipient regions, including the superior colliculus (tectum), an evolutionarily conserved midbrain structure, mediating visual evoked innate behaviors. We propose to map out parallel retinotectal circuits, understand cellular and molecular mechanisms regulating specific retinotectal circuit wiring, and link specific retinotectal circuits to defined visual evoked behaviors. Our studies will reveal wiring principles for synaptic convergence and divergence in the mammalian brain and provide significant insights into higher visual processing.

PHR: Narrative Vascular cognitive impairment is one of the most prevalent causes of age-related decline of brain health. Vascular changes precede neuronal alterations thus they provide targets for potential, new therapeutic approaches. Thermogenesis positively affects metabolism and systemic inflammation thus it can be used as a therapeutic option to boost cerebrovascular health and cognitive status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Female-controlled prevention methods against sexual HIV-1 transmission and pregnancy are critically needed. Here, we propose to develop an innovative platform for long-acting HIV prevention and contraception by integrating antiviral drug delivery onto an innovative shape-memory copper-containing intrauterine device. This approach will empower and provide women with a multipurpose technology for effective control of their reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida albicans is the leading fungal pathogen of humans, responsible for ~100 million mucocutaneous infections and ~500,000 invasive infections every year; despite the devastating impact of these diseases, only a handful of drugs are available for treating invasive infections, with mortality reaching ~40%. This project will build and leverage the most comprehensive functional genomic resource for a fungal pathogen to provide a global view of genes that are required for this opportunistic pathogen to thrive in the host and cause disease. By developing high-quality comprehensive datasets and strain resources for the community using cutting-edge methods, this investment will transform the field, yielding unexpected biological insights and facilitating the development of much-needed antifungal drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Anxiety and stress are recognized as major contributors to the motivation as to why people use alcohol to excess. This study focuses on gaining understanding into the mechanisms by which alcohol modulates anxiety. Specifically, this work will characterize a potential genetic source of individual variability in stress-dependent alcohol misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Automating the Discovery of Clinically-Relevant Intracellular Signaling Responses in Immune Cell-Types Technological advancements in high-parameter mass cytometry (CyTOF) have enabled comprehensive charac- terization of the immune system at unparalleled depths in clinical settings. Ex-vivo stimulation is used to identify clinically-predictive intracellular signaling responses across immune-cell types, but the data produced 1) require an extensive amount of manual labor to analyze and 2) generates a large number of immunological features that do not all directly describe canonical signaling pathways. This project will develop algorithms to integrate single-cells across patient, clinical outcomes, and stimulation conditions to automatically identify cell-populations with clinically-predictive intracellular signaling responses to stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The lack of valid and reliable RDoC behavioral tasks and measures for identifying areas of overlap and distinction between negative and positive motivational systems in the human brain represents a significant barrier to public health research on a variety of neuropsychiatric disorders. The long-term goal of this project is to demonstrate the psychometric strength and the diagnostic and predictive validity of a user-friendly AP-AV task that we’ve developed for use in behavioral and neuroimaging research. Outcomes of this project include a flexible paradigm for immediate use in human research, and empirical data that lay the foundation for future investigations into the paradigm’s suitability for use with individuals who vary widely in age, ability, and/or severity of distress and/or dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) causes major disease in neonates and transplant patients. HCMV infects many different cell types, by using different viral glycoproteins and our studies will focus on how HCMV glycoproteins mediate virus entry into different cells. These HCMV glycoproteins are also major targets of host immunity and the subject of intense interest for vaccines and we will study human anti-glycoprotein antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune-mediated eye disease is a pathological hallmark of multiple systemic autoimmune diseases. With a severe lack in efficacious treatment options that is driven by a combination of inadequate early detection strategies and a poor understanding of disease mechanisms, patients suffer life-long morbidity. Using innovative new technologies, we seek to define the mechanisms driving dry eye disease development at the single cell level, with the goal of discovering new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative We are proposing to establish the Indiana University Bloomington Center for Cannabis, Cannabinoids, and Addiction to support drug abuse researchers across the central Midwest and around the nation. The Center consists of research cores to support the work of these researchers as they measure lipid biomarkers associated with addiction and apply cutting-edge optical imaging to learn how drug addiction affects brain anatomy and function. The Center will also have a strong educational component to bring more researchers into drug addiction research, particularly drawing from populations not well-represented in the field and to train scientists in the cutting-edge technologies used in the Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Peanut Allergy (PA) has emerged as a major clinical and public health problem worldwide. This prospective birth cohort study aims to investigate T cell receptor ß-chain (TCRß) repertoire features and changes during the first two years of life in relation to the risk of developing PA; and further examine the interplay of TCRß repertoires with potentially modifiable early life factors such as nutrition and metabolomic alteration on PA. Successful completion of this study will help to identify novel biomarkers for early risk assessment and new targets for effective interventions during the earliest developmental windows when they may have the greatest life-long benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effectively engaging men in HIV prevention remains one of the greatest challenges to driving the HIV epidemic towards elimination in sub-Saharan Africa. The objective of this project is to use an implementation science approach to establish the impact of HIV self-test distribution through male social networks, with innovative community-based support on pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake among men in Eastern Zimbabwe. Such a strategy aims to engage hard-to-reach men, decrease barriers to the uptake of male HIV testing prevention by reducing the need for engagement with clinics and seeks to expedite subsequent uptake of PrEP. We will use the findings of the study to model the potential population level impacts and cost-effectiveness of male peer to peer HIVST distribution strategies on the uptake of PrEP in HIV hyper-endemic settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Word learning represents one of the major difficulties experienced by children with developmental language disorder (DLD). In this project, children with DLD participate in activities that emphasize the frequent recall of newly introduced words with the goal of significantly improving these children’s word learning outcomes. Findings from this project might serve as the foundation for the development of new methods of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This postbaccalaureate training program is designed to provide two-year research opportunities and professional development activities to recently graduated people from diverse backgrounds that were at an undergraduate institute with limited research opportunities. Program participants are expected to develop novel research projects that will provide important new insights into the neurobiology underlying drug use and addiction. The research and education activities of the program will prepare the program participants for successful matriculation into neuroscience- related Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D. programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  Tissue patterning is a fundamental process that establishes complex skin architectures required for optimal skin functions. We have used the developing skin as experimental models to study the morphogenetic processes involved in the generation of multiple appendage units, the formation of cyclic renewable follicles, and the assembly of the muscle network. The newly learned principles and concepts will enhance our ability to promote tissue patterning in engineered skin and to move forward toward applications in future regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The function of many rogue, disease-causing proteins cannot not be easily blocked using a small molecule drug approach, hence they are ‘undruggable’. To address this, we propose to simply eliminate or inactivate these unwanted proteins from the body instead of trying to use drugs to block their function. Here we describe the development of a new classes of drugs that target ‘undruggable’ proteins for destruction or inactivation and propose to implement these new pharmaceutical strategies against problem proteins that play key roles in oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative Osteoarthritis is a common and serious disease, and there are likely multiple different subtypes, or phenotypes. This proposal will enhance the candidate’s abilities and capacities in patient-oriented research (POR) and mentoring through aims focused on the intersection of POR, health equity (opportunities for all to have good health), and machine learning (computer algorithms) to examine different osteoarthritis phenotypes in two diverse population-based cohorts, leveraging extensive existing data. The proposed midcareer investigator award project represents a necessary step towards understanding risk factors and outcomes in osteoarthritis and is relevant to the NIAMS mission of achieving health equity and understanding differences in disease across diverse groups of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary focus of this project is to investigate the neural mechanisms of age-related attentional distractibility, focusing on the neural circuit between the locus coeruleus and the salience network (LC-SN), by utilizing both human brain imaging and an animal-model based circuit-selective gene manipulation approach. We will examine the effects of aging on the LC-SN network using a mouse model, test whether LC-SN dysconnectivity increases attentional distractibility in human older adults, and rescue the attentional deficit in both aged mice and human older adults (including, as an exploratory variable, family history of Alzheimer’s disease within our human studies). The successful implementation of this research may have significant translational implications to identify and protect against attentional declines in the context of typical aging, as well as among those at-risk for ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Viral infections like SARS-CoV-2 can induce devastating damage on the lungs resulting in the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Neutrophils are an immediate responder to viral pneumonia and release neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in an attempt to help control infections. In this proposal, we will generate new understanding on how NETs contribute to COVID-19-induced ARDS, and test new strategies to prevent and/or treat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While diabetes is a known complication of acute pancreatitis (AP), a full understanding of the underlying etiology of this disorder is lacking. To address this gap in knowledge, we have assembled a multidisciplinary team at Indiana University, with expertise in exocrine pancreas pathophysiology, diabetes, β cell biology, genetics, and pancreatic imaging. As part of the newly formed Type 1 Diabetes in Acute Pancreatitis Consortium, members of the Indiana University Clinical Center will collaborate with other consortium members to undertake studies focused on the comprehensive clinical, epidemiological, biological and imaging characterization of diabetes occurring after AP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The trajectory of the COVID-19 epidemic is shaped by individual behavior. We propose the development of new transmission models of COVID-19 and seasonal inﬂuenza that study the interplay between individual behavior and transmission dynamics, while considering important uncertainties, such as seasonal effects and the loss of immunity. Building on our prior work on vaccination behaviors for inﬂuenza and the transmission of COVID-19, these models will be informed by tailored longitudinal surveys, observed behavior, and case data from the ongoing pandemic, and we will develop tools that run our models and allow users to identify the effects of behavioral factors on policy effectiveness, evaluate the potential impact of vaccine availability, and identify strategies that are robust to a wide range of uncertainties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The I-SPY 2 neoadjuvant breast cancer clinical trial is a personalized, adaptive trial designed to improve outcomes in high-risk breast cancer patients. This study seeks to unravel the complex interactions between intrinsic host germline and tumor somatic mutations, and extrinsic tumor microenvironment features that drive the biology of response or resistance to therapy. This research aims to generate genomic and tumor microenvironment response-predictive biomarkers that improve on current qualifying biomarkers – providing better stratification of patients and directing them to best predicted interventions – and that identify possible alternative treatment strategies for non-responders – reducing unnecessary therapeutic burden.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Data Coordinating and Operations Center (DCOC) for the IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network will facilitate the development, implementation and reporting on multicenter clinical trials that address the health needs of children living in IDeA states. Since populations in IDeA states are disproportionately rural and medically underserved, the clinical trials findings should have implications for those populations. The DCOC will also collaborate with the clinical investigators in enhancing the clinical trial workforce to improve the environment for conducting clinical trials in the IDeA states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study is novel in applying the theoretical perspective of work-family conflict to ADRD caregivers with psychoneuroimmunological methods. If our hypotheses are supported, researchers will better understand the role of employment as a risk factor to caregivers’ psychosocial functioning and chronic inflammaiton. By identifying if employment and psychosocial variables are predictors of higher chronic inflamation, we will be better able to identify caregivers most at risk and tailor effective interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective targeted therapies remain to be found for pancreatic cancer, the 3rd leading cause of cancer deaths in the US, and surpassing colorectal cancer in 2020 to become the 2nd leading cause of cancer deaths. With KRAS mutations found in ~95% of pancreatic cancers, it is well-accepted that effective anti-KRAS therapies will provide successful treatments for this deadly cancer. Based on recent unpublished observations, we propose four provocative directions not widely pursued by the RAS and cancer research field to make “undruggable” KRAS druggable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: US HELPING US, PEOPLE INTO LIVING, INC.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stark inequities in pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) use, retention in PrEP care, PrEP adherence, and PrEP protection persist among Black sexual minority men (SMM) and HIV incidence continues to increase among certain segment of Black SMM, especially those in the Southeastern United States (U.S.). This signifies a critical failure of the U.S. public health system and the need to: (1) investigate the concomitant and intersecting associations of anticipated, perceptions, and experiences of RD at multiple levels with key PrEP continuum outcomes; (2) assess the moderating effects of resiliency factors on the link between multilevel RD and PrEP continuum outcomes, and (3) triangulate quantitative, qualitative and social mapping data to validate causal relationships and identify possible social-structural and/or strengths-based interventions that may mitigate the effects of multilevel RD on PrEP continuum outcomes. The combination of novel multilevel RD and resiliency measures and robust phenotypic PrEP biomarker data, in addition to the study population and location, represents a significant advancement in HIV prevention and has the potential to increase the number of Black SMM who initiate and adhere to PrEP and ultimately reduce HIV incidence, which aligns with the federal plan to End the HIV Epidemic by 2030, the National HIV/AIDS Strategy and funding priorities of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Langerhans cells are resident cells of skin that participate in the immune responses. We propose to study leprosy as a model to gain insight into the mechanism by which Langerhans cells indirectly contribute to host defense against infection by the activation of T cells and directly mediate antimicrobial responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Penicillins are essential antibiotics for the resolution of gram-positive bacterial infections. The development of chemoenzymatic strategies for the green chemical synthesis of penicillin-class antibiotics can help to increase their availability and decrease the cost of production. In the present work we join the activities of an engineered aldehyde dehydrogenase from the bacterial styrene catabolic pathway and the fungal isopenicillanic acid N-acyltransferase to generate a new route for the synthesis of penicillins from 6-aminopenicillanic acid and aldehyde stating materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative von Willebrand factor (vWF) is essential for normal hemostasis and thrombosis and is involved in other important processes such as angiogenesis and cancer cell metastasis. Regulated release of vWF depends on normal maturation of its storage granule, the Weibel-Palade bodies (WPBs), and subsequent fusion of WPBs to the plasma membrane, processes which are poorly understood. Using live cell microscopy, pulldown of endogenously tagged proteins, and a genetically modified mouse model, we propose to elucidate the endosomal pathway in WPB biogenesis, the associated trafficking machinery, and regulation of WPB exocytosis by the exocyst complex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of the proposed research is to determine how common genetic variants and environmental risk factors predispose to the development, natural history, and phenotypic heterogeneity of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (IIP) by establishing and prospectively evaluating a cohort of subjects at high-risk of familial interstitial pneumonia (FIP). Our proposed rare disease cohort focuses on a critical unmet public health need in interstitial pneumonia, to understand the etiology, natural history, and phenotypic heterogeneity of preclinical pulmonary fibrosis (PrePF), before the lung is scarred irreversibly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will provide a system for the scalable continuous evolution and computational design of antibodies against user-selected antigens. Antibodies are critical tools in medical research and are the basis for numerous therapies, but the generation of custom antibodies against new targets is a difficult and specialized task. The system proposed will turn antibody generation into a routine and widely accessible process for researchers in almost any field.
